story:
As the Artistic Director of the Brooklyn based, Evidence, A Dance Company, founded in 1985, we have been dedicated to creating dance for the body and soul.  We are raising money for our newest piece,set to the music of Jason Moran.  


The Indiegogo campaign will allow our Circle of Friends to have a sense of ownership with the knowledge that their contributions are essential to making The Subtle One a vital addition to the Evidence repertory. 

The funds will be used for dancers salaries, as well as fees for our Lighting and Costume Designers, critical to the production.  The Subtle One will become a part of touring repertory with dates in North Carolina, Washington, DC and other stops during our 30th Anniversary tour.  

During the development of this new dance we will share video clips of rehearsals, conversations with the dancers and the research/writings that will give you a window in to the process.  

Each gift, no matter what size, makes a difference.   I think folks will understand the journey as the The Subtle One, as we collectively embrace; 

So subtle are the wings of angels

that you may not realize 

they've come and gone, except

that innerly remains a glowing

which seems just as good as knowing

Folks who can not donate....please spread the word that Evidence is working on a new work that celebrates the human spirit.

story:
Who we are

Marquez Dance Project (MDP) explores human complexity through a creative lens. The intention behind our work is to recapture moments that speak to the community by raising questions about what is happening within our society, and challenging individuals to mobilize. We incorporate theatrical, physical and often surreal imagery to generate meaningful and provoking works. Dance is the central component, however we collaborate with other artists from different genres. Making these connections enriches the breadth of the work and allows a broader range of artistic investigation. 

Creating a strong foundation within society is an important concern of MDP.  Since 2009, we have focused on linking performers and community members through workshops and master classes. These programs allow individuals to move freely and create with open minds in a positive environment. In providing these generous exchanges we hope to develop a strong advocacy for the arts within the community.

La Femme Project

What does it mean to be a woman in today’s society? What obstacles does a woman face regularly and how does she handle them? Does society automatically place limits on what women are capable of? How can we tackle these biases and create a new foundation for the younger generation. La Femme discusses these topics and faces them head on.

We examine these issues in more detail over 3 parts: a solo, duet and group. The solo conveys the topic male gaze and how this is a common battle for women. We observe one woman's fight against it, how at times she succumbs to the pressures as well as find ways to manipulate the system to obtain her way. The duet is a reflection of the past and a glimpse of the future between two women and how sexism, false perceptions and social media can impact their lives. How do they acknowledge and navigate their way through these issues while discovering their own true identity. Finally, the group section dives into matters of discrimination and violence among women. We view the cause and effect of these prejudices through personal accounts from performers and members of the community how they've overcome these obstacles and restore their sense of empowerment. 

“La Femme,” is directed and conceived by Jennifer Eccher. Choreography by the performers of MDP. Original music composed by John Osburn. Performances by Katherine Brent, Amy Compton, Jennifer Eccher, Tanya Mucci, Shannon Sefcik & Kenya Woods.

Your Contribution

We need your support in getting this project moving forward. Our performance is February 27th - March 1st and your contribution will help defray production costs. All funding will go directly into performer's fees, composer fees, designer fees, marketing and videography. 

The Impact

This performance is just the start, we plan to create an empowerment program for teenage women who have been involved in an abusive relationship. The purpose in developing this program is to provide a caring, supportive environment for them to discuss their experiences and help them understand what a healthy relationship means through creative movement and writing. The objective is establishing a positive space where they can regain, rebuild and restore their voices.

Spread the Word

Please help us build our audience by spreading the word about this show. The more people in attendance the more we can bring awareness to these prejudices which can potentially help motivate a change in our society. 

Cleveland Public Theatre  Big Box '14

February 27 - March 1

James Levin Theatre; 7:00pm

Tickets for Big Box are $12 - $18

Take advantage of $12 Thursday

or

Free Beer Friday - Hang out after the show to mingle with friends and artists while enjoying a free drink on us!

Tickets may be purchased online www.cptonline.org, by calling (216) 631-2727 extension 501, or in person at our box office.

Cleveland Public Theatre

6415 Detroit Avenue

Cleveland, Oh 44102

story:
Original Works Original Artists.

This showcase of talent from the local Rhode Island area will be The Enterprise Theater Company's first show. This show will include an art exhibit from some of the local artists. This will include photography, paintings, and even a film exhibit. The main event is comprised of three original one act plays being designed, directed, and performed from local talent. A live musical performance will accompany each show by a local band.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we receive will be divided as such:
 
  • Space rental fees from Courthouse Center for the Arts
  • Supplies for set design and props
  • Transportation expenses for the bands and other equipment

Should we receive more money than needed, the surplus will be directed towards organizing and producing our next production or event.

Contributing to our cause will enable you to perks such as:

 

  • A special mention as an honored patron in our program
  • A signed poster by the cast and crew of the show
  • Free tickets to the show
  • An original piece donated by one of the Artists

 

The Impact

Our goal for this event is to start an entertainment and arts company that benefits the community of Rhode Island. We seek to stimulate the culture of the local community and its people. Providing an atmosphere of entertainment, education, and higher thinking is one of our goals. Exposure to undiscovered talent is a prime motivator for us. This first show, "Original Works Original Artists", is the first step in adding to the prestige of Rhode Island and the New England area.

Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest way you can help our cause and your community is to come out to the show! Bring your friends along! We guaranty an entertaining night. If you can support us with a monetary donation, supporting the show and the local talent is all that we can ask for. Spreading the word about how talented and culture rich the Rhode Island area is one of the greatest ways that you can help.

story:
PRÉSENTATION

 

Nous sommes deux collectifs issus de l’émergence artistique de la ville de Québec :

 

L’Insoutenable // Claudelle Houde Labrecque et Nelly Paquentin

C’est le paradoxe entre l’équilibre et la chute. Deux êtres poussés par la nécessité de créer ensemble, quelque chose de immensurable.

Le Théâtre de l’Impie // Maxime Milhorat Gusteau et Auréliane Macé

Le Théâtre de l’Impie revendique un art engagé, affranchi des contraintes de la représentation traditionnelle, qui cherche à heurter la conscience politique du public

 

Animées par une envie commune de création, nous avons décidé de soumettre nos projets à l’organisme de diffusion nomade Joker Joker. Nos deux créations ont donc été choisies et mises en résonance pour lancer leur programmation 2019 sous forme de programme double.

 

Dans un lieu unique, encore inconnu, nous allons performer du 12 au 16 février 2019, au sein de deux univers distincts et texturés.

 

NOS PROJETS

 

Under

 

C’est un choix.

Celui de s’exposer et de se soustraire au regard, d’une manière peu conventionnelle.

C’est la confrontation entre l’intérieur et l’extérieur,

L’échange d’un malaise pour un inconfort plus grand, à la limite de l’intolérable.

 

C’est une et plusieurs métaphores.

La tragédie du conformisme,

Mais aussi l'essoufflement d’un corps dans l’absurdité d’une situation provoquée.

La transformation d’un être pur.

Sa renaissance cathartique comme issue à l’insoutenable.


 

Requiem pour Martirio A.

 

Un canard en plastique

Une piscine gonflable

Une chaise longue et son coussin fleuri

Un party piscine raté

Une orgie de paillettes

Requiem pour Martirio A. est un combat entre deux performeuses, deux amies, deux supposées visions sur ce que doit être, faire, penser une femme. Dans cette performance féministe en trois actes, elles se commettent dans l'épuisement et la salissure physique.

C'est La Vierge et la Putain qui s'affrontent dans un vomi de glitter

Et celle qui doit se noyer se noiera.

 

CE QUI NOUS ANIME

L’Insoutenable et le Théâtre de l’Impie sont impatientes de vous présenter leurs projets de créations respectifs! D’autant plus que les représentations de février 2019 seront pour la majorité des membres des deux collectifs, une première expérience de diffusion et de production professionnelles. Under et Requiem pour Martirio A. constituent donc une étape marquante et essentielle dans le cheminement de ces jeunes artistes de la relève.

Nous et nos collaboratrices avons porté ces deux projets de longue haleine depuis plus d’un an déjà, avec passion, énergie, dévouement, sur la scène ou derrière un écran d’ordinateur. Nous sommes fébriles de voir nos idées les plus folles se réaliser enfin, concrètement, et de pouvoir vous les présenter à cinq reprises, dans un cadre original (et encore tenu secret …).

Cette collaboration bicéphale nous tient à coeur : grâce à votre aide, vous nous permettez de la faire vivre et de la rendre pérenne.

 

Merci pour votre curiosité, votre audace, votre générosité.

Merci à vous de soutenir l’émergence performative et créatrice.

 

À QUOI SERVIRONT VOS CONTRIBUTIONS?

 

Vos contributions nous serons essentielles pour mener à bien notre projet. Comme vous le savez, les temps sont durs pour les artistes de la relève, l'ère est au capitalisme et non à la culture. Nous vous avons concocté deux beaux projets qui sont prêts à être sacrifiés par le public.

Afin de vous proposer la meilleure version de nos deux créations nous avons besoin de fonds pour effectuer la production, la conception scénographique, des éclairages et autres cascades en tout genre.

D'un point de vue plus pragmatique, nous souhaitons nous offrir des conditions de travail dignes ainsi qu’à nos collaborateurs-rices. Nous croyons que le travail artistique ne doit pas être bénévole, nous souhaitons que toutes et chacunes puissent se consacrer entièrement à la création sans avoir une épée de Damoclès financière au dessus de la tête.

story:
Hello, my name is Alanna Phillips and I am currently a company member at LaShelle's School of Dance in Detroit, Michigan. I have been dancing for 8 years and I am now 16 years old. I participate in ballet, tap, pointe, jazz, modern and hip hop. At the studio, I am also a junior staff member. Besides dancing at the studio I am an uprising junior at Renaissance High School and I maintain a 3.5 grade point average. I also am a member of the dance workshop at school. This year I won 3 first place trophies for my tap solo on the regional level and placed 2nd at Nationals in Orlando, FL. I am very dedicated to dance and serious about having a career as a professional dancer someday!

As many of you know, last summer I was on a mission to get to a special dance program in Buffalo New York and I made it thanks to your support and generosity!   This year I'm on a mission to New York again, but I can only do it with your help...

I just found out about a program I would LOVE to participate in. This up coming August, I am hoping to attend a summer dance intensive in NYC but having just returned from nationals in Orlando, I don't quite have enough funds for the trip. Broadway Dance Centre will be hosting a 4 day long Intensive where I will be taking 7 classes a day in different genres of dance from New York's top choreographers. I will also have the opportunity  to meet  with agents and take classes with dancers from all over the country. My family can cover travel and lodging but it is getting down to the deadline and I still need help with the registration fees.  I really want to go so I'm trying to do whatever I can to make it happen.

By participating in this summer program, I believe it will help me diversify and improve my dancing. Anytime I take classes from different teachers, I realize that I am adding a new style to my dance knowledge and increasing my skills. Only with the help of your donations will I be able to achieve the goal of becoming a better dancer by attending this Intensive Program. I appreciate anything you can give!

Thanks for stopping by my page :-)  I hope you enjoyed the video! If you want to read more about the intensive you can go to http://www.broadwaydancecenter.com/workshops/summer_workshop/index.shtml

story:
Our Story

Theatrum Elysium offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, Theatrum Elysium strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us.

True to its name, Theatrum Elysium is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, Theatrum Elysium is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We at Theatrum Elysium are committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

The Production

Theatrum Elysium invites audiences to join us this summer as we celebrate the inauguration of our new outdoor stage with a bold and exhilarating production of William  Shakespeare’s oft-forgotten epic, Cymbeline.  Vibrantly brought to life by Artistic Director Aaron Ganz, Cymbeline takes audiences through a spirited adventure teeming with the Bard’s familiar themes of forbidden romances, betrayed relationships, and the mayhem of war, and reinvigorates them with a dynamic and refreshing theatrical vision.

One of Shakespeare’s final works, Cymbeline follows the tale of Cymbeline, the King of Britain and his only daughter, the beautiful Imogen.  Under the sway of the ambitious new Queen, Cymbeline promises her son Cloten not only Imogen as his wife, but a greater seat of power.  Upon discovering that Imogen has secretly married a commoner for love rather than politics, the royal family is spurred into a rage and Cymbeline banishes her lover.  With the kingdom knocked into chaos by scandal and a looming political threat fromRome, Imogen escapes from her father’s court and embarks on a journey to reunite with her love—however, she is far from being free from danger.  Imogen’s path thrusts her into a fantastical world of alchemy, disguises, and treachery, which she must overcome in order to find not only her husband, but the hidden strength within herself.

Theatrum Elysium’s Cymbeline offers theatre-goers a production that does not simply “take place outdoors”—but rather a rare opportunity to be transported into the vivid, but often dangerous, world of Shakespeare’s imagination.  Infused with expressive choreography, riveting music, explosive battle scenes, and a narrator to guide audiences through the flurry of adventures, this theatrical experience rediscovers the magic and mystery of mistaken identity, star-crossed lovers, and the dreams that define us all.

 

What We Need & What You Get 

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on Theatrum Elysium's CYMBELINE - opening August 8th, 2012!

The Goal: $1,000 for the show's production budget and marketing efforts!

Theatrum Elysium is giving all supporters of our inaugural production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

The Production
Theatrum Elysium invites audiences to join us this summer as we celebrate the inauguration of our new outdoor stage with a bold and exhilarating production of William  Shakespeare’s oft-forgotten epic, Cymbeline.  Vibrantly brought to life by Artistic Director Aaron Ganz, Cymbeline takes audiences through a spirited adventure teeming with the Bard’s familiar themes of forbidden romances, betrayed relationships, and the mayhem of war, and reinvigorates them with a dynamic and refreshing theatrical vision.
One of Shakespeare’s final works, Cymbeline follows the tale of Cymbeline, the King of Britain and his only daughter, the beautiful Imogen.  Under the sway of the ambitious new Queen, Cymbeline promises her son Cloten not only Imogen as his wife, but a greater seat of power.  Upon discovering that Imogen has secretly married a commoner for love rather than politics, the royal family is spurred into a rage and Cymbeline banishes her lover.  With the kingdom knocked into chaos by scandal and a looming political threat fromRome, Imogen escapes from her father’s court and embarks on a journey to reunite with her love—however, she is far from being free from danger.  Imogen’s path thrusts her into a fantastical world of alchemy, disguises, and treachery, which she must overcome in order to find not only her husband, but the hidden strength within herself.
Theatrum Elysium’s Cymbeline offers theatre-goers a production that does not simply “take place outdoors”—but rather a rare opportunity to be transported into the vivid, but often dangerous, world of Shakespeare’s imagination.  Infused with expressive choreography, riveting music, explosive battle scenes, and a narrator to guide audiences through the flurry of adventures, this theatrical experience rediscovers the magic and mystery of mistaken identity, star-crossed lovers, and the dreams that define us all.
 
What We Need & What You Get 


Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on Theatrum Elysium's CYMBELINE - opening August 8th, 2012!
The Goal: $1,000 for the show's production budget and marketing efforts!
Theatrum Elysium is giving all supporters of our inaugural production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
Summary

Hello,

I am a homeschooling parent in Chicago.  My daughter loves Marie Curie.  We found a program coming to town called Manya - A Living History of Marie Curie.  It will be performed at a Northwestern University conference on infrared optoelectronic materials and devices.  I visited the Manya website and was excited by the description.  It sounded perfect for theatrical and sciency students.  Unfortunately, admission was restricted to university students and conference attendees.  I had a few conversations with the artist in Colorado to see if we could arrange another showing.  It required negotiation with NU and a host of others, but we rolled through it.  The artist is so generous and committed to sharing Marie Curie's life that she has given us a really reduced rate.  Northwestern is also generous enough to allow us to "borrow" their artist on the plane ticket for which they paid.

By donating to this, you will be making this show available to school children and adults throughout the Chicago area.  Obviously, Northwestern thought it was a great enough show to be the closing act of their intense multi-day conference.  Our kids deserve to see it too.  

What We Need

The artist has been quite generous by charging the parent community a fraction of what she charges large organizations.  Still, we can't have the fee fall on a few on one family.  We need to raise enough to cover her fee, which she asks to not make public because it was a unique negotiation, and the fee indiegogo takes here.  

Admission will be open to the public free of charge otherwise.  Please make a donation to support the artist.

The Impact

Marie Curie has been an inspiration to young scientists for decades.  The program description from the Storysmith site explains exactly why your child and you might want to donate and attend.

Likely the most famous woman scientist, Madame Marie Curie (née Maria Skłodowska) — changed the world in which we live through her discovery of radium and radioactivity. Through collaboration with the medical community the Curies discovered and established the first successful radiation treatments of cancer. Simply through her own passion and perseverance, Marie Curie opened the doors of science to women world wide.

This program honors a preeminent woman of science : Madame Curie was the first European woman to earn a doctorate in the sciences; the first woman to receive a Nobel Prize (for the discovery of radioactivity); the first woman to teach at the Sorbonne; and the first person to receive a second Nobel Prize (a feat not to be repeated for another 50 years). Audiences witness the origins of scientific discoveries we now take for granted. They re-live the remarkable collaboration between husband and wife, Pierre and Marie, companion scientists.

This program honors the ethic of scientific altruism. Einstein said Marie Curie was "the only person to be uncorrupted by fame." In today's age of patents and litigation, the audience learns that the Curies declined to patent their methods, refused to bend their discoveries toward personal financial gain. Marie insisted that to profit from the discovery of radium would be "contrary to the scientific spirit."

This program honors the wife and mother, who felt more daunted by the chemistry of the kitchen than of the laboratory. As a single mother, Marie raised her two daughters from ages 16 months and 8 years, after the tragic death of her husband, Pierre. And it honors Manya's Polish heritage — much neglected not only now, but in her own life, to her own dismay. This program brings to light many of Marie's lesser-known contributions, both social and scientific — and the obstacles she faced along the way.

Marie Curie was, in turn, nervous and shy in public, obsessive about measurement, in denial of the dangers of working with radioactive materials, proud and possessive of her discoveries, yet generous to the extreme with the products of her work. Within her lifetime she saw the curative effects of radiation on cancer. Late in life she came to admit the dangers of working with radioactive materials. She died before the new understanding of the atom — initiated by her discoveries — produced the atomic bomb. Whether looking at Marie within her historical context or through the lens of a new millennium, this is a life that challenges our assumptions about what one person can achieve and the responsibilities of science.

We will have the longer show for older students:

  • MANYA - A Living History of Marie Curie. Two-hour, full-length adult program. The year is 1915. Wrapped in a context of the outset of the Great War, this program spans childhood memories, romance, scientific discoveries, honors, the disruptions incurred by fame, the pain of loss of her husband, and emergence.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot attend or contribute, please share the date!

story:
The Genesis:

In March of 2016, Raleigh actress and advocate Ashley Popio put out a call in search of women who would be interested in forming a theatre festival. She expected a handful of people, but when over 200 women responded, the Women's Theatre Festival was born!

At the initial meeting, Ashley shared some pretty staggering statistics about women's roles in the local theatre scene:

Of the 126 total theatrical productions in the Triangle in the 2014-2015 season, there were:

    Only 31 female-identified playwrights (24.6%)
    Only 39 female-identified directors (31%).

That means that for every show produced in the Triangle that was written by a woman, three shows were produced that were written by men. Men got three times as much exposure, recognition, and recompense for their theatrical writing than women last year.  That was not in 1950; that was LAST YEAR.

The women of WTF decided that they wanted to change that picture and tilt those percentages back towards equality. They created a festival where every work they produced was written by a woman, directed by a woman, had at least a 50% female cast, and utilized as many female technicians and designers as possible.


WTF & You

So how can you help WTF achieve this goal? You can invest in getting us started! To make this festival a reality, we need $12,000.

Here's a breakdown of some of the things we will need to pay for in the coming months:


    Marketing.  Posters, programs, and print ad space all fall under this umbrella. Marketing is one of the most important, and most expensive, parts of producing, but without it, people won't know we exist, and we won't have an audience for our art.
    Space.  The volume of shows rehearsing at once will require several different venues to be rented in order to provide everyone ample space to rehearse and perform.
    Royalties. While many of the shows we are producing are local, original works, others are held by organizations that require a per-production fee.
    Design Budgets. Sets, lights, costumes, sound...design is such a fundamental component of producing, and it is often underfunded. We want to ensure our productions receive high-quality designs.
    Insurance. Liability insurance, while not the most exciting part of the process, is a necessity. We take the safety and well-being of all our participants seriously.
    General Overhead. We need a PO Box for mail, general copy material (forms, surveys, contracts, etc), and a dedicated WTF telephone line...all things that help the administrative side of producing run a little bit smoother.

So where do you come in?
We need your contribution! This theatrical movement had a grassroots beginning, and that momentum can lead us to achieve our goal: creating an of-women, by-women festival. Every little bit you can give will bring us closer to making the WTF dream a reality.
To help sweeten the pot a bit, we've got a stellar list of perks to choose from. Find the level that works best for you and select it, and that perk is all yours!
(Please note: you don't have to select a perk to give; you can donate without a perk as well!)

Why WTF?

Right now, women are so underrepresented in theatre and film that they are almost invisible. Legislators, employers, doctors, lawyers, judges, police officers, insurance providers and many, many more people make decisions daily without knowing our side of the story. Theatre provokes empathy and understanding. More women's voices telling more women's stories could potentially change the course of history by changing the way people understand women, and therefore, the way that people make decisions that affect women.

We aim to create, produce, and promote extraordinary theatre by women. We also plan to offer talk-backs on both theatrical and topical subjects, and train women in skill sets that many of them were discouraged from learning, like lighting design, sound design and set design. By doing this, we hope to make it easier to hire women to work those jobs.  

We also plan to promote other productions, theatres, and artists in the area that are already fulfilling our mission so that they get rewarded for making good choices. Finally, by the year 2020, we hope to help most local theatres achieve a 50/50 gender balance in scriptwriting, directing, acting, and design.

The Glass Ceiling

So what's stopping us? There are several challenges that we expect to face. First of all, we are brand new.  All of our contacts, policies, and infrastructure have to be created as we go. That takes time and a lot of work.

Secondly, because this is our first year, we have no financial cushion to fall back on.  If we make it through this year, that will hopefully change, but for now, we start with nothing.

Finally, despite the fact that endemic and institutionalized discrimination against women is rampant, many people either don't know about it or refuse to believe it. Many times, we here at WTF get asked, "Why do we even need a Women's Theatre Festival?"  The data about women only writing one in four produced pieces and directing one in three is virtually unknown.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, and we understand that.  Some ways you can help without spending a dime would be:


    Spread the word about us on your social media platforms. Like and share this campaign with a personal message about why you support us.
    Send our story to your local news agencies (both on TV, in print, and web-based)
    Get involved with our movement by volunteering! Write to info@womenstheatrefestival.com if you're interested in signing up for our volunteer base.

Women's Theatre Festival is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Women's Theatre Festival must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

** Please note: Starting July 20, due to an early printing deadline, we are unable to honor printing new backers in our official WTF program. We will do everything we can to find an appropriate substitute for this particular perk. Everything else in the perks are still available. We apologize for any inconvenience, and we greatly appreciate your support!

story:
Let me introduce to you 555 Contemporary Dance Company, a DreamMaker Project of the Ink People. We are a performance troupe consisting of dancers from all over Humboldt county varying in different levels and styles of dance. Our philosophy of Dance is to give purpose behind  every movement; our dancers are story tellers. We strive to pull the audience into another world and communicate through art. We believe that Dance is the purest of art forms, as the dancer becomes the art itself. Our mission is to grow as a Dance Company, producing our own performances, touring, and reimbursing the dancers. This has been the long-time dream of project director and choreographer, Stephanie Carter, and she is thrilled beyond words to start this adventure.

Open auditions were held in June, and the cast consists of a wide variety of dancers from all over Humboldt. We hope to bring you a stellar performance in October, which will help to raise funds for the upcoming performance season. This is 555's very first fundraiser performance, meaning we are starting at zero. Costumes, sets, props, rehearsal space, performance venue - everything needed to put on a show - can really add up, and all of it is coming out the project director's tiny little dance teacher's pocket. We truly want this performance to be something special and bring the audience and cast members delight, so we need your help! 

Anything that can be contributed will go a long way! There are many ways one can help make this performance a success; donations of funds, production assistance, costumes and set creations are the main things we need! 

 If you are able to only donate a buck or two, or just skip the latte today in order to donate, we are so very grateful! If you are able to lend your sewing or set design talents, or have some Halloween decorations laying around we could use, that would also be so very awesome! Just contact Stephanie at SCarPot85@gmail.com.

Thank you for considering being a part of what is sure to be a memorable performance!

story:
______________________________

Thank you so much funders! We are so grateful for all the support everyone showed during our campaign.

You should have been contacted by Sean regarding your perks, and the postcard notifications have been sent out.  All the shirts, coffee mugs, and bonus perks are now available for pick up at the theatre.

Thanks again for all your help! We are very excited about this project and all the Made Up Theatre adventures YOU made possible.

Photos and videos coming soon!

______________________________
The Breakdown

Made Up Theatre is a new, award winning improv and sketch comedy theatre that was established by five actors who wanted to share their love for the art with the Bay Area. Our theatre provides the community with fun and affordable entertainment, as well as offers education that inspires creativity and teaches the power of play.


Our venue, 3392 Seldon Court in Fremont is an intimate space that seats 49 people. We've opened the doors to the public, but there is still a lot to be done.  We've teamed up with Indie-GoGo and created some great incentives to help raise the funding necessary in order to give people an unforgettable experience.  With your help, we will be able to not only give friends, families, dates, and strangers a place to laugh and have fun, but we will also be able to bring laughter to thousands of people at local business, churches, and organizations with portable shows and team building events.


All money raised will go toward making the theatre functional and portable, covering operating expenses and equipment.  We are hoping to purchase: a 

sound system, wireless microphones, speakers, a mixer, cables, lighting equipment, video projection, and air-conditioning. 

We've created some great perks for your contributions, check them out, and thank you so much for your support!

Sincerely,

The cast and crew of Made Up Theatre: Bobby August, Ben Stephens, Dustin Seidler, and Sean Taylor


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your family and friends.  Use the share tools at the top of the page.  Every little bit helps and by helping us spread the word by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media sites, you are helping us achieve this goal.  Even printing it out and passing it on to someone you think could help would mean the world to us. 

"Like" us on Facebook to follow this campaign and get access to news, events, and special offers from Made Up Theatre. 

FINAL PERK!  Until the end, anyone who donates $25 or more (in addition to the perks you already get) your name will be included on our plaque to commemorate those who have helped us during this campaign!  Anyone who has donated $25 or more already will also be included!  The following ranking system will be proudly presented on our plaque!

$15-49 - Assistant Directors
$50-99 - Directors
$100-$499 - Producers
$500 & Above - Executive Producers

story:
Our Story

Earth Pearl Collective (EPC) is a social justice oriented assemblage of cutting edge queer, black womyn dedicated to increasing the visibility and success of queer black womyn, enhancing their general wellbeing and promoting their artistic talents through performances, events, and workshops around Chicago. 


The Impact

Keeping with the spirit of Earth Pearl Collective’s mission to showcase the struggles and triumphs of queer womyn of color, co-founder Crutcher aims “to bring out issues of domestic violence” that affect all communities. “The ‘streetcar’ becomes Chicago’s own Red Line and takes place in what could be any urban neighborhood in the city.” Inspired by the original play, the performers will convey the attractions to and consequences of emotions, deception, truth, and of course, desire.

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $3000 to pay for the theatre space and the set, to compensate the actors and the crew, marketing and filming, photography and costumes. 

Other Ways You Can Help

ALL DONATIONS ARE ACCEPTED!!! ANY AMOUNT WILL HELP!

If you can't help financially, please help us spread the word to as many people as you can! 

Tickets can be purchased here:

https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/32915/1335915000000/prm/
story_txt:
Our Story
Earth Pearl Collective (EPC) is a social justice oriented assemblage of cutting edge queer, black womyn dedicated to increasing the visibility and success of queer black womyn, enhancing their general wellbeing and promoting their artistic talents through performances, events, and workshops around Chicago. 
The Impact
Keeping with the spirit of Earth Pearl Collective’s mission to showcase the struggles and triumphs of queer womyn of color, co-founder Crutcher aims “to bring out issues of domestic violence” that affect all communities. “The ‘streetcar’ becomes Chicago’s own Red Line and takes place in what could be any urban neighborhood in the city.” Inspired by the original play, the performers will convey the attractions to and consequences of emotions, deception, truth, and of course, desire.
What We Need & What You Get
We are aiming to raise $3000 to pay for the theatre space and the set, to compensate the actors and the crew, marketing and filming, photography and costumes. 
Other Ways You Can Help
ALL DONATIONS ARE ACCEPTED!!! ANY AMOUNT WILL HELP!
If you can't help financially, please help us spread the word to as many people as you can! 
Tickets can be purchased here:
https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/32915/1335915000000/prm/

story:
Hi There!

My name is Sadie Pepperrell and I am a twenty year old actress living in London.

This year I have been blessed to recieve a place at The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama

The school sees thousands of applicants, for only on average 20 places available.

So what's this all about?

I have been wanting to go to drama school for a very long time. I auditioned for several school's back in 2011 where I received call backs but sadly no places. I knew after visiting Royal Central, it is where I wanted to go. I took nearly two years out and since then have studied a performed at The Oval House Theatre and The Questors Theatre.

To recieve funds from anyone, would be absolutely amazing and I would be eternally grateful that you have taken the time to not only read this, but believe in my ability to become a versatile and successful actress.

Check me out in The Wimbledon Guardian and The Surrey Comet!

Unsung Hero Of The Week At The Surrey Comet

Coveted Spot At Central - Wimbledon Guardian

What I'd like to raise

·  I am looking to raise £500

·  With this it allows me to to get up to Hampstead everyday, live, it helps me purchase all of my equipment that is needed.

·  If I don't reach my target, I will still be happy and so grateful for everyone's support!!! I will continue to work during my studies at The Golden Lion pub in Putney! I love working there and hope to see you all in there ;)

·  If you would not like to donate money but perhaps donate an item from my school list - please feel free to message me!

This list is

Yoga Mat, Locker Padlock, Skipping Rope, Cross Trainers, Knee Pads, Black Socks, Black Tracksuit, Black Footless Tights, Black Character Shoes (Size 8),White Blouse,  Black Full Length Rehearsal Skirt 

As well as 21 books that must be read by the end of the year. These can be purchased very cheaply second hand on amazon! ( please message me if you would like to buy a book for me, I love reading so this would pretty much feel like my birthday ha)

Can't donate?

Support and sharing this page can be just as much as a huge help as donating. If you can take the time to shout and share this around!

TO ANYONE KIND ENOUGH DO DONATE, I WILL ALWAYS KEEP YOU IN THE LOOP ABOUT MY JOURNEY, WITH PICTURES AND VIDEOS AND HELP YOU IN ANYWAY I CAN!!!

story:
FROZEN FEET THEATER has created a new genre in ice dancing that goes beyond the current Ice Capades-Follies-Cirque-Stars on Ice format, by telling dramatic stories; the myths and legends of the worlds’ cultures, integrating the fluid strength and agility of actor/ice dancers and the magical realism of puppetry within a narrative structure, this offers them the opportunity to present stories reflecting who we are, were and can be.  Their unique format has altered the approach of ice dancers, to include acting a role. It has added a new dimension and way to reach an audience by combining the skaters’ unique artistry within the context of a multifaceted story such as “Viva La Vida; The Life of Frida Kahlo” or “Persephone and the Birth of Winter”. The key for each story is finding the balance between the narrative, dance, music and puppetry, each of which provides the audience with a new way to appreciate old tales and insights, for a new age.

The inspiration for "RELATIONSHIPS" comes from this tiny rink, on the corner of a cobblestone street, right in the middle of what was the Meat Packing district of NYC.   The original score is a jumble of intriguing conversations which slowly reveal themselves… ranging from the mundane to ….“The sky is full of clouds.  There are no clouds in the sky.  The night is a thick dark veil that makes me hungry for more… is there more?”  Relationships involving homosexual, heterosexual, transgender and polyamory, are all part of this exploration.

As usual Frozen Feet Theater Choreographer, Beth Woronoff, will approach this unlikely corner of ice in an unusual and visually enticing manner, not to be further revealed now.  Please support this exploration of TIGHT QUARTERS and PERSONAL NYC STORIES!

The Choreography will include 6 professional skaters.  We will start preliminary work on it in February before indiegogo funding is here.  The performance dates are to be announced based on successful funding.  Money raised will go toward skater’s rehearsal and performance fees, costumes and transportation fees and video documentation costs.  Performances will be in NYC and in Saugerties NY.  The rehearsal schedule will involve approximately 24 hours of ice time which will be donated or greatly discounted.  If we do not receive full funding we will only do one performance, the costumes and choreography budget will be dropped, if we raise additional funds we will add performance dates and videography documentation will be supplemented.

FROZEN FEET THEATER combines the talents of Beth Woronoff and Mike Carson as choreographer and scenario writers and directors.  The ice dancers, now actor/ice dancers are all current professional ice skaters. Joining us in this new/old world of storytelling are Nick Lesserkind, Composer and Sound Designer, Theresa Linnihan and Sara Peattie of the Puppeteers Cooperative, who consistently find creative ways to design and build what Beth and Mike conceive with their own special artistry, providing us with the magical realism that helps creates for all of us, a  wonderful collaborative adventure.

BETH WORONOFF is a Co-Founder of Frozen Feet Theater and is the Founder and Director of the Saugerties, NY based Boundless Edge Ice Dancing Ensemble and School, now in its 10th year.  Recent choreography includes Volcano, depicting a trio of women warriors performing rituals, entering unknown territories and fending off dangers while keeping the circle between them safe.  Flight examines ageing and our vanity and fears related to it, utilizing a very long skirt, extending 5 feet past her feet. Billowing out like wings.  Persephone and the Birth of Winter, first told by two jesters, then skated by a cast of eight, five foot tall Lost Soul puppet faces and a masked Zeus on stilts embellish the ice stage filled with a winged Hades, the two faced character of “Winter/Summer”, Demeter and, young Persephone.  Beth has received three Strategic Opportunities Stipends through New York Foundation for the Arts and New York State Council on the Arts, has been featured on Diamond Dance Views, a Woodstock based hour long weekly TV program.  Beth was chosen to participate in the 2012 MARK NYFA Bootcamp.  Beth has a BA from New York University and an M.Arch. from Parsons School of Design, she received the 1996 Artist in Residence Choreography Grant from Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers and is the recipient of the 1997 Lawrence Epstein Choreography Award.  Beth is a former Ensemble Member of and Choreographic Contributor to the Ice Theatre of New York where Beth skated works by Ann Carlson, David Dorfman, Donlin Foreman and Lar Lubovitch.

MIKE CARSON, Co-Founder of Frozen Feet Theater,  started out as a stage manager, director in the theater world, he founded and is President of Michael Carson Productions focusing on producing Fortune 500 corporate meetings and events. During this time he also developed and produced three Off-Off Broadway plays and a musical with a cast of 25 at the NY International Fringe Festival. Over the last five years he has served as an Executive Director in the non-profit sector and also founded the Winter Lights Festival / Celebrating the Arts in Milford, PA. where he created and developed the concept of telling socially relevant stories on ice through the fluid strength and agility of ice dancers and the magical realism of giant puppets. Three years ago he met Beth Woronoff and together they have created PERSEPHONE & THE BIRTH OF WINTER and then, VIVA LA VIDA, based on the life of Frida Khalo. They are looking forward to further developing this unique form of story telling by creating a repertoire of stories based on myths and legends “to hold as ‘twere the mirror up to nature…” our 21st Century.

story:
We are a small, thus far self-funded, creative collective. We have successfully written and performed two theatre shows in the last year and a half and are determined to make a bigger dent in the industry. 
We were founded in 2013 when founding members Thom Jordan and Emily Tresidder decided on a whim that going to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival was something that they must do, and so they did. Successfully premiering a sketch comedy show in Scotland. 
Shortly after returning the pair begun writing a family theatre show, 'The Hand of Time', focused on an extraordinary young girl, who in a world shackled by ordinariness can freeze time. During the making of this show the Not Suitable for Drinking team expanded, and two new, extremely valuable individuals joined the team; resident director Julia Patey and producer Rebecca Blake.  Thom and Emily, along with the expanded team, premiered this show in 2014 at the Sydney Fringe and after some hilarious and necessary re-writes are taking this show and two others to Fringe World in Perth and the Adelaide Fringe. 
The two other shows are equally as close to the team's hearts. Thom and Julia have written and developed a one-man theatre show, 'We Are All' which follows the rise and journey of a young church pastor. 
Finally creative director Emily Tresidder, also stands up, comically, and she will be performing her debut, full length stand up show 'Absolutely Ridiculous' at the two fringes.

What Your Help Means

While we have successfully put on a number of shows, funding such endeavours is incredibly straining on such a small number of young, independent artists. With your help we will be able to:
  • Premiere three new Australian pieces of performance. 
  • Continue to grow and expand as a company. We have big dreams and we would be more than disappointed if finances stopped us from creating works that we love to share with the public. 
  • Continue creating works that can be further developed and more widely accessed. 

Dreams & Appropriate Challenges

As aforementioned we have huge dreams, for example getting ourselves, and bigger and better shows back to Edinburgh in 2015. We understand that this is not only economically challenging, but also requires tireless commitment and unwaiving time and effort. However; 
  • We have up unto this point responsibly organised both the companies finance and our time in order to successfully deliver shows. We will no doubt continue to do this. 
  • With your help we could also potentially have the financial freedom to source extra hands and resources to ensure the continuation of our creative collaborations. 

What else?

We understand that it is not always possible to give financially to such campaigns, however you can always help in other ways: 

  • Share our campaign with your friends if you see it's value
  • Like our pages on Facebook and Instagram, and check out our website and show your cyber support. 

Thanks!

story:
Intrusions

Event: World Parks Congress (WPC) November 12th - 19th 2014

Our venues & dates: Sydney Olympic Park Saturday 15th 9:30 -10am + Parramatta Riverside Theatres, Lennox Theatre, Monday 17th 7:30-8:30pm

Collaborating presenters: choreographer Dean Walsh & ecologist Dr Judy Fisher

Who is that masked man?

Dean Walsh, Sydney based choreographer, facilitator and dance/marine environment researcher and Australia Council Fellow 2011-2012, has 23 years professional experience. His proposal to World Parks Congress was accepted to present INTRUSIONS, a 30 minute dance and discussion segment reflecting on the theme of 'invasive species'.

Inspired by marine science and conservation for many years Dean began scuba diving in 2008. This activity immediately inspired a major shift in his former thematic interests. He moved from topics of a personal or human social nature towards also reflecting environmental themes, in particular, marine ecology and biodiversity. To carry out his investigations he scuba dives, free dives (without breathing apparatus), attends symposiums, talks and conferences and interviews marine scientists and professional environmentalists.

He spends many hours in studios at various institutions physically researching how this information might be embodied and choreographically composed. In 2011 he undertook a two year Australia Council Fellowship. In this period he formed a new movement 'filing' system (akin to a type of user manual or taxonomy), called PrimeOrderly. His choreographic process for new dance works are streamed through this system. 

What is World Parks (WPC) congress?:

WPC is one of the world's most important environmental events. It runs for an entire week and is commissioned by the IUCN (International Union for the Conservation of Nature). It brings together more than 166 countries - general public, environmental policy makers, scientists and conservation organisations, to engage in critical discussion within a multinational and multicultural context. It happens only once each decade in a different host city. It is estimated that nearly 5,000 people will attend the event in 2014 in Sydney. 

The presentations:

As a work-in-progress (towards a 60 minute feature length work in 2015) INTRUSIONS at WPC will take the form of a dance-based lecture demonstration in 4 sections - taking inspiration from the format of a David Attenborough nature documentary. Eight highly skilled young dancers will embody a series of complex movement modulations, inspired by Dean's research into marine environment and ecology, in 4 tightly structured improvisations each reflecting a specific take on invasive species or the act of being invasive (human social / psychological metaphors) and the potential impacts.

Between these sections, to give context and insight into his research of depicting these realms, Dean will 'narrate' the entire presentation a little like a TED talk. Ecologist, Judy Fisher will also say a few words. She will reveal her research and its context within the presentation, discussing the arts and their position in environmental conversations, in particular, how dance can add a visceral communication of scientific findings and conservation matters in engaging ways.

INTRUSIONS will have two presentations:  one in the Marine Pavilion at WPC, Sydney Olympic Park site and the 2nd will be held at Parramatta Riverside Theatres (dates above). The Parramatta presentation will include basic theatrical atmospheres, a brief 2 minute sharing of motion capture-based digital animations that will later be added to the work. A panel of arts / science and conservation professionals will then discuss the themes in relation to their work and interests in the arts and science interface. Finally, a Q&A will be held to engage the invited audience of WPC delegates, local arts and environmental professionals, as well as arts and environmental students.

$4,000 - in only 4 weeks!

As soon as we discovered we were successful in our application to WPC Dean Walsh embarked upon a fund raising campaign. He applied to various local and state councils as well as a few other institutions he thought may be able to assist. Whilst they found it a very interesting project, most have gotten back with news they cannot support us. This crowd funding campaign is now our only means of at least securing some funds for these incredible dancers who will have worked in excess of 80 hours each to make this presentation the best it can be.

Budget breakdown for what this campaign seeks assistance with:

  • 6 x 400 = 2,400 - graduating student performance fees
  • 2 x $1,200 - 2 paid professional dancers

$4,800 - total all performers fees Please help us reach our goal or even exceed it! The money will most definitely go towards overhead expenses. If you cannot donate perhaps you could help us by distributing our campaign through your networks? We'd greatly appreciate it.

Choreographic impact:

The potential for networking, audience development and possible future financial support through presenting at WPC is high. It will also help develop the work and ongoing support for it as well as Dean's overall research and growing dance/environment practice. There is potential for international touring of INTRUSIONS at off-shoot future conferences and symposiums.

http://worldparkscongress.org

Justified and ancient:

Dance has universal resonance as a language that has communicated human (and animal / environmental) stories for millennia. It is a culturally diverse and geographically specific form of expression that helps to reconnect us to play, pleasure and persuasion where perhaps words, or complex scientific facts on their own, cannot. Dance also reconnects us to a sense of belonging - to community and nature - as opposed to existing in isolation or separate from them. INTRUSIONS will convey, through intricate choreographic compositions, how species (including humans in this instance) invade or pillage ecosystems or perhaps, choreographically speaking, one another's physical or personal environments and the negative effects these can have. Discussions will reveal ways we might be able to arrest these negative impacts.

A note on donations and PayPal:

Contributions are paid into my PayPal account via credit or debit card or through your PayPal account if you have one. However, you do not need a PayPal account yourself to make donations. Just follow the prompts that lead you to paying with either a credit or debit card. PayPal is a reliable and fully secured payment method.

definitely go towards overhead expenses. If you cannot donate perhaps 
you could help us by distributing our campaign through your networks? 
We'd greatly appreciate it. 
Choreographic impact:
The potential for networking, audience 
development and possible future financial support through presenting at WPC is high. It will also help develop the work and ongoing support for it as well as Dean's overall research and growing dance/environment practice. There is 
potential for international touring of 
INTRUSIONS at off-shoot future conferences and symposiums.

http://worldparkscongress.org

Justified and ancient: 

Dance has universal resonance as a language that has communicated human (and animal / environmental) stories for millennia. It is a culturally diverse and geographically specific form of expression that helps to reconnect us to play, pleasure and persuasion where perhaps words, or complex scientific facts on their own, cannot. Dance also reconnects us to a sense of belonging - to community and nature - as opposed to existing in isolation or separate from them. INTRUSIONS will convey, through intricate choreographic compositions, how species (including humans in this instance) invade or pillage ecosystems or perhaps, choreographically speaking, one another's physical or personal environments and the negative effects these can have. Discussions will reveal ways we might be able to arrest these negative impacts.

A note on donations and PayPal:
Contributions are paid into my PayPal account via credit or debit card or through your PayPal account if you have one. However, you do not need a PayPal account yourself to make donations. Just follow the prompts that lead you to paying with either a credit or debit card. PayPal is a reliable and fully secured payment method.

story:
The Gist:

Ahoy! My name is Mia Moore, a burlesque performer in Lafayette, Louisiana. I pour myself into singing, dancing, acting, costuming, directing, empowerment and teaching workshops with Boom! Boom! Burlesque. Right now, my workshops can only go as far as my education...and I want MORE! Funding this project will send me to BurlyCon in Seattle, Washington. BurlyCon is the premiere burlesque education convention in the country, where I can not only enrich my cheeky performances, but also ignite a new line of workshops on skills I'll learn there, including silk fans, choreography, floorwork, costuming, chair dance, boa and MORE! Performing and teaching are my passion - help me combine those and bring it home to you!

My Goal:

In order to make it to Con, I'll need $1200:

$206 Early Registration

$450 Flight

$390 Hotel for three nights

$175 Supplies and shipping for perks!

(=$1221 Approximate fees included)

If I surpass my goal, the remainder goes towards workshop supplies for my students, including gloves, boas, fans, costume supplies and any other treats I can think of for attendees!

If I don't reach my goal, I get nothing, however I've already started paying for registration, so I'm headed to Seattle no matter what - your help would facilitate that goal and help me bring that education to YOU and audiences far and wide (okay, mostly to Acadiana)!

The Perks!

As a costume and jewelry designer for over a decade, I would LOVE to bring my creations and education to you. I've spent years performing, creating and teaching various creative workshops - this trip and the time following will be the ultimate extension of my passions.

Check out the list of perks on the right and decide which is best suited for you - be that a burlesque postcard, one or more of my creations - including pasties and glamorous fascinators - or the ultimate - a private class with ME and your best friends! Perks are transferrable and make great gifts, otherwise, should you live out of town/state or are not interested in a workshop, you can cash in on pasties and fascinators or any other mail-able perk.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Can't contribute?  I'd love your help anyway!

  • Share this page with your friends...use all those fun social media tools to get the word out!
  • Hire me or my troupe for your next gathering...we'll make it an event your guests won't forget!
  • Keep an eye out for upcoming workshops - especially after BurlyCon in October!
  • Follow me on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MiaMoore
  • Follow my troupe on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/lafayetteburlesque
  • Finally, you can come to a show!

Thank you for watching, reading and sharing - hopefully I'll see you in the workshop studio soon!

story:
Thank you for popping by!  

Please stay awhile.  Pull up a chair, toast a crumpet, make yourself comfy and let me tell you a story...

Sex, Lies & Earl Grey is the idea-baby of writer and performer, Deborah Berenson.  Earlier this year it was selected by the FringeNYC for the 2014 Summer season, where it will make its world debut…but it needs a little help getting there.

Deborah's previous solo show Baggage played to sold-out audiences in London and this will be her NYC debut, featuring a character very close to her heart.

Deborah / Georgina / Who?

Call me Debs. (Thank you, please.)  Sex, Lies & Earl Grey is my creative lovechild, and marks the culmination of 6+ years of hopes, dreams and theatrical fantasies.  I first created Georgina Grace (the star of our show) for a short monologue piece in 2008…and I fell in love.  She's sweet, obnoxious, complicated, mischievous and very much unhinged…and she thrives before an audience.  I wanted to develop an interactive show where audience members were more than passive onlookers and could be a part of Georgina's world: having tea with her and getting swept up by her whimsical reverie.  

Applying to the FringeNYC felt like a long-shot and there was definitely the sense of "why would they choose little old me with my one-woman show?" - but the adjudicators saw what I hope to bring to NYC audiences this summer: fun, foolishness, music and joy.

What makes this any kind of special, Debs?

A unique experience:  Think, walking into an etiquette class and leaving thirsty, disturbed…and a little aroused.  

Sex, Lies & Earl Grey is a character-piece cabaret.  A lot of people are scared of that word.  [Or expect to see boobs.]  I wanted to combine my primary discipline (singing) with my love of comedy and character work.  My goals in the genre of cabaret are to;

  • Create an immersive experience for an audience, whose involvement helps shape each individual performance
  • Bridge the gap between traditional showtune revues, exotic burlesque/variety, character/narrative-driven drama and stand-up comedy
  • Change perception of the genre and make it more of a go-to choice

Cabaret shows are a great and affordable night out, often showcasing phenomenal talent. Your generosity will ensure that this piece has the opportunity to make an impact: on audiences, on the genre-crossover within the industry and on the plummeting standards of manners and etiquette among Americans.


The Deets!

Where the $$$s are going and how we can share the love.

Our fundraising goal will cover the majority of expenses for the run of the show at this year's New York International Fringe Festival:  

  • Rehearsal Space
  • Props & Costume
  • Song Rights
  • Advertising & Marketing - design/printing/distribution
  • Insurance (mandatory)
  • Programs - design/printing
  • Staff - as much compensation for the creative team as can be accommodated after our costs.  A small team means fewer people doing more work, and I want to be able to pay these wonderful people!

Any additional funding will go towards the costs of filming/recording the performances and fulfilling the perks of Indiegogo donations.


You scratch my back…

Showering you with love! (not tea - that would be sticky)

When you donate, you can choose one of the unique perks set up as thank yous for your contribution.   These include CDs, DVDs (and downloads for the tech-savvy), eternal gratitude, special features, shout-outs & personalized song tributes, sexy stickers, a teatime hamper, Georgina's etiquette manual and more!

If we don't make our goal, we will still make use of any amount we have successfully raised and put it toward the cost of the run.  


    Risks & Challenges

    Creativity is all about risk, faith and facing your fears of failure.  To make this show a success at the FringeNYC we have assembled a wonderfully talented team of similarly minded individuals - dedicated to the art, not the profit.  We will not be wasting a penny of your generosity!  

    We endeavor to deliver all perks/rewards by their estimated dates, but in the event of a delay, we offer the following:

    • the freedom to harass Deborah daily on    Facebook    &Twitter    until she gets her shit together
    • a link to a video of Deborah's mum apologizing for the delay and explaining that she thought she raised her girl better than this*

    Plus we'll still get your stuff to you - and we'll include a bonus something nice.

    *mum, please call me so we can set this up.  I know you don't know how to use the camera on your laptop.


    No Pledge? No Problem!

    If times are tight and the idea of donating makes your wallet cry, please don't run away.  The best thing you can do?  Tell your friends about the project and our goal and LOVE US PUBLICLY by LIKING us on Facebook and FOLLOWING us on Twitter.  Tell your dog walker…tell your hairdresser!  Tell your super-wealthy benefactor-type-friends.  Spreading the word about our show and fundraising campaign goes a long way and we will be the most mega of grateful.

    You made it through ALL of the spiel.  Thank you.  You are my favorite!  What are you waiting for?  Please make some digital noise and get clickity clicking on those Indiegogo sharing tools!

story:
Help our Dancers Keep on Dancin’

Support Hoover Street Dance Company's Indiegogo Campaign to Dance to our Heart's Content! 

Whether or not you can help us now, please share our campaign with your friends, family, and anyone else who knows and loves our dancers or the joy of dancing!

Our dance company gives young dancers in southeastern Michigan opportunities to perform and choreograph original new works. 

Our dancers are challenged to try new things, learn new skills, and explore who they are creatively. They find inspiration from other dancers, and they learn the valuable life skill of working together toward creation of something beautiful. 

We've had an exciting two successful and exciting years, and we'd like your help and support to do even more next year. Please help support our dancers, whether they're your friends, family, or just someone you'd like to help nurture! 

We have launched an Indiegogo campaign to fund this project.  What’s really exciting is knowing that not only will you help make our dancers soar to new heights, but there are some great gifts as our way to say "thank you."

For more information, call (734) 302-3502.

The Hoover Street Dance Company is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. All contributions are fully tax-deductible as allowed by law. 

Who Is the Hoover Street Dance Company?

• Young dancers, aged 10-18, from Southeastern Michigan

• We perform an original ballet every year in February

• We have workshops about all things related to creating and performing dance

• We have fun

How Will Your Support Help?

We will be able to:

• Perform more often and in more places

• Expand our costumes, music, lighting, and sets to enhance our dancers’ performances

• Expand the educational and creative workshops we give our dancers

..and you’ll know you’re supporting young dancers' dreams!

story:
(Despite the above message -- placed there by the website vendor -- all donations made through this site will go directly to Judson Memorial Church. Judson's 501(c)3 standing with the IRS is "American Baptist Churches," so the site vendor keeps generating this message. It's confusing and we're working on changing it. In the meantime, rest assured: Contributions made through this site are processed directly by Judson Memorial Church to be utilized by its Building Fund.

Also, "perks" are the price points at which your contribution will enable various pieces of work to occur. Filling out the address line will trigger a hand-written thank you note, not a piece of terra cotta. Sorry for the confusion!)


Judson Church was completed in 1893 at a cost of $240,578, but keeping it standing has cost significantly more than that. Designed by architects McKim, Mead, & White, the building was packed with delicious (and expensive) details such as LaFarge stained glass windows and a marble baptistry by American Renaissance sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens. It is, quite frankly, gorgeous. In 1921, Bob's great grandmother founded the Judson Health Center in its basement. In 1966 the building received landmark status, which protected it from demolition but also from half-baked (or under-funded) repair and restoration work. Work conducted on the exterior of the church requires the guidance of professional conservators and specialty firms, a pricey combination. It's not unusual for work to be postoned repeatedly due to insufficient funds... until the situation becomes critical. 

For the past year, Megan has been at work with the Buildings Committee to plan a million dollar restoration of the building’s exterior. Last repaired in 1996, the sills around the La Farge stained glass windows are on the point of rotting and badly need attention.  In addition, the church is due for repointing, a process by which workers repair cracks, loose bricks, and precarious cornices to keep the façade from crumbling onto pedestrians below (eek!). Work is scheduled to begin in April 2014. 

Contributions made through this site are processed directly through Judson Church, a 501(c)3, and are tax deductible.

story:
"Blood Moon is based on a true story. Cleanly and clearly plotted right up to it's haunting conclusion."


First off, THANK YOU for stopping by!  As you may already know, I’ve started putting together the pieces of producing Nicholas Kazan’s terrific play BLOOD MOON. I first learned about the play in my acting class.  My teacher would assign it on occasion and the first time I read it, I was HOOKED. The play will have its run here in New York City at the Workshop Theatre Company on their Main Stage in March 2015.  Wow, 2015!  Weird to say.  But, I digress.

                                   

To get to the point, in order to make this happen I need your help. Putting up a play takes a lot of time, planning and, unfortunately, money.  But the good news is you can be part of making this play come to life by donating TODAY!  The even better news is that Fractured Atlas is fiscally sponsoring the production.  For those of you who don't know, Fractured Atlas is a non-profit organization that does it’s best to minimize any obstacles that prevent artists from sharing their art.  What does this mean for you?  Well, any money you donate is TAX DEDUCTIBLE.  Woo Hoo!

                                           

Giving today will allow me to hire the people I need NOW before they are snatched up by some other evil group of actors.  Postcards can be printed.  The set designer can start building the set.  Rehearsal space can be rented.  You get the idea.  All you have to do is pick your perk, donate and keep the wheels moving (Cliche #1).

 

 I’ll never forget going to see The Wiz when I was about 10 years old.  It had a permanent and life changing effect on me.  In this day and age I really feel the world needs to have music and art and theater more then ever.  I’ve always been a believer that education feeds the mind, but the arts give us our humanity.  There are so many stories about people whose lives have been touched by seeing a great show.  I even know of people who have been healed by plays that deal with personal and relevant topics. At its best, theater can change lives.

It’s people like you who make this happen.  When you donate or buy a ticket you become part of a bigger community.  A better community.  It sounds cheesy, but you do make the world a better place (yes, I DID say that). 

I also want to let you in on one more thing.  This play deals with violence against women.  Coincidentally, it’s also a subject that is very much in the news these days. As soon as I found out I got the rights to this play, even before the news stories broke, I made a promise to myself.  I don’t feel right doing this kind of play without giving something back.  So, I’m going to be donating a portion of every ticket sold to an organization that supports women of violence.  Actually, by donating to the fundraising campaign you are giving TWICE.  Once to the arts.  Once to women who are in need of help.  All of this gets done because of you!  As I said, "pick your perk", donate and let’s get the ball rolling (third time's the charm ;~)

I want to thank you for taking the time to read this.  I know your time is precious and I appreciate you listening.  I hope that you are very well!

P.S.  A very good friend once told me that people don’t invest in things, they invest in people.  I hope that you believe enough in what I’m doing to DONATE to the cause.

More Ways You Can Help

Spreading the word will help SO much.  Please tell others about the campaign. Share with your friends and family. Share on Social Media.  Sharing is caring ;~)

I want to thank you for taking the time to read this.  I know your time is precious and I appreciate you listening.  I hope that you are very well!
P.S.  A very good friend once told me that people don’t invest in things, they invest in people.  I hope that you believe enough in what I’m doing to DONATE to the cause.
More Ways You Can Help
Spreading the word will help SO much.  Please tell others about the campaign. Share with your friends and family. Share on Social Media.  Sharing is caring ;~)

story:
Updates

On August 3rd, we did a showing of our new version of Moxie to enthusiastic audience response. This success has got us even more revved up and rarin' to get to Vancouver. HUGE thanks to everyone who joined us in Boulder for our pre-tour showing. We can't wait to share our show with a broader audience!


Our Story

Pickpocket Theatre is Alana Eve Burman and Teresa Sparks. We're a young theatre company dedicated to producing original work and proving to you that theatre doesn't have to be quiet and serious, it's also a place to get rowdy and revel in the hilarious variety of human experience.  


Building on Moxie's success at the Boulder Fringe, we've taken a leap of faith and are bringing the play to the Vancouver Fringe in preparation for a cross-Canada tour next summer. The costs of taking a show on tour far exceed the costs of producing it in our home town and we need your help.


Here's a brief blurb about the show:


Pickpocket Theatre presents: Moxie

Written by Alana Eve Burman & Teresa Sparks. Starring Alana Eve Burman


Don’t miss the show our mothers are calling “adorable” and our fathers tell us is “historically inaccurate.” Quick, hilarious and immaculately rehearsed, Moxie will answer all of your questions, provided those questions are “Does Edward R. Murrow approve of Howdy Doody’s divorce?” and “Should pinup girls know morse code?” Whew! Fame is a rough town.


"Burman has excellent comic chops." - The Denver Post


"Burman exudes demure charm. 'Moxie' is a smart piece that employs clever stagecraft." - Boulder Daily Camera


"Enchanting! Must See!" - Boulder Fringe audience member


The Impact

It is impossible to prove that the production of any artistic work will be of value to society, but we believe that humanity's proudest achievements are artistic and cultural achievements. Democracy, for example. No particular company or career depends on one showing of one play. We will make art of nothing, with nothing, for nothing, because making art is what humans do. We would love your help making it.


What We Need & What You Get

Here's the basic budget for this tour:


Lodging:  $1980

Festival Application Fees:  $900

Travel Expenses:  $700

Director fees:  $200

Printing (Postcards, posters, programs):  $200

Prop construction:  $100

Shipping of set & prop pieces:  $50

-------------------------------------------
$4,130.00 TOTAL


Regardless of funding, we will be taking this show to Vancouver, but our ability to do so without going into debt and struggling while we're there depends greatly on meeting these funding goals.


And don't forget, there are PERKS!

We appreciate your support of our endeavors. See the perks sidebar to see what tokens of appreciation we're offering up for donating to the Pickpockets!


Other Ways You Can Help

When the inventor of chess showed his invention to the king, the king liked the game so much he gave the inventor the right to name his prize. The man, who was very wise, asked the king this: for the first square on the board, he would receive one grain of rice, for the second, two, for the third, four, and so on, doubling his gift with every square. 


The king, who was a moron in the special way of royalty, agreed immediately, not realizing that by the time they reached the 64th square this amounted to more rice than had ever been harvested in the history of the world. This is called geometric progression. 


Let's use the wonder of mathematics to support the wonder of storytelling. We need your rice. Spread the word.


Here's how:
- Tell others about this campaign and encourage them to donate. Check out the "Share This Campaign" box above.
- Come see one of our shows in Vancouver in September. Click for more info.
