story:
Hello and welcome. For those of you who do not know me personally, my name is Jordan Friedman, a recent graduate of Ithaca College's Theatre Arts program with a Bachelor of Arts in Drama.

This is a campaign to help fund an independent production of the musical theatre song cycle "Homemade Fusion," with music by Michael Kooman, and book and lyrics by Christopher Dimond. Described by the creators as a "series of musical snapshots," this song cycle features songs about many different topics in this world, including but not limited to: love, loss of love, stalkers, foreplay, cliches and rules of musical theatre, and that one candy bar in the vending machine. Together, these create in my opinion a very funny, smart, moving and emotional collection of songs with music that spans a wide range from satirical to poignant, and lyrics that are very intelligently placed and used.

This show has had many successful performances across New York and all over the United States and world with college students, professional actors, and more. I would simply like to attempt to add a production to the list of many successful productions this show has had. In addition to being the sole producer of this show (as far as I know), I will also be directing this show, as a result I am taking the commitment seriously to create the best show I possibly can and to make it worthy of many past successful versions. To do this however, I will need your help to cover some of the expenses with this show, which includes but not be limited to renting the performance space and rehearsal spaces, affording the licensing and rights to the show, creating the programs and marketing of the show, and more. Any donation will be helpful towards this cause, all it takes is many people donating a small amount to help reach this goal. If you are unable to donate yourself, that is alright, you can spread the word to people who might be able to, and if you are in the New York City area, there will be plenty of ways to be involved with the production itself.

I would like to thank you for either contributing to this campaign directly or helping out in an indirect way. This production could not be possible without your support on all levels.

story:
HELLO EVERYONE!!

  First off, let me say how thrilled I am that you've come to here to see what this project is all about. Now, let me introduce myself:

  I'm Cat Mahari-Johnson: a choreographer/dancer and the floor is my baby, my first full length work! I'm a recipient of a 2013 RAC Support Artist Grant, and am currently a Charlotte St. Foundation 2014/15 performing artist-in-residence. I graduated with a BFA from the Conservatory of Music & Dance in Kansas City, Missouri, and a MA from the Royal Central School of Speech & Drama in London, England.

  When it's time to get down, no one can hold back, and we all share the dance floor. My mission with the floor is to bring together the amazing nightlife diversity in African, Latino, and European cultures in order to subtly engage the ways our stories influence and change us all. Every artist involved in the floor has a unique story and background, which allows them to bring an exceptional quality and vibrancy to the work as a whole.
Check out our tumblr page: (stay updated!
the floor tumblr

  Why did I create this Indiegogo campaign? the floor is my FIRST full-length work, and my first immersive theatre production, and I want to make it as best as it can be. Reaching this fundraising goal will provide me with the means to cover production costs and pay the dancers. In return, I will give you an inspiring evening of dance, music, food, and drama -- in addition to my love and gratitude!

 

Fundraising Goal: $4300

-Visual Designer $900
-Composer $1000
-Dancers ($300/dancer) $1800
-Set Fee $600
-Indigogo Fee (appx.) $172



*If we reach our goal, 4% will go to Indiegogo, for allowing us to use this platform. If we fail to reach our goal, that percentage will rise to 9%.

*Best case scenario: we hit $5000, or beyond! Surpassing this goal will provide additional funding for documentation and filming, in addition to marketing, which is currently coming out of my own pocket.

*What about box office profits? Partial box office profits will go towards the dancers, the goal is to bring their pay up to $500, and provide pay to others involved in the process.

*What if I don't make the goal? Hopefully I am able to at least clear the $2000 mark, to cover production costs. If this is the case, I will split 100% of the box office profits amongst the dancers. If I fail to raise $2000, production costs will be covered by personal means, with profits going to the dancers.

___________________________________________

The Timeline

  This work has been in workshop for the past year, but rehearsals have picked up drastically since October. The performance date and time is November 21st, 2014, 7-10pm. Doors open at 6:30pm!

The Performance

  For over a year I have been thinking more and more about repetition, tradition and stories.

  The conclusion I have come to is that so many stories are told, laughs, kisses, and moments are shared when people meet up and go out with those that are like them. For so many people and cultures a particular party place, bar, club or event - is also a safe space to express themselves. This is obvious - but the matter that decisions and perceptions are being formed there that impacts others that do not occupy that same space, has been on my mind.     

  My goal is to create a setting and a work - where audience inclusion and participation is an important key - that explores shared and differing cultural connections in relationships of love, community, and individual stories. All leading to the most important idea: transformation.

The Impact
 
  This performance will give me, the dancers, and designers the rare opportunity to showcase a different side of our artistry. The majority of work we have done, as individuals, has been focused in our separate genres of art. Which is awesome! We love it and are thankful for everything these opportunities have provided us! However, I believe that it is important to collaborate in work that addresses social questions and concepts, and allows for a creative process that pushes us outside comfort zones. My goal is for you to come away from this experience with a deeper understanding and sincere appreciation for all of us as human beings, and encourage you to push your own boundaries in life.  
 
  Through exploring "repetition and transformation”, what I am really seeking to answer is: What will the consequences of our actions and perceptions be? What do we aim to leave behind? How can we positively affect the world in which we live? By helping us achieve our goal of creating this work, you are helping us answer these questions, and (we hope!) you to answer them for yourself.   
 
  Every individual involved is this project is generous with their time, talent, and knowledge. We teach, support, and volunteer in community, school, and studio based programs. We educate, encourage, love, and connect with a multitude of communities and ages to bring awareness to our art and all it entails: self-discipline, health, spatial awareness, musicality, emotional intelligence, creativity, problem solving, teamwork, self-confidence, goal setting...the list is endless. Through supporting this project, you are helping everyone of us grow and build our knowledge, which we can then pass on to those with whom we work.

  Thank you - truly - from the bottom of my heart, if you actually read all the way down to this last paragraph, its unbelievably awesome that you took the time to do so.

  I know how it feels to have someone ask for the money you work so hard for, so if you have already reached your donation budget, I completely understand. Please know that even passing this campaign on to anyone you know, who may be interested, could potentially make a difference and get us one step closer to our goal.

Also, I hope you can come and share the floor with us!

  With love and respect,
 Cat Mahari-Johnson and the floor artists

story:
www.secondarycharacters.org

Introductions

Hi, I'm Shelley Wojcik and I am the co-Founder/Artistic Director along with Nicola Davies for the not-for -profit musical theatre company, Secondary Characters.  I work as a choreographer, teaching dance to children ages 8-18, at the Chilliwack School of Performing Arts and Nicola teaches and directs voice and music across the Fraser Valley .  We started this organization together 4 years ago because of our love for theatre and we have 3 successful productions already under our belt:  Little Women, You're a Good Man Charlie Brown, and The Sound of Music which was a nominee for best show/concert for the Progress A-List. This company is based mostly on volunteers, is for artists of all ages, and explores all efforts to present imaginative, passionate and inspiring productions in our community.

This summer we are putting on the musical "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat."  In order to do this show justice we want to make it as spectacular and exciting as possible. We are looking for donations for all aspects of the production, including set, costumes and rental fees.  We are  grateful for any support you have to offer as the show would not be possible without creative and passionate volunteers and generous sponsors. 

Thank you.

 

Fundraising

We are looking at raising $1500. 

$500 for costumes (for a cast of 14 men, 9 women and 10 kids)

$500 for set and materials (including fog machine and disco ball rental!)

$500 will go towards venue rental.

If we do not meet our fundraising goal "the show must go on" and we will find a way to make the experience wonderful for all involved!

 

Make a Difference

If you've ever been involved in theatre you know how addicting it can be.  Chilliwack has a huge theatre following and I'm proud to be a part of that community.  With Secondary Characters, I and many other artists with a passion for creating and performing, finally have an outlet to do so.  Your contribution will be greatly appreciated.

 

Show Information

Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat 

July 24th-August 4th, 2013

July 31st- special sing along performance

Showing at the University of the Fraser Valley Theatre

Chilliwack, British Columbia

Tickets through the Chilliwack Cultural Centre

http://www.chilliwackculturalcentre.ca/event/jo...

 

Support the Arts and go see a show!

story:
BBS Ensemble is currently getting ready for our upcoming production of smash Broadway hit, The Who's Tommy!!  Tommy will run for five perormances from May 8-12 at our home base space at Congregation Beth Sholom, 354 Maitland Ave, Teaneck, NJ.  Our immediate goal is to raise funds for TOMMY, as well as start up costs for our next productions.

 

The BBS Ensemble’s first Teaneck production was a full-scale rendition of Into The WoodsinFebruary 2012.  This was followed by an intimate production of William Inge’s play Summer Brave; a Jesse Freedman-directed workshop of Matt Okin’s original play Walter Liked to Sit in His Big Backyard; and a recent reading of Inge’s final work, Natural Affection.  With the BBS Ensemble, Black Box Studios continues its long-term endeavor to bring a new kind of cutting-edge regional theater to Bergen County. This collaborative group of hand-picked local actors along with NY-based rising professionals is already planning for a large scale musical production in the fall, as well as developing original works for the stage in the winter and next spring of 2014..

story:
"Someone, I tell you, in another time will remember us"

- Sappho, 600 BC


Dear friends, 

We are Jessica Ruano and Victoria Grove, and thank you for visiting our IndieGogo page!

We're raising funds to bring our beloved production of 'Sappho ...in 9 fragments' by Jane Montgomery Griffiths to the Edinburgh Festival Festival for the first time this year. This play tells the story of Ancient Greece's first love poet, juxtaposed with a modern-day romantic affair. 

Following our sold-out extended run at the White Rabbit Theatre in London, we're transferring the show to The Rose Theatre, Bankside in May, before taking off on our Canadian tour in June, and then participating in the Edinburgh Fringe in August.

Take a look at our video to see Victoria Grove perform aerial choreography in her roped playground!

 

First things first, is the play any good? 

“The best theatrical experience I’ve had since New York 2011 and The Book of Mormon” Maureen Lipman

"Uncommonly exhilarating" Exeunt Magazine ★★★★

"A spectacular physical and visual piece" Remote Goat ★★★★

"Stunningly athletic and entirely sensuous" The Lady ★★★★

"Written, directed, and executed with passion" Female Arts ★★★★ 

More reviews here: http://sappho9fragments.wordpress.com/reviews/


So, what's this money paying for? 

Touring theatre is expensive! But so so worth it.

To cover Edinburgh venue costs alone, we're looking at paying £640.00. 

We're hoping to surpass our goal so that we can afford to pay for marketing materials (£500.00), living expenses (£500.00), and other productions costs (£360.00) while in Edinburgh.

TOTAL £2000.00 to take this show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival!

If you don't have the funds to support us financially, you can still help! Please spread the words to your friends and colleagues, and tell them all about the show. You can post a link to this page on Facebook, on Twitter, or in your e-mail newsletter. 

 

And why is this play so important to us?

We are passionate about presenting the works of female writers and telling women's stories, especially with regards to meaningful relationships between women. 

Sappho is a strong, powerful, intelligent, witty, and vibrant character. Roles like this for women are far too rare in theatre and film, and we think this one is worth celebrating.

Also, the historical Sappho - while prolific and tremendously influential as a poet and a lesbian icon - is relatively unknown, and very little is known about her. We would love the opportunity to share her moving and poignant life's work with as many people as possible.

Your generosity and support with contribute to the following:

  • Highlighting theatre work by a female playwright, female director, female designer, and female actor
  • Presenting a meaningful and complex love story between two women to international audiences
  • Encouraging UK/Canadian touring theatre and nurturing relationships between international artists

 

And in return, you may received some pretty fantastic perks! Highlights include a yoga class taught by Victoria, a personalised short story written by Jessica, or an evening out for cocktails with both of us!

 

Thank you thank you thank you in advance for any and all donations. Your support means the world to us. 

 

Much love x

Jessica Ruano - Director / Producer
Victoria Grove - Sappho / Atthis
story_txt:
"Someone, I tell you, in another time will remember us"
- Sappho, 600 BC
Dear friends, 
We are Jessica Ruano and Victoria Grove, and thank you for visiting our IndieGogo page!
We're raising funds to bring our beloved production of 'Sappho ...in 9 fragments' by Jane Montgomery Griffiths to the Edinburgh Festival Festival for the first time this year. This play tells the story of Ancient Greece's first love poet, juxtaposed with a modern-day romantic affair. 
Following our sold-out extended run at the White Rabbit Theatre in London, we're transferring the show to The Rose Theatre, Bankside in May, before taking off on our Canadian tour in June, and then participating in the Edinburgh Fringe in August.
Take a look at our video to see Victoria Grove perform aerial choreography in her roped playground!
 
First things first, is the play any good? 
“The best theatrical experience I’ve had since New York 2011 and The Book of Mormon” Maureen Lipman
"Uncommonly exhilarating" Exeunt Magazine ★★★★
"A spectacular physical and visual piece" Remote Goat ★★★★
"Stunningly athletic and entirely sensuous" The Lady ★★★★
"Written, directed, and executed with passion" Female Arts ★★★★ 
More reviews here: http://sappho9fragments.wordpress.com/reviews/
So, what's this money paying for? 
Touring theatre is expensive! But so so worth it.
To cover Edinburgh venue costs alone, we're looking at paying £640.00. 
We're hoping to surpass our goal so that we can afford to pay for marketing materials (£500.00), living expenses (£500.00), and other productions costs (£360.00) while in Edinburgh.
TOTAL £2000.00 to take this show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival!

story:
The Boundary

A world premiere by Houston playwrights Doug Williams and Donna McKenzie that explores the nature of our loves, the passions of our lives, and the turbulence of our times.

The story

The lives of a successful romance novelist and her sturdy husband are radically altered overnight by the sudden appearance of her former lover. But he’s now a dangerous fugitive wanted by the FBI for crimes against corporate America, and he needs her help for what may be his boldest, most desperate – and likely final – act. It forces her to face all of her choices and to examine the shifting lines between love and marriage, trust and betrayal, and life and death.

Run dates and venue

Friday and Saturday, March 25 and 26 @ 8 p.m.; Sunday, March 27 @ 3 p.m.; Thursday, March 31 @ 7:30 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, April 1-2 @ 8 p.m. Midtown Arts & Theater Center (MATCH), 3400 Main St., Houston.

A quarter-century path to production

The Boundary was born more than 25 years ago in a playwrights group, when Doug Williams began writing the story of a crisis management expert who could not handle a crisis in his own life. Overtly political (the title then was A More Or Less Perfect Union), it was put on the back burner when Williams began stage acting, his early plays were produced in New York, and he started drifting toward screenwriting.

Then in October 2013, he revived the project, finishing a working draft a year later. This version was still political and had the same basic structure, but had shifted to larger themes about how, why, and who people love. It was not a natural subject for him. A onetime activist who worked with African-Americans in George Wallace’s Alabama, he was more of a thinker than a feeler.

Enter Donna McKenzie, a fixture in Houston radio for three decades who has both acted and directed for the stage. She attended a May 2015 table read of the play, and began asking Williams questions about the characters and their motivations, choices, fears, and dreams. It became very clear, very fast, that she could enrich and deepen the play’s emotions without sacrificing some of the more political themes Williams wanted to explore. They became collaborators.

Over the next five months, they rewrote the script twice. McKenzie reshaped the characters in large and small ways, plugged holes in the narrative, and made sure that the story had as much (or more) heart than head. Williams took a lot of notes and bemoaned the fact that what just erupted from her brain would take him three weeks to come up with. Although they would spar on occasion, he says McKenzie won about 90 percent of the debates, and for one simple reason: She brings logic to a knife fight.

They finished a production draft in October 2015. At the end of the year, the recently established Dirt Dogs Theatre Company agreed to produce the pay, with Malinda L. Beckham signing on as director. Dirt Dogs had particular appeal to McKenzie and Williams, not only because Beckham had directed politically themed love stories in the past, but also because the company was devoted to – and respectful of – playwrights.

In early 2016, the play was scheduled for a two-week run at Houston’s new MATCH complex, one of city’s leading arts venues.

A budget with a difference – and a commitment to actors

The director, design team, and writers of The Boundary have agreed to take no money for their work. After the hard costs for the play are covered – venue, insurance, set construction, etc. – the remaining profits will go to the 12 actors and crew.

We hope to raise a minimum of $8,100, with the fixed costs as follows:

·  Venue: $4,100

·  Insurance: $200

·  Set construction: $1,000

·  Costumes: $500

Obviously, ticket sales will defray some of these costs. But for the most part, the project will be supported by people like you, who believe that actors should have opportunities for their work to be seen – and to be paid for their time and talent.

We greatly appreciate your time and consideration, and hope to see you at MATCH for the show.

story:
THE ASSESSMENT is a new play by Oren Stevens directed by Nora Ives which will be premiering at the New York International Fringe Festival this August!  We've got our schedule, a great team, and a great script, now here's where you come in:

In order to bring you the best show possible we need to raise money. Everything we raise from this campaign will go right into the production. We need to buy sets and costumes and pay our amazing creative team for their time and effort. Ten dollars will buy us a pivotal prop. Just twenty five bucks will get our amazing actor one step closer from performing in his underwear by buying an essential costume piece. For fifty dollars you can help us make a complete new world of sound.

Take a look at our rewards and help us bring this amazing show to the stage. We can't do it without you!

Starring Alex Grubbs

Produced by Graydon Gund
Stage Managed by Bryn Herdrich
Lighting Design by Daisy Long
Sound Design by Leo Martin

There are 26,000 home fires every week. There are 2,000 miscarriages every day. Someone is diagnosed with cancer every nineteen seconds. But I do it out of love. Are you ready for your assessment?

SIX SHOWS ONLY
Saturday 8/10 @ 3:45pm
Sunday 8/11 @ 7pm
Monday 8/12 @ 5pm
Thursday 8/15 @ 7pm
Monday 8/19 @ 7pm
Sunday 8/25 @ 2pm

Performing in
The White Box
440 Lafayette Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY 10003

6 to Astor Place

story:
Hello beautiful people

As an advocate for freedom of expression in the canadian dance scene i feel the need to get out of the country and further explore Dance as a whole.

Being a leader of the expirimental dance scene in toronto has given me the urge to see how other communites outside of canada flourish.

After years of creating safe spaces and platforms for expression in the city i feel the need to do that for myself.

I am reaching out to you in hopes of getting to Eindhoven Netherlands for the OPEN YOUR MIND dance festival
https://www.facebook.com/events/1495356787222326/

Ive been 1 of 25 selected in the world to Perform in Solo competiton called "STAGE DAY" soloists from all over the world compete for the number one spot recieving $ 1000 euros.

Day 2 is the Open Your Mind Dance battle where experimental movers compete in 1 vs 1 tournament style

Day 3 Workshops

Hoping to gain as much knowledge and experience to bring back to the dance scene in Toronto/Canada

Funds will cover

Flight to Eindhoven
Flight Back home
Air b&b room to stay

story:
Who We Are

Full Fathom is founded by a diverse group of passionate creators who are dedicated to redefining art and it's possibilities. 

The Funds

The money raised will go to making our productions the best they can possibly be!  

The $1,000 we're asking for will be distributed to:

  1. Production Expenses - $700
    • Rights, sets, props, costumes, makeup, lighting, sound, film equipment, transportation
  2. Advertising - $100
    • Posters, playbills, locations
  3. Company Equipment - $200
    • Projectors, film equipment, stage equipment

Our donors have access to many wonderful perks including

  •  Headshots by our Visual Director, Max Riley
  • Reserved seats to both 'Seascape' and 'Dorian Gray'
  • A copy of 'Dorian Gray'
  • A packet of Oscar Wilde's stories, poems, and letters
  • A personalized caricature drawn by Phebe Wickham, the Technical Director 
  • Full Fathom stickers and pins

Thank you for your donation!

Your Impact

Every donation counts. Art can be created on every scale, on any budget. All funds gathered will allow us to create more elaborate and wonderful productions and we sincerely appreciate any donation. 

Can't donate? That's okay. Follow us on social media and come to our shows! If you'd like to share our campaign we would greatly appreciate it!

story:
-The Gravity BeTween & our Goal-

The GraviTy beTween is a multidisciplinary quartet (2 dancers, 2 musicians) choreographed by Jacqueline Bulnes, former Soloist of the Martha Graham Dance Company and Soloist of the Limón Dance Company, with original live music by the Danish composer, Niklas Emborg Gjersøe. The piece is about human connection across borders and we seek opportunities to refine our work through performances, workshops and artist talks.  Our objective is to bring the quality of training offered in New York City Institutions to students across Denmark. 

In November 2018, we toured Denmark for two weeks reaching approximately 500-700 (students & audiences).  This June 2019, our estimations lead us to believe we will reach approximately 1000-1500 (students & audiences).

We believe in this project and we are primarily self produced though we can use your help in funding our housing while in Denmark!   We understand if you are unable to help financially, but please do help us spread the word!

-Breakdown of Costs-

Airbnb costs

  • $850 (2 dancers X four weeks in Esbjerg)
  • $350 (2 dancers X seven days in Odense, Aarhus & Copenhagen)

-Workshops, Performances & Artist talks-

Workshops & Artists Talks at-  

Royal Danish Ballet Theatre (Odense), Danish National Academy of Music (Esbjerg), Skolerne I Oure (Oure), Dansestudiet (Aarhus), Sceneindgangen (Copenhagen), Jazz et Motion (Hvidovre), Kulturskolen (Esbjerg).

Performances at-

Odeon Theatre (Odense), Kulturskolen (Esbjerg) Hvidovre Festival (Hvidovre).

-What inspired this project-

This project is inspired by a chance encounter of all four artists in NYC last Spring 2018. The two musicians were visiting the U.S. from Esbjerg, Denmark with The Danish National Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts in Southern Denmark and destiny sat them right beside the two Limon dancers at a jazz concert in NYC. Their collective interest in multidisciplinary exchange was the gravitational pull that sparked this artistic partnership.

Following their meeting, Jacqueline became a resident artist at Chez Bushwick in NY and invited the two danish musicians to join her and another dancer to begin building the work, which at the time was sponsored by the Jonah Bokaer Arts Foundation. Following this residency, Jacqueline was then invited by The Royal Danish Theatre Ballet School in Odense (DK) as Master teacher, as well as by the Danish National Academy of Music in Esbjerg (DK) as resident artist in Fall 2018 where she explored the creative possibilities between two diverse cultures, building new pathways for networking between Denmark & the U.S. The residency at the Academy of Music culminated towards a 2 week tour in Denmark offering free performances, Master workshops & Artist Talks.

story:
About Me...

I am a Teacher of the Arts, a Mentor and a Dream Maker. My name is Rochelle aka the "Rock" and I am here to build a foundation on which young Artists can stand. 

In 1997, I moved to New York City with $25 dollars in my pocket and a one-way bus ticket. I survived as a starving artist & then a professional dancer for 11 years; having produced my own show. I received the training and tools necessary to make RCDC a reality. I knew it was time to come share the knowledge, passion & love of the Arts with my Community. 

By joining in on this campaign you will be helping our kids to potentially CHANGE their focus, BELIEVE they can DO ANYTHING and SAVE their lives by BREAKING DOWN emotional BARRIERS, CREATING AWARENESS of self and OPENING THE DOOR TO SELF-EXPRESSION. 

Right now, we are looking to bring $7,500 to the table. This will open the doors to RebelChique Dance Co. get the equipment such as Dance Mirrors, Ballet Barres, a "Spring Floor" to prevent injury. We also have a Sponsorship Program that will allow one child who cannot afford classes become sponsored by a Corporation, Group or Individual to learn their Art for a Year.  

This is what I mean by SAVING LIVES. 

NO MATTER WHAT...Even if we don't reach our goal, I am STILL GOING after this VISION. The money raised will still go to the studio and continue to HOST EVENTS to continue to GROW the money via tickets sales and more. Our Community NEEDS this. 

Our kids are ACTING OUT for a REASON! They are BORED for a REASON. They are making BAD DECISIONS for a REASON. So let's RE-DIRECT THEIR FOCUS!!

Over the last 10 years, I have had the HONOR of teaching & Instructing over 500 kids & Adults. From New York to Lancaster and in between. 

There is NOTHING MORE I'd rather do than Encourage, Empower & Inspire YOUNG PEOPLE.

They keep me young and I LOVE what I do! There is PASSION in what I do. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and make some noise about our RebelChique Dance Co. campaign & don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

This crowdfunding campaign is part of The Great Social Enterprise Pitch, a friendly competition facilitated by ASSETS and the Lancaster County Community Foundation. The Pitch consists of social enterprise ideas based in Central Pennsylvania. A Social Enterprise is a market-based, income-generating enterprise that aims to solve a social and/or environmental problem through its business activities. Social enterprises focus on a triple bottom line:  people, planet, and profit. Upon completion of the Crowdfunding phase of the competition, 5 ideas will be chosen to move on to the Live Pitch, during which the contestants will present their ideas to a panel of judges, with winners receiving a package of cash and pro-bono prizes. In 2017, winners received over $50,000 in cash and pro-bono prizes. In addition, all participants have agreed to donate 5% of their total raised funds from their crowdfunding campaign to ASSETS.

Please visit www.lancasterpitch.com for more information.

To access to the crowdfunding sites of all participating social enterprise ideas, click here: https://www.indiegogo.com/partners/SocialEnterp....

In addition, all participants have agreed to donate 5% of their total raised funds from their crowdfunding campaign to ASSETS.Please visit www.lancasterpitch.com for more information.To access to the crowdfunding sites of all participating social enterprise ideas, click here: https://www.indiegogo.com/partners/SocialEnterp....

story:
The People's Assembly

The People’s Assembly is a national movement dedicated to opposing the harmful austerity imposed by the government. As the Manchester branch, we support and connect local campaigns against the cuts, hold engaging public meetings, and stage headline-grabbing protests to make our opposition heard. Whether it’s holding a skill-sharing session, or getting 80,000 people onto the streets of Manchester to protest the 2015 Tory party conference, we’re here to help everyone stand up to austerity.

We’re proud of the strong contribution the Manchester People’s Assembly makes to the voices calling for a fairer society, and in 2016 we need to keep building the movement.

What We Need

We’re looking to raise £1,000 over the next month to support the following aims

-  Help us shout louder! We hold many rallies with large audiences and excellent speakers; we want to purchase a good quality PA system so these important messages can be heard

-  Help us continue our key work. The backbone of our work - our regular meetings and actions - couldn’t take place without funds for leafleting and venues

-  Help us grow! This year we aim to hold an outstanding programme of anti-austerity events in Manchester. The funds raised will make this possible by allowing us to book large enough venues and pay speakers’ expenses if necessary

Ways You Can Help

Can you help us by donating to the People's Assembly? Please donate what you can.  We don't have millionaire backers but we do have many supporters who understand the importance of stopping these cuts.  If we all donate what we can afford we will soon reach our funding goal.

If you can't afford a financial contribution we would still love you to become involved in the People's Assembly:

https://www.facebook.com/ManchesterPeoplesAssem...

story:
Short Summary

Hello! 

 I am Avinoam Silverman, a former Soloist with the National Ballet of Canada and now a freelance choreographer and dance teacher.  I have always been very interested in choreography and creation as a whole. During my years with the National Ballet I created a number of pieces for choreographic workshops using dancers from the company. Each time further developing and exploring my choreographic voice. Since retiring from the National Ballet I have collaborated with Cadence Ballet, Ballet Jörgen and 60x60 Dance, creating new and original dance works. Now, as a freelance choreographer, I am looking to continue this journey by creating a new and exciting dance film. 

I am very passionate and excited about this new project. So far I have started choreographing a short dance piece with 4 wonderful, talented dancers who have been graciously volunteering their time. I have also been collaborating with an amazing videographer, who I am trusting to bring my vision to life. 

 The process for this dance film has been inspired by the fast pace go-go-go-go world where our attention gets pulled left, right and centre. From the latest phone model to the "best"clothing labels …  all these things are external and cosmetic. There is nothing wrong with enjoying material things, but if we define ourselves by what we have and own, including what we wear, we are creating a really limited view of who we truly are. I believe that we need to start looking inwardly for true meaning in life as the external things are impermanent, but our essence is eternal.

Using a thematic plot line, this dance film will tackle these ideas by featuring two characters. A women on a shopping spree, driving around a city and a male dancer heading to a rehearsal with 3 supporting female performers. The climax of this dance film showcases an accident where the male dancer gets hit by the woman driving her car. Emphasizing the fragility and preciousness of life, I am aiming to shed some light on the importance of finding true meaning and lasting values by looking inwardly instead of outwardly. 

None of this will be possible without your support. Please help us reach our goal of $4,000 by making a donation. By helping us bring this important piece to life you will be a part of taking it from monologue to dialogue. It is only with your help that we can produce our work and we appreciate your consideration and generosity!  


What We Need & What You Get

 Your generosity goes directly to artist fees for the collaborators: 

  • Dancers (CADA rates)
  • Actress
  • Videographer/Editor 
  • Choreographer (CADA rates)
  • Special effects make up artist
  • Rental spaces

The Impact

Your contribution will help bring this piece to life! Not only will you be endorsing us in creating the work, you are joining us in showing another view of looking at life. My goal is to bring more awareness to this topic and hopefully provide a fresh and meaningful perspective for people. My vision is to start a dialogue which will bring us closer to our truth.  There is so much more to us then what we wear and own. Help us express this through our engaging, exciting and meaningful dance film!

If you cannot support us monetarily, please help us share our campaign.

story:
What is Conk and Bone?

--a world premiere dark comedy--
Written by Joe Musso and Directed by Kappy Kilburn
October 19 - November 4, 2012
At the Carrie Hamilton Theatre at the Pasadena Playhouse
 
Conk and Bone are once again hired by Death to prepare a soul for the ferry ride across the River Styx. But tonight is different and all goes awry when two souls are delivered instead of one. Confined to an abandoned house on a moonless night in Louisiana, Conk and Bone must confront a tortured tattooed girl, a furious fallen hero, and Death himself--but not before they have to face each other.
 
Featuring Jennifer Daley, Doug Power, Bruce A. Lemon, Ryan Mulkay, and Paul Vroom;

Designed by Brandon Baruch, Karla Contreras, Cricket S. Myers, David T. Offner, Doug Oliphant, and Jenny Smith;

Want to know more about the show?

We've got you covered. Here is a link to a recent article written by the director:

http://www.lastagetimes.com/2012/10/kilburn-returns-to-the-hamilton-with-conk-and-bone/ 

Who are the Mutineers?

Mutineer Theatre Company (MTC) is comprised of actors, visual artists, composers, writers, dancers, photographers, sculptors, filmmakers, directors, and designers working collaboratively to conceive unique and inspired work. We are committed to creating intelligent, challenging, and thought-provoking theatre that observes, explores, and reflects upon the human condition.

Because of Mutineer Theatre Company's non-profit 501(c)3 status, contributions are tax-deductible! 

Will you help us?

We continue to operate as a fiscally responsible organization and our highly anticipated world premiere production of Conk and Bone is no exception. Taking place at the historic Carrie Hamilton Theatre at the Pasadena Playhouse and directed by Kappy Kilburn, we have assembled a stellar cast and extraordinary production team who have demonstrated their confidence in both the play and production by reducing their fees and deferring payment until the show closes on November 4th. This means we only have a month to get the word out about the production, the generous artists involved, and to pay our bills on time!

How else can you help?

Come and see Conk and Bone! The artists involved with Mutineer invest their time, energy, and resources in a lot of ways, but it all comes down to creating and sharing compelling, interesting, and thought-provoking stories that spark conversation. We invite you to share our story. Tell your family, tell your friends, tell strangers! We'll see you at the playhouse!

http://www.mutineertheatre.com/ @MutineerTheatre #ConkandBone

story:
The Play

Molly Bloom-Lately is the story of a young girl who is singled out on her first day of third grade for being the smallest in her class.  With the help of an interesting and entertaining cast of characters and some amusing mishaps along the way, we watch as Molly learns what it means to be uniquely her and witness a surprise ending that shows even the smallest among us have something to share. 

Written by Ashleigh Catsos with music by Brian Ray Stearns, this children's theater piece both entertains and educates, providing its audience with the reminder to celebrate the YOU that you are and to always be kind even when others are not.  In turn, the story highlights tools to effectively deal with a bully scenario by demonstrating positive ways to stand up for oneself.

The History

Ashleigh Catsos, playwright, and Lindsay Hayes, Awaken Productions Artistic Director, have been friends since the summer before their senior years of college, when they met as interns at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center National Playwrights Conference.  The last seven years have seen them through acting successes and rejections, break-ups and a marriage, and years of nannying to pay the bills.  With so much time and love shared with kids, a children's play seemed like the natural next step.  

With your help, we will be bringing the important messages of this production to audiences throughout the five boroughs, starting with Brooklyn this fall.  What better way to begin an important dialogue about these topics than through theater?

The Need

In order to fulfill our production goals, we need to raise $5,500.  These funds will allow us to pay our cast and crew, which is a standard that Awaken Productions maintains as so often actors do not get paid for their hard work and time.  With your help we will also be able to pay for the materials for our set, costumes, rehearsal space, and publicity materials...just to name a few!  

How YOU Can Help

It is easy to support Awaken through this campaign with various thank yous and perks along the way.  Any amount you can share is much appreciated! As a supporter of Molly Bloom-Lately, you can feel confident that you are helping to breathe life into a project with an important and heartfelt message.

Awaken Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, and therefore all contributions are tax-deductible.  

In the Fall of 2010 Awaken successfully staged a full production in NYC's Theatre District.  Through the generous contributions of our supporters and Awaken's strict budgeting and financial management, we were able to get the entire production paid for as well as pay the actors and crew members. You can feel confident that this time around will be the same story.  

Not Able to Donate?  There Are Other Ways to Help!

We are so thankful that you have taken the time to view our indiegogo campaign!  If you are not able to help us out with a monetary donation at this time we ask for your help in spreading the word about our play and about our fundraising campaign.  Please share this indiegogo link www.indiegogo.com/mollybloomlately and take advantage of the share tools that the site has available.  Sharing our website, www.awakenproductions.org and 'liking' our Facebook page are more great ways to get others interested in our project.  Helping us get the word out is just as important as any dollar bill!  We thank you all for your time, support, and love.  We are so excited about this show and the places it can go!

The Why

Molly Bloom-Lately is not only entertaining for children and adults alike, but it carries the significant message of finding self-esteem and confidence, the importance of friendship, and provides tools for dealing with bullying in a healthy and productive way.  It seems like every other news story lately is about a case of bullying and its horrific aftermath, which makes us feel even more passionate about sharing this play's powerful message. 

It is important to Awaken that any new project allows for the company to work toward and fulfill our mission. 

MISSION

As artists we strive to enable our audience to recognize the shared connection we all have as human beings. We desire to incite something more in them: to stir them to action, to look closer at themselves, to acknowledge the truth, or to simply love more fully...

to AWAKEN the full human potential in each of us.

 

That mission is exemplified in the story, characters, and lessons of Molly Bloom-Lately and we cannot wait to share it with you!

 

Cheers & Love,

Lindsay and Ashleigh

story:
"Antonietta e Gabriele"

“Bisogna seguire il vicino di casa per scoprire delle storie bellissime” sosteneva Cesare Zavattini. Ci sono storie che non si possono dimenticare, aggiungiamo noi. 

Da un intuizione di Simone Sibillano, già conosciuto dal pubblico teatrale prima per le sue iterpretazioni in musical di successo (Jesus Christ Superstar, Aladin, Robin Hood, Biancaneve,etc) e dopo per le regie e scritture di diversi testi teatrali(America-il musical; Il primo Papa; Le sorelle Frank; Violetta Il musical) nasce la storia di Antonietta e Gabriele, raccontata dalle labbra inaridite dal tempo ma ricche della passione del ricordo, di un vecchio, un tempo portiere di un antico palazzo della Roma del Fascio, merita riflessione e ricordo.  Era bella ricorda er Sor Fernando Antonietta “la più bella pischella der quartiere” tratteggiando l’archetipo della popolana vulcanica, della donna colma di umanità…”poi s’era accasata il marito, i figli, le bollette da pagare, ma l’occhi, quell’occhi,  anche coll’occhiaie della fatica, chi se li scorda più”. 
Un tempo, quello della quotidianità, nella Roma fascista che troppo nascondeva dietro le tendine ricamate delle finestre dei caseggiati popolari. Lenzuola stese al sole di una Roma a Maggio, profumo di sapone e glicine, pantofole sdrucite e calze rammagliate, nell’orgoglio fascista della Patria. Fuori da quell’ambiente domestico il Mondo segna il suo tempo, anticipando il dolore di una guerra che intride  lenzuola che garriscono come bandiere del sangue dei figli che, Antonietta ancora non lo sa, sacrificherà a  quell’Adolf Hitler che, con Mussolini in testa, Roma attende con venerazione.  “Me chiedeva i giornali la sora Antonietta - racconta il portiere – ritagliava tutti gli articoli sul Duce”.  
Dirimpettaio Gabriele, lo sapeva er Sor Fernando quello che si bisbigliava su di lui, ma non gli interessava: “Era un gran signore, educato, salutava, me dava la mancia a Natale e a Pasqua, parlava a bassa voce…dalla finestra sua sortiva quella musica americana che er Fascio proibiva, mortacci loro…me piaceva sta a sentì mentre pulivo er cortile del Palazzo… era musica de vita de gioventù vera altro che Giovinezza”…
Una maratona nel tempo e nello spazio: microstoria di due vite umane, rette in parallelo, destinate a non incontrarsi mai se non fosse quell’inopinata fuga del pappagallino di Antonietta, quarantenne madre di sei figli che, volato via dalla finestra,  finisce sul davanzale del dirimpettaio. La donna si reca così dal vicino: è Gabriele affascinante, modi bizzarri e sfrontati, un incontro destinato a rovesciare prospettive  e visioni dei loro mondi. Prologo di una tragedia, prologo di una educazione al bello che Gabriele, il giornalista omosessuale, regala a Antonietta, prima di restituirla , per breve tratto alla sua falsa normalità -la guerra urge  e tutto cambierà – prima di recarsi al confino. Viaggio senza ritorno.

Interpreti

​Due i protagonisti Brunella Platania e Simone Sibillano : una intesa profonda nella scena, una capacità di essere vivi e veri che non potrà non affascinare. Due performer di razza  noti al grande pubblico del Musical e non solo capaci di convogliare l’interesse sia dei  loro fans  sia di chi ama ascoltare – leit motive e parole storie archiviate troppo in fretta 

Simone Sibillano

Nel 1998 si diploma all’Istituto Statale d’Arte Sacra per l’Arredamento e la Decorazione della Chiesa.Dal 1996 al 1998 studia canto lirico con il baritono R. Piemontese e nel frattempo frequenta corsi di danza moderna, jazz e latina e un corso di recitazione con il regista G. Nardoni.

ESPERIENZE LAVORATIVE

2015-2016 Production singer presso Costa Crociere

2015 dirige e interpreta il musical “Il primo Papa” sulla vita di San Pietro, nel ruolo del protagonista

2015 interpreta Amore nel Musical “Amore e Psiche” per la regia di Giovanni Nardoni.

2015 Scrive il musical “Le sorelle Frank” liberamente ispirato al Diario di Anna Frank. E ne cura la regia

2014 Scrive e interpreta il musical “Cercasi Violetta” per la regia di Marco Simeoli

2013 Interpreta il ruolo di Tommaso nella commedia musicale "Raffaello e la leggenda della Fornarina" di Giancarlo Acquisti per la regia di Marcello Sindici

2013 Scrive e dirige il musical “America” interpretando il ruolo di Bartolomeo Cataldo

2012-2013 interpreta il ruolo del cacciatore nel musical “Biancaneve”

2010-2011-2012 é Jafar nel musical “Aladin” di Stefano D'orazio musiche dei Pooh per la regia di Fabrizio angelini.Svolge per lo show un' attivita di vocal coach.

2009-2010-2011 è Paolo il fariseo nella opera-musical "Wojtila generation" con concerti in Polonia e Spagna.

2010 interpreta il ruolo di Karol Wojtila nel musical “Non abbiate paura- Giovanni Paolo II il grande” per la regia di Gianluca ferrato.

2008-2009-2010 è impegnato nella tourneè del musical “Robin Hood” di B. Dati nel ruolo dello sceriffo di Notthingam Guyo Tristan per la regia di C. Ginepro.

2007 è nel musical “Il principe della gioventù” di R. Ortolani per la regia di P. L. Pizzi nel ruolo di Franceschino

2006-2007-2008 interpreta il ruolo di Jesus nel musical in versione italiana “Jesus Christ Superstar” di Webber – Rice per la regia di F. Angelini

2005-2006 è Raoul ne "Il fantasma dell’opera" per la regia di A. De la Roche.

2004 è nel musical "Boccadoro the traveller” per la regia di F.Angelini nel ruolo di Boccadoro.

2003 interpreta il ruolo dell’evangelista nel musical "Per sempre mio divino amore" e il uolo dell’angelo nel musical "Quando cantano le ali", entrambi per la regia di L. Cognatti.

2003 lavora come cantante solista-ballerino nella produzione Rai "Casaraiuno" per le coreografie di F. Miseria.

2002 è nel musical “Il ritratto di Dorian Gray” di T. Russo, nel ruolo di Adrian Singleton e come cover di Dorian Gray, James Vane e Alan Campbell.

2001 entra a far parte del musical “I Promessi Sposi” di T. Russo.

2000 viene scritturato da M. Ranieri per il musical “Il grande campione” di M. Fabrizio e G. Morra per la regia di G. P. Griffi.

1999 Debutta in teatro due anni dopo come cantante-attore al fianco di N. Castelnuovo nella tragedia musicale "Elena" di Euripide per la regia di G. Nardoni.

1997 lavora come cantante solista nella produzione Mediaset “Sarabanda”.

PREMI

2014 vince il premio Broadwayworld.com per la categoria miglior attore protagonista

per l'interpretazione di Batolomeo Cataldo nel musical “America”.

 

Brunella Platania

Cantante, attrice e doppiatrice.
Attualmente è Vi Moore nel musical "Footloose" della Stage Entertainment.
 Brunella Platania, interpreta,nell’ambito del musical, il ruolo di Sidonia e Tosca in “Tosca Amore Disperato” di L. Dalla e D. Zard, Maddalena in “Jesus Christ Superstar” della Compagnia della Rancia, diretta da F. Angelini, prima Perpetua poi Agnese ne “I Promessi Sposi” di M. Guardì, Fornarina in “Raffaello e la Leggenda della Fornarina” di G.Acquisti, diretta da M. Sindici, Ortensia in “Aggiungi un Posto a Tavola”, diretta da F. Angelini, Malfiore in “Wojtyla Generation - Love Rock Musical” di R. Avallone, Adriana in “Trasteverini, Sotto il cielo di Roma” di G. Vergoni e A. Perrozzi,diretta Angelini, Ambra in “E non finisce mica il cielo” di G. Vergoni, sempre per la regia di Angelini, la Signora Otis in “Canterville” di Robert Steiner , regia M. Simeoli, Lady Rose in “Robin Hood , il valore della giustizia” di S.Martino, regia di P. Gatti. In tetaro è stata protagonista di:  “Opinioni di un Clown in si bemolle”di Heinrich Boll , regia di S. De Luca e M.L. Platania; “ Tutti al macello!” di B. Vian, regia di A.Cervigni; ”La Torta di Joe” di E Tulli, regia di S. Mastrosimone e G. Matruonola. Porta in scena, con la compagnia “Le tempe d’un pause”, gli spettacoli  “Lovers, -Amanti”, “Una stranissima ragazza” e “Chocolat” e “Piccole Donne “con la regia di M.L. Platania. Nel Maggio 2015 la vediamo come regista associata, acting e vocal coach nel nuovo allestimento di “Jesus Christ Superstar” della “Compagnia della Croce del Sud”, dove ha l’opportunità di lavorare a fianco del performer di fama internazionale Steve Balsamo (“Jesus” nel West End); nella ripresa del 2016 interpreterà la Maddalena nelle Special Cast. Si cimenta ancora nella regia nel giugno 2015, insieme a M. Sindici e M.L. Platania, in “Sogno di una notte di mezza estate” versione musical al Teatro Sala Umberto di Roma, ripreso poi a Macerata al Lauro Rossi accanto a R. Rossetti. Nel Maggio 2016 in  "Georgie il musical" dove, oltre ad interpretare Mary Buttman, Brunella è vocal coach e casting director .Nel doppiaggio ha dato la voce “cantante” alla dottoressa Bailey nella puntata musical di “Grey’s Anatomy” e a diversi personaggi di cartoni animati della Fox e della Disney con cui collabora sotto la direzione del maestro Ernesto Brancucci. Deve la sua preparazione a grandi maestri quali Pino Manzari, Claretta Carotenuto, T. Zinzi e G. De Feo e in quello musicale e del canto a L. Vella, P.Bonfrati, Luca Velletri, M. Fontana, P. Neri e al grande Carl Anderson. È direttrice dell’Accademia Platafisica di Macerata e dell’accademia Professione Spettacolo di Roma, e del corso di canto e interpretazione del MIP di Chiara Noschese.

Perché il crowdfounding

Intanto per ansia di libertà, voglia di realizzare progetti originali e utili, senza legarsi a nessuno se non alla propria professionalità  e alla capacità di raccogliere il pubblico giusto, quello che ama sentirsi raccontare la storia del proprio mondo e delle proprie radici, la fatica di affermare la diversità: di Antonietta che confida dolente a Gabriele “Con un ignorante puoi fare qualunque cosa perché non c’è rispetto”, di Gabriele che ricorda l’umiliazione "Ti abbiamo ritirato la tessera del partito, perché quelli come te, non possono far parte del nostro partito, che è un partito di uomini.", del Sor Fernando il narratore che tra le mani tiene il libro “I tre Moschettieri” quello che “Er Sor Gabriele aveva regalato alla Sora Antonietta”…perché dove è ora Antonietta?
story_txt: "Antonietta e Gabriele"“Bisogna seguire il vicino di casa per scoprire delle storie bellissime” sosteneva Cesare Zavattini. Ci sono storie che non si possono dimenticare, aggiungiamo noi. Da un intuizione di Simone Sibillano, già conosciuto dal pubblico teatrale prima per le sue iterpretazioni in musical di successo (Jesus Christ Superstar, Aladin, Robin Hood, Biancaneve,etc) e dopo per le regie e scritture di diversi testi teatrali(America-il musical; Il primo Papa; Le sorelle Frank; Violetta Il musical) nasce la storia di Antonietta e Gabriele, raccontata dalle labbra inaridite dal tempo ma ricche della passione del ricordo, di un vecchio, un tempo portiere di un antico palazzo della Roma del Fascio, merita riflessione e ricordo.  Era bella ricorda er Sor Fernando Antonietta “la più bella pischella der quartiere” tratteggiando l’archetipo della popolana vulcanica, della donna colma di umanità…”poi s’era accasata il marito, i figli, le bollette da pagare, ma l’occhi, quell’occhi,  anche coll’occhiaie della fatica, chi se li scorda più”. Un tempo, quello della quotidianità, nella Roma fascista che troppo nascondeva dietro le tendine ricamate delle finestre dei caseggiati popolari. Lenzuola stese al sole di una Roma a Maggio, profumo di sapone e glicine, pantofole sdrucite e calze rammagliate, nell’orgoglio fascista della Patria. Fuori da quell’ambiente domestico il Mondo segna il suo tempo, anticipando il dolore di una guerra che intride  lenzuola che garriscono come bandiere del sangue dei figli che, Antonietta ancora non lo sa, sacrificherà a  quell’Adolf Hitler che, con Mussolini in testa, Roma attende con venerazione.  “Me chiedeva i giornali la sora Antonietta - racconta il portiere – ritagliava tutti gli articoli sul Duce”.  Dirimpettaio Gabriele, lo sapeva er Sor Fernando quello che si bisbigliava su di lui, ma non gli interessava: “Era un gran signore, educato, salutava, me dava la mancia a Natale e a Pasqua, parlava a bassa voce…dalla finestra sua sortiva quella musica americana che er Fascio proibiva, mortacci loro…me piaceva sta a sentì mentre pulivo er cortile del Palazzo… era musica de vita de gioventù vera altro che Giovinezza”…Una maratona nel tempo e nello spazio: microstoria di due vite umane, rette in parallelo, destinate a non incontrarsi mai se non fosse quell’inopinata fuga del pappagallino di Antonietta, quarantenne madre di sei figli che, volato via dalla finestra,  finisce sul davanzale del dirimpettaio. La donna si reca così dal vicino: è Gabriele affascinante, modi bizzarri e sfrontati, un incontro destinato a rovesciare prospettive  e visioni dei loro mondi. Prologo di una tragedia, prologo di una educazione al bello che Gabriele, il giornalista omosessuale, regala a Antonietta, prima di restituirla , per breve tratto alla sua falsa normalità -la guerra urge  e tutto cambierà – prima di recarsi al confino. Viaggio senza ritorno.Interpreti​Due i protagonisti Brunella Platania e Simone Sibillano : una intesa profonda nella scena, una capacità di essere vivi e veri che non potrà non affascinare. Due performer di razza  noti al grande pubblico del Musical e non solo capaci di convogliare l’interesse sia dei  loro fans  sia di chi ama ascoltare – leit motive e parole storie archiviate troppo in fretta Simone SibillanoNel 1998 si diploma all’Istituto Statale d’Arte Sacra per l’Arredamento e la Decorazione della Chiesa.Dal 1996 al 1998 studia canto lirico con il baritono R. Piemontese e nel frattempo frequenta corsi di danza moderna, jazz e latina e un corso di recitazione con il regista G. Nardoni.ESPERIENZE LAVORATIVE2015-2016 Production singer presso Costa Crociere2015 dirige e interpreta il musical “Il primo Papa” sulla vita di San Pietro, nel ruolo del protagonista2015 interpreta Amore nel Musical “Amore e Psiche” per la regia di Giovanni Nardoni.2015 Scrive il musical “Le sorelle Frank” liberamente ispirato al Diario di Anna Frank. E ne cura la regia2014 Scrive e interpreta il musical “Cercasi Violetta” per la regia di Marco Simeoli2013 Interpreta il ruolo di Tommaso nella commedia musicale "Raffaello e la leggenda della Fornarina" di Giancarlo Acquisti per la regia di Marcello Sindici2013 Scrive e dirige il musical “America” interpretando il ruolo di Bartolomeo Cataldo2012-2013 interpreta il ruolo del cacciatore nel musical “Biancaneve”2010-2011-2012 é Jafar nel musical “Aladin” di Stefano D'orazio musiche dei Pooh per la regia di Fabrizio angelini.Svolge per lo show un' attivita di vocal coach.2009-2010-2011 è Paolo il fariseo nella opera-musical "Wojtila generation" con concerti in Polonia e Spagna.2010 interpreta il ruolo di Karol Wojtila nel musical “Non abbiate paura- Giovanni Paolo II il grande” per la regia di Gianluca ferrato.2008-2009-2010 è impegnato nella tourneè del musical “Robin Hood” di B. Dati nel ruolo dello sceriffo di Notthingam Guyo Tristan per la regia di C. Ginepro.2007 è nel musical “Il principe della gioventù” di R. Ortolani per la regia di P. L. Pizzi nel ruolo di Franceschino2006-2007-2008 interpreta il ruolo di Jesus nel musical in versione italiana “Jesus Christ Superstar” di Webber – Rice per la regia di F. Angelini2005-2006 è Raoul ne "Il fantasma dell’opera" per la regia di A. De la Roche.2004 è nel musical "Boccadoro the traveller” per la regia di F.Angelini nel ruolo di Boccadoro.2003 interpreta il ruolo dell’evangelista nel musical "Per sempre mio divino amore" e il uolo dell’angelo nel musical "Quando cantano le ali", entrambi per la regia di L. Cognatti.2003 lavora come cantante solista-ballerino nella produzione Rai "Casaraiuno" per le coreografie di F. Miseria.2002 è nel musical “Il ritratto di Dorian Gray” di T. Russo, nel ruolo di Adrian Singleton e come cover di Dorian Gray, James Vane e Alan Campbell.2001 entra a far parte del musical “I Promessi Sposi” di T. Russo.2000 viene scritturato da M. Ranieri per il musical “Il grande campione” di M. Fabrizio e G. Morra per la regia di G. P. Griffi.1999 Debutta in teatro due anni dopo come cantante-attore al fianco di N. Castelnuovo nella tragedia musicale "Elena" di Euripide per la regia di G. Nardoni.1997 lavora come cantante solista nella produzione Mediaset “Sarabanda”.PREMI2014 vince il premio Broadwayworld.com per la categoria miglior attore protagonistaper l'interpretazione di Batolomeo Cataldo nel musical “America”. Brunella PlataniaCantante, attrice e doppiatrice.Attualmente è Vi Moore nel musical "Footloose" della Stage Entertainment. Brunella Platania, interpreta,nell’ambito del musical, il ruolo di Sidonia e Tosca in “Tosca Amore Disperato” di L. Perrozzi,diretta Angelini, Ambra in “E non finisce mica il cielo” di G. Vergoni, sempre per la regia di Angelini, la Signora Otis in “Canterville” di Robert Steiner , regia M. story:
Short Summary

Now in its 8th year, “What is Erotic?” is dedicated to fostering wellness around sex as an annual curated theatre arts show.   We invite artists, housewives, and politicians alike to answer one provocative question:  “What is Erotic?”  Although “What is Erotic?”  is a titillating performance arts show, it’s also a safe space for exploration, education, and self expression of sexuality and relationship--by combining personal development with creative expression.  

We want to give you a peek behind the curtain!  The documentary, including footage from rehearsals and coaching sessions with artists, will show you our 5 month intensive backstage process and highlight how we bring depth to each show.  Our goal is to bring sex out of the shadows and show that the erotic is something to celebrate--with authenticity and integrity!

The Impact

We see this documentary as the bridge to expand from our success as a local Santa Cruz fundraiser to becoming an internationally known exploration of healthy sexual expression.  The documentary makes it clear how we 'break the taboo' of the erotic, and will assist us in creating shows in communities across the globe.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $5,000 for our pre-production documentary work.

We have hired a team of documentarians who are filming every meeting, works in progress, and character development lab. 

FUNDS GO TOWARD:

  • Filming Equipment
  • Lights
  • Film Editor
  • Videographer

We have successfully completed 7 years of shows, with a steady increase in revenue annually.  Dozens of people have performed, hundreds have volunteered, and thousands have seen the show.  We feel we've matured and are ready to take this show on the road! and out to many new audiences.  We hope you agree that this is a worthy cause and that our society is ready for a new way to be with the erotic. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Regardless of your ability to chip in financially, you can help!

Please get the word out NOW and make some noise about the campaign!  Use of email, social media like Twitter and Facebook, and good old fashioned word of mouth are all extremely helpful.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!  The more activity on Indiegogo, the more likely they will spread the word too.

You can volunteer behind-the-scenes!  We would love your contribution.  Contact us to assist with production, finding sponsorships, volunteer wrangling, graphic art, writing, etc.

story:
Short Summary

Our senior acting class at Elon University is responsible for producing two full length shows and this includes fund raising! We have selected Columbinus by Steven Karam and PJ Paparelli and Beautiful Bodies by Laura Shaine Cunningham. We are all passionate artists and these are two powerful pieces that we believe are worth sharing with the world.

What We Need

In order to produce a show, there are a number of things we have to pay for, including:

  • Rights for the shows
  • Set materials
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Publicity

Why We Are Doing It

Both Columbinus and Beautiful Bodies deal heavily with important and relevant social issues. Columbinus is a theatrical docu-drama about the events that took place at the Columbine high school massacre. With the recent surge in teen violence, this production couldn't be more relevant or important to share with the public. Beautiful Bodies is a story of a group of women coming together at major transition points in their lives. With themes of friendship, and body image, we think this is a really important piece to share with young adults. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are college kids so we know as well as anyone that money can be tight at times. If you can't donate today, please consider sharing our project on any form of social media you can. Facebook, twitter, and anything else you can possibly imagine. 

Also, come see our shows! They run at Elon University's Black Box Theater from Nov 14th-18th. Thank you so much for your time!

story:
Join the National Asian American Theater Movement!

The Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) is an organization that supports the vibrant, growing and changing field of Asian American theater. We organize the biennial National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival (ConFest). Preparations are now underway for the sixth convening, this year in Chicago from August 13-18.

Since the first national gathering in 2006, CAATA has rallied Asian American theater artists and professionals to dive headfirst into the deep, challenging conversations that surround what it means to be engaged in American theater as a person of color.

This year's theme, Revolutionary Acts, will engage attendees and the Chicago community in critical theatre and dialogue regarding the intersection of art, leadership, and community in the face of social injustice, inequity, and active resistance in American culture. What are we, as theater practitioners, doing about it? How will we be responsive together?

Over the course of six days in Chicago, the 2018 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival will bring theater productions, panel discussions, plenary sessions, new play readings, workshops, special events, and most importantly, a space for Asian American artists and professionals from across the country to connect and build the relationships that help keep the community vibrant and alive. It will be an opportunity to see some of the amazing work being presented by theater artists across the country.

What Your Help Can Do

As a member of this community we ask you to support CAATA and the upcoming ConFest. Your contribution goes directly toward advancing Asian and Pacific Islander artistic work in the American theater landscape and raising the visibility of the Asian Pacific community, the fastest growing population in the United States.

The 2018 National Asian American Theater Conference and Festival is expected to cost $240,000 for six days of programming. This includes:

  • Staging five Festival productions, plus numerous showcases and readings
  • Hiring technicians, operators and front of house staff
  • Honorariums for artists, speakers and panelists
  • Travel stipends for ConFest participants
  • Printing Conference and Festival materials
  • Hosting receptions and other opportunities for attendees to convene
  • ConFest marketing and outreach

Most of the cost will be covered by government and foundation grants. But in order for this historic, national gathering to be successful, we need the support of all members of the Asian American community: artists, administrators, audiences and beyond.

About Us

The Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists (CAATA) envisions a strong and sustainable Asian American theater community that is an integral presence in national culture: evocative of our past, declarative of our present, and innovative towards our future. Our mission is to advance the field of Asian American theater through a national network of organizations and artists. We collaborate to inspire learning and sharing of knowledge and resources to promote a healthy, sustainable artistic ecology.

story:
Pencil Productions is delighted to announce 

Stranger Odds will be going to the Fresh Fruit Festival this July!

Can you help us get there?

 

Stranger Odds

Written by Rachel Graf Evans / Directed by Philip Waller

Featuring the talents of 
Jacqueline Chambers, Peter Giessl, Olivia Jampol, Mallory Kinney, and Josh Krebs

Synopsis 

After an awkward encounter with a cute guy at a coffee shop, Maggie thinks she is hopelessly doomed in the ways of romance in the big bad city. Since her normally helpful and supportive roommate Stevie has just fallen for the cutest femme named Tanya, Maggie finds advice at the hands of Stevie's delightfully meddlesome friend Frankie, who just so happens to have a tragically straight and single roommate. A queer little rom-com about the venn diagrams of who we are lucky enough to know.   

How can you help?

Well, producing a play around here takes some stuff, especially if you want to be able to thank everyone that helped you do something with some cash monies.

We’d like to be able to do that. We’d like to be able to pay our actors, director, stage manager, and designers. We also need to rehearse somewhere, have things on stage that help tell our story, and then we need to get people to come see it with nifty little pieces of propaganda we mean publicity designed by someone awesome whom we’d also like to pay.

In order to do all of this, we need to raise $2500. Can you help us?

Can’t formally donate but still want to support us? Oh please come see the show!

Tickets can be purchased here.

 The performances will be

July 17th @9PM
July 18th @7PM
and July 20th @12noon
at The Wild Project

 

Feel free to pass this along to anyone who may be interested.
Be sure to stay in touch with us at Pencil Productions.
story_txt:
Pencil Productions is delighted to announce 
Stranger Odds will be going to the Fresh Fruit Festival this July!
Can you help us get there?
 
Stranger OddsWritten by Rachel Graf Evans / Directed by Philip Waller
Featuring the talents of Jacqueline Chambers, Peter Giessl, Olivia Jampol, Mallory Kinney, and Josh Krebs
Synopsis 
After an awkward encounter with a cute guy at a coffee shop, Maggie thinks she is hopelessly doomed in the ways of romance in the big bad city. Since her normally helpful and supportive roommate Stevie has just fallen for the cutest femme named Tanya, Maggie finds advice at the hands of Stevie's delightfully meddlesome friend Frankie, who just so happens to have a tragically straight and single roommate. A queer little rom-com about the venn diagrams of who we are lucky enough to know.   
How can you help?
Well, producing a play around here takes some stuff, especially if you want to be able to thank everyone that helped you do something with some cash monies.
We’d like to be able to do that. We’d like to be able to pay our actors, director, stage manager, and designers. We also need to rehearse somewhere, have things on stage that help tell our story, and then we need to get people to come see it with nifty little pieces of propaganda we mean publicity designed by someone awesome whom we’d also like to pay.
In order to do all of this, we need to raise $2500. Can you help us?
Can’t formally donate but still want to support us? Oh please come see the show!
Tickets can be purchased here.
 The performances will be
July 17th @9PMJuly 18th @7PMand July 20th @12noonat The Wild Project
 
Feel free to pass this along to anyone who may be interested.Be sure to stay in touch with us at Pencil Productions.

story:
Short Summary

Each summer since 2005, Sonoma Conservatory of Dance has held a Summer Dance Workshop and Performance.  The expenses related to the Workshop and Performance, including (among other things) an outstanding guest faculty and performance venue rental, total over $20,000. 

As the Owner and Artistic Director, I have chosen to keep the tuition and ticket prices low in comparison to other summer dance programs, in order to be able to bring dance to as many interested students as possible each summer.  Therefore, the $20,000+ in expenses are not covered by tuition and performance ticket sales.  In the past, I have made up any shortfalls with my own personal funds because I love to share my passion for dance with these amazing young people.

In order to make this Workshop a viable option this summer, I am asking you to help me by contributing to our campaign.  By doing so, you will be supporting a high-quality summer dance training program that allows students to develop mastery in a friendly and encouraging environment.

Those who have experienced our Summer Dance Workshops in the past express themselves so eloquently:

"At age 15, my daughter is among the youngest students at San Francisco Conservatory of Dance's Session 3 Workshop.  Not only is the strength of my daughter's ballet technique repeatedly acknowledged by the director and instructors of San Francisco Conservatory of Dance but last summer she pleasantly surprised the instructors at Ballet West of Salt Lake City, Utah, for having strong Character Dance technique -- something she only learned during her summers with SCD!"  Laura Lee Cole

"I have been dancing at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance for ten years and have received excellent instruction. I felt very well prepared for my Summer Intensive experience at Ballet Magnificat, in Jackson, Mississippi this summer.

Patty emphasizes excellent technique, and because of small class size, she is able to give explicit individual corrections to each student, therefore expediting learning.  She knows how to motivate each student to her full potential, which I believe has greatly benefited me. In fact, I was placed a level higher than my peers at Ballet Magnificat, I believe, because of Patty’s excellent teaching standards.

Patty has taught me to push myself by helping me to make mental and physical connections, which has enabled me to do what I never knew that I could do. And because of this I have become much more confident as a dancer.

Not only have I learned about ballet techniques and combinations, I have also learned about the history of ballet, mathematical concepts in relation to body angles, and the different genres of music related to dance.  I have a passion for dance and look forward to growing more under Patty’s instruction."  Natalie Palmgren

With your help, we can keep adding to the list of beaming dancers well-trained and excited to follow dance wherever it leads them! 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to truly bridge the gap and cover all expenses, we are exploring various fundraising opportunities as we strive to raise $6000.  Reaching our Indiegogo Campaign Goal of $3000 will bring us halfway there.  Any funds raised beyond the $3000 will, of course, bring us closer to our overall target.  Should we raise more than $6000 from Indiegogo and our 50-50 Raffle, we will set those funds aside for Summer Dance Workshop 2014.  What a wonderfully exciting gift that would be for dance in the Sonoma Valley and surrounding communities!

The Impact

With arts education at risk in so many schools, what is available to the students at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance's Summer Dance Workshop is invaluable.  Dance helps students to ground themselves, work as a team, learn patience and perseverence, all skills that will help them in the academic environment as well as life, as they mature into adulthood.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about Sonoma Conservatory of Dance. 

  • Like us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/sonomaconservatoryofdance and share our Events
  • Share this Campaign with your friends
  • Visit our website at www.SonomaDanceStudio.com to learn more about us and what we offer to the community
  • Subscribe to our e-newsletter at http://visitor.r20.constantcontact.com/manage/o...

If right now money is scarce, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Share our campaign with your friends & family.
  • Please use the tools below to share our campaign on facebook and twitter, too!

We appreciate any help you can give!

story:
Help BBRT Produce Cruel Tears/Lágrimas Crueles!

Contemporary relevance of classic works


What’s going on?

We are building on the two previous incarnations of this work (the English Canadian-set Cruel Tears, and the Spanish Mexican-set Lágrimas Crueles) to create a bilingual musical production to be presented here in Victoria.  It will be a new version, neither the Canadian Cruel Tears nor the Mexican Lágrimas Crueles.  This adaptation moves the events across the border into Texas, where the dynamics of race and immigration that grip the entire continent are most vivid.  It is vital to keep both languages (as opposed to artificially imposing English onto Mexican characters) for various reasons – it will highlight the cultural tensions, and also give Canadian audiences the chance to hear the cadence and richness of Spanish as it is spoken and, most importantly, sung. 

By producing Cruel Tears, BBRT is embarking upon a variety of endeavours including: 

  • our first formal collaboration with another local theatre company, PUENTE Theatre; 
  • showcasing the transformation and continued improvements of The Roxy Theatre; 
  • and our ongoing commitment to provide professional work opportunities for early career professionals. 

HISTORY OF CRUEL TEARS

  • Originally commissioned by the Persephone Theatre in 1975 (Brian Richmond, Artistic Director), Cruel Tears is a contemporary retelling of Shakespeare’s Othello, transposed into the world of Saskatchewan truckers
  • Cruel Tears went on to be invited to the 1976 Cultural Olympics in Montreal and the United Nations Conference for the Habitat in Vancouver
  • Cruel Tears was one of the first major cross-Canada tours to originate from a Western Canadian theatre company
SPANISH REVIVAL

  • In 2006, in collaboration with the Universidad Veracruzana in Xalapa, Mexico,  Cruel Tears was redeveloped by Brian Richmond and Mercedes Bátiz-Benét (now Artistic Director of PUENTE Theatre) to become Lágrimas Crueles - the story of Cruel Tears transposed onto to Mexican soil.  The production was remounted twice, and was invited to the prestigious Teatro Salvador Novo at the National Arts Centre in Mexico City.  

WHY THE NEW ADAPTATION?

There are three main reasons we wish to pursue this new development of this classic work:

  1. To Fully Realize the Original Vision of the Work: when Ken Mitchell and Humphrey and the Dumptrucks first started working on the play in 1975, it was originally conceived as a folk opera. Cruel Tears / Lágrimas Crueles will explore the relationship between American and Mexican folk music in the  realization of this opera.  
  2. To Stay True to the Shakespearean Roots of this Work: Cruel Tears is based on Shakespeare’s Othello; but the connection between these two works goes beyond plot structure.  Shakespeare was a master of utilizing allegory in the writing of his plays.  Othello, while taking place in Venice, Italy, really spoke to the heart of the immigrant influx into London – a hot-button topic for the local population.  It is with a similar allegorical approach that we wish to explore Cruel Tears / Lágrimas Crueles.  By setting the play in the midst of the tensions between the Mexican and US border, we are able to evoke many themes that are important to Canadian poplulations – particularly in British Columbia.  
  3. To Fulfill BBRT’s Commitment to Fresh Takes on Classic Works: classic works are classics because they have stood the test of time.  Many of these works are revered and iconicized, but in that there is a danger of these works being treated a museum pieces – relics from the past.  At BBRT, we are passionate about highlighting or showcasing the contemporary relevance of these classic works – and one of the strategies in achieving this is the development of a new adaptation of a classic work.  It also has the opportunity to ignite a new method of working at BBRT, where we can truly use the Roxy Theatre as an incubator for more fresh takes on classic works.

What will the funding be used for?

All money raised by this campaign will go directly towards production costs!  This includes:

  • Artist Salaries
  • Production Design (Sets, Lights, Costumes, Props)
  • Production Tech (equipment, running crew, materials)
  • Marketing Materials to promote the show!
