story:
*We have reached our Indiegogo goal, but we have more funds to raise towards our overall goal! Please continute to donate if you are willing and able!!*

The Persecution and Assassination of Jean-Paul Marat as Performed by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charenton Under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade

Produced by Alex Wolfe, Directed by Fergus Inder 

The inmates of the Charenton Asylum in France are instructed to perform a play detailing the events that led to the assassination of radical journalist Jean-Paul Marat during the French Revolution. The performance is directed by their fellow inmate, the Marquis de Sade, and has a revolutionary character of its own, intended to defy the hospital director and staff.

Performances will be held in McCormick Auditorium in the Norris University Center at Northwestern University. The dates and times of the performances are:

  • Thursday, November 7: 10 pm
  • Friday, November 8: 8 and 11 pm
  • Saturday, November 9: 8 and 11 pm

Tickets are only $5 for those with a Northwestern ID and a mere $10 for the general public.

WAVE Productions

WAVE Productions is one of eight theatre boards in StuCo, Northwestern's student theatre coalition. Each board is fully functional and reflects the models of not-for-profit theatre set by Chicago storefront theatres and Off-Off-Broadway theatres in New York. WAVE's mission is to produce projects that students are passionate about. 

The Team

Marat/Sade has a 52-person production team and 17-person cast. Positions on the team range from producer and director to co-assistant master electricians and fundraising assistants. This show will be put on entirely by this group -- funding, marketing, designs, building, technical work, direction, and more. Everyone on the team, no matter how large or small their position, has put in so much effort already. We are also so passionate and excited about this project and want to share this enthusiasm with our audiences and additionally those who cannot see the show but want to support it.

How Your Donation Helps

With a budget that is over $5,000, we really appreciate even the smallest of donations. We are putting our money towards elements of the show including:

  • Set: a bathhouse with multi-level platforms, multiple bathtubs and showers, and more
  • Lights: our lighting design includes multiple moving lights that aid in the development and change of tone throughout the show
  • Costumes: our costume designs are very specific to the outfits worn in French mental asylums of the Napoleonic Era -- many of our costumes are being hand-made by our incredible four-person costume team
  • Hair/Make-up: with characters that have skin diseases, act as clowns, and more, a lot of the world of the asylum is created through specific hair and make-up designs
  • Publicity: we are trying to attract as wide of an audience as possible, reaching out to student groups at Northwestern, businesses in the town of Evanston, and theatres and businesses around Chicago

If You Do Not Have the Means to Donate

We understand!! You can support our show in a variety of ways:

  • Share the indiegogo link on social networking sites and with family and friends
  • Come see the show! We'd love to have as many people as possible see this incredible work of art. To reserve seats, email alexandrawolfe2016@u.northwestern.edu.

story:
Bring Swing Back To Rosa Parks for ArtPrize

For 9 years the Grand Rapids Original Swing Society has brought swing dancing to Grand Rapids with the belief that the community is a better place when people can come together to dance.  We have taught thousands of people of all ages.

However this summer swing dance at Rosa Parks Circle was put into jeopardy when non-dancers came to the park to cause trouble.  So we moved the dance indoors as a result.  

We miss the outdoor dance and want to bring it back for three nights Sept. 24th.  Oct 1st and Oct 8th from 7-10pm. 

What We Need Help

The only way we can bring swing back is if we hire the added security the Grand Rapids Police say we need. We need to hire 5 police officers at $70 an hour for 3 hours.  This means $1050 just for security on each night. 

We also need to still pay for insurance, rent, permits, and sound system.  So for the three nights we need to raise around $5000 dollars.

Make Swing Night Outdoors again

Help us bring swing back to Rosa Parks Circle to show the troublemakers that you can not take this away from us. 

 Even if we can't raise the entire amount we hope to make enough for 1 night.  Anything over $5000 will be used to pay for more outdoor nights next year.

story:
What more can I say besides, THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME REACH MY GOAL! I am so appreciative to all who donated to this campaign. It is a heavy burden lifted off of my shoulders. Now I can focus on the many other things that need to get done before relocating to NYC!!!! I love you all and God Bless!

Welcome to my campaign,

My name is Stacie Cannon, I'm from Portsmouth, Va and I'm 25 yrs. old. I attended Shenandoah University and graduated in 2009 with a BFA in Dance. Currently, I teach and dance in Washington D.C., but I will be moving to New York by the end of this summer. I was afforded the opportunity to attend Peridance Capezio Center's 2-year Certificate Program for professional dancers. My focus will be in the Ballet/Contemporary track.

Why I need your help!!!   ($5,000)

I need to raise $5,000 for half of my tuition cost. The other half of my tuition cost will be matched, then my full tuition for the year will be paid off. Coming up with these funds on my own is more than a challenge...that's why I need your help! Please donate whatever amount you are willing to give. It all adds up in the end, right?!?!

Why Peridance?

The Certificate Program at Peridance Capezio Center is the perfect program for me at this point in my life. Getting to New York City to train and perform has always been on my list of "dance goals" since I was in middle school. The time is NOW!
    This program gives me the opportunity to continue to train on a professional level in a learning, competitive and nurturing environment in NYC. I will also be able to network with world-renowned teachers, choreographers and directors that I may not get the opportunity to meet outside of this program. Having 3-4 technique classes, five days a week, will significantly help to improve my technique, artistry and the confidence I will need to audition for major dance companies.
   One of my biggest goals as a dancer, is to join a major dance company that does tons of national and international touring (I love to travel). The Certificate Program has a large international connection that could introduce me to the possibilities of performing and teaching abroad. I really couldn't ask for more!

THANK YOU for helping me get closer to dreams. I really appreciate your time, help and support!!!

story:
“...you’re never less than happy to be there, watching Mr. Harrell and his ever-changing crew say yes to everything.” --The New York Times


ABOUT THE PROJECT

This Spring, my newest work, Antigone Sr./Twenty Looks or Paris is Burning at The Judson Church (L), will premiere over four nights at New York Live Arts from April 25 - April 28. 

Antigone Sr. is the culmination of eleven years of research and the apex in a series of choreographic works that come in five sizes: Twenty Looks or Paris is Burning at The Judson Church Extra Small (XS), Small (S), (M)imosa, Antigone (jr.) and now, Antigone(Sr.). All five sizes share the same proposition:  What would have happened in 1963 if someone from the Voguing ball scene in Harlem had come downtown to perform alongside the early postmoderns at Judson Church? 

Antigone Sr. proposes a look at the voguing dance tradition –a form of dance itself predominantly practiced by African-American and Latino gays, transsexuals and transgendered– and its relationship to the aesthetic foundations of ancient Greek classical theater, where men also played male and female roles.


WHY VOGUING AND POSTMODERISM?

I was stunned to find out that voguing and Judson era postmodern dance started around the same historical time in the 1960’s—one downtown in Greenwich Village and one uptown in Harlem. Since 2001, my work has imagined what would happen if the two actually came together in dialogue to question and reflect together -- politically and aesthetically.

 Of course, dance history speaks about Judson, but not voguing. Gérard Mayen, the collaborating dramaturg, has written, “Judson reunited middle and upper-middle class artists and audiences, white and culturally  selective, politicized, and convinced of the democratic scope of their privilege for an everyday gesture and body - one that was neutral and full of ‘authenticity.’ The voguing ballrooms brought together poorer artists and audiences, non-white, inspired by pop and fashion culture and a search for the ‘realness’ of gesture” --which turns out to reveal the artificiality being performed at the root of all social identities. â€¨â€¨

 I am most interested in how the imagination can re-think the “omissions” of history.  In this vein, performance can be a way in which we collectively re-imagine the impossibilities of history and thus make room for new possibilities in the world we make today. â€¨



WHY INDIEGOGO?

In April, nine incredible performers and designers will travel to New York to rehearse and premiere Antigone Sr. I spend a lot of time in Europe developing work and collaborating with wonderful artists there, but my work is inspired by and responds to the culture of the US, so to me, it is crucial to keep a home base and premiere the work in New York.

While it’s no surprise that it can cost a lot of money to sustain an international practice, the reality is that very few US grants cover international travel costs, particularly to bring artists from abroad to perform here. That’s why we are reaching out to friends and supporters, to help us make this project possible.

Antigone Sr.’s premiere has received the incredibly generous support of our presenter (above and beyond!!) and some longtime supporters. We’ve raised a substantial portion of the project budget, but travel and lodging remains the single largest expense for us to cover. We need to raise a minimum of $9,500 to get everyone over here and put a roof over their heads when they arrive. We have a great team working extremely hard to bring this work to New York and share it, and we are getting closer. With your help, we know we can get there!

 HEART,

Trajal and the creative team of Antigone Sr.

 

WHO’S ON THE CREATIVE TEAM

Choreographer: Trajal Harrell

Interpreters: Rob Fordeyn (Belgium), Trajal Harrell, Thibault Lac (France), Stephen Thompson (Canada), Ondrej Vidlar (Czech Republic)

Set Designer: Erik Flatmo (San Francisco)

Lighting Designer: Jan Maartens (Belgium)

Sound Designer: Robin Meier (Switzerland)

Dramaturg: Gérard Mayen (France)

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPâ€¨

Spread the word by telling your friends and sharing this campaign on your social networks. Most of all, see the work at New York Live Arts, April 25-28!â€¨


FAQS:

"What happens if you exceed the funding goal? Should I still give?"

YES! $9,500 is a minimum just to get everyone here. We could still use your support on production related costs!

 

"If I'm not in the US, can I still give?"

YES! Wherever you are, Indiegogo can accept your online donation --and we can feel your support.

 

"Where can I learn more?"

Visit my website at betatrajal.org, find me on Facebook, follow me on Twitter @trajal, or contact: trajalnyc12@gmail.com

story:
The Shelter Presents: Art
Among all creatures on this earth, art is a uniquely human activity. In THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART, four playwrights track the journey of the artist and examine art’s role in the human experience. This exploration spans time and genres, and in true Shelter style, produces a seamless blend of comedy and drama. 

“THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART explores the journey of the artist from the birth of art in mankind to the birth of art in the individual man. From hope to desolation, THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART examines the need to create and how it affects the relationships we have with our fellow human beings," stated The Shelter Co-Artistic Director Meghan E. Jones.

The four short plays are:
  • Michael Sean McGuinness’ GLYPH – a cave comedy about the origin of the artist and his struggle to survive, directed by Catya McMullen. The cast of GLYPH will feature Alec A. Head, Chris Cardona, Andy Hassell, and Tania Verafied.
  • Meghan E. Jones’ MARK MAKES ART – a play that examines two struggling parents whose child is creating brilliant, yet emotionally unsettling drawings, directed by Paco Lozano. This two-hander will feature Beth Jastroch and Dave Lankford.
  • Michael Bernstein’s play ROBOT GIRL envisions a dystopian future, where a lone street artist calls out over airwaves searching for other signs of humanity in a lifeless, robot-automated world, directed by Beth Jastroch. The ROBOT GIRL cast will feature Olivia Killingswoth.
  • Ginger Kearn’s THIS IS A PLAY ABOUT ARTISTS launches two self-righteous artists at one another, creating an absurdly funny – and unexpected – romantic conundrum, directed by Nicole Rosner. THIS IS A PLAY ABOUT ARTISTS will feature Ian Bell, Ginger Kearns and Michael Kingsbaker.

The Shelter will also work with several local New York artists to create a large spectrum of art, spanning many disciplines. Art will be on display at the theatre, a different guest artist will create an original piece of art during each performance, and performance art designed by Melinda Smart will be integrated into the overall production.

THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART runs April 19 through 29, with performances Wednesdays through Fridays at 8:00pm, Saturdays at 3:00pm and 8:00pm and Sundays at 3:00pm at the Flamboyan Theater (at the CSV Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street). Tickets are $12 during preview performances (April 19 and April 20) and $18 for the remainder of the run. Tickets can be purchased online at www.theshelternyc.org or at the door.


About The Shelter
The Shelter is a family of theatrical artists creating authentic theatre for the New York stage. All productions are written, directed, acted, and designed by its members and are developed through the company's weekly Shelter Sunday workshop series. The heartbeat of The Shelter, Shelter Sunday provides a safe harbor where New York's top emerging theatrical artists can collaboratively challenge themselves to explore their artistry and hone their respective crafts.  

"The Shelter is to be applauded for the work it’s doing — developing new theatre and building creative relationships at a time when small theatre companies are dropping like flies. Its approach to making theatre is both practical and optimistic." Regina Robbins, Theatre Is Easy
 
For more information about THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART or The Shelter, please visit www.theshelternyc.org.

story:
Script

Spots and Stripes is a timeless original tale, part allegory and part fantasy. Two medieval communities have lived separated by the "land of in-between" for hundreds of years, after the last war.  A child from each side gets lost in the forest, befriends the other child, and they exchange "Spots" and "Stripes" cloaks. Uproar ensues when the children return to their own lands.  The once-great Spotted and Striped armies have dwindled over the years into one solitary knight each. These knights are sent to engage in battle to save their people.  King Zutan is a hard-hearted penny pincher who is more concerned with his treasury than his subjects.  King Mollus is absent-minded, indecisive and easily manipulated. Enchanted animals and a Great Silver Oak bring the lands together, but for how long? Fifteen marvelous songs leave you thoughtful, happy and humming.

Summary

Namron Players Theatre, Gregg Standridge and Brian Eads are uniting for this adventure! These artists are seasoned, with a long list of achievements.  The story was created to show children and adults that although prejudice is alive, it can be overcome.  How timely is that? We will make this incredible independent musical happen, but can only do it with YOUR SUPPORT!

The Production Team

Gregg Standridge, Original Lyrics, Music, Orchestration
Brian Eads, Original Book, Music, Sound Designer
Kassie Carroll, Director, Choreographer
Sarah King Bartell, Production Manager
Lynn Crussel, Costumes
Craig Swan, Set & Image Designer
Isabelle Scroggie, Director Read-Through
Michael & Gloria McCarty - Publicity

Gregg Standridge

                                    Original Lyrics, Music, Orchestration, Musical composition

Gregg is a musician, singer/songwriter. "Gus knows me." (Songwriter of Big Dumb Buildings,  http://www.bigdumbbuildings.com/index.html ) S & S music includes folk rock with aspects of traditional country/bluegrass/soul as well as jazz/blues and gospel. Gregg studied music at OCCC, USAO and Oklahoma City University, and has a Masters Degree in Classical Guitar Performance. Gregg offers private lessons in guitar, mandolin and bass from his studio at the Norman Music Institute. Teaching experience includes positions at Oklahoma City University and Oklahoma City Community College as head of guitar studies. Standridge currently performs in the OKC area and with The Sunday Flyers, Empty Bottles, and Terry Buffalo Ware.

                                                                                   

                                              Brian Eads                                                

Original Book, Music, Sound Designer/Engineer

Brian’s eye and ear for detail and organization keep us in line! "Bake knows me." (Songwriter of Big Dumb Buildings, http://www.bigdumbbuildings.com/index.html ) Brian owns Dust Bunny Ranch Recording Studios.  He is kind, trustworthy and gives of himself effortlessly. Sound and writing extraordinaire!


Kassie Carroll

Director, Choreographer

Kassie has directed and choreographed in New York and Australia, and has brought her amazing talents back to Oklahoma.  She has performed Off-Broadway and is a member of Actors' Equity.  She recently directed Oklahoma Cimarron Opera's production of HMS Pinafore. She teaches at Sooner Theatre Performing Arts.  And a shout-out to Sooner Theatre for letting us use workshop space!

Sarah King Bartell

Production Manager, Actress

Sarah is Co-founder and Chairman of the Namron Players Theatre in Norman, a 501c3 nonprofit organization dedicated to producing original work with local artists.  http://www.namronplayers.com/  In her spare time she writes plays, creates visual art out of trash, and teaches a Playwriting class at the Lyric Theatre Thelma Gaylord Academy.  
 

 

Craig Swan
  Graphics and Set Designer

Craig is a visual artist, arts educator, musician, writer, aspiring language nerd, and a jackass of all trades. He digs heavy metal, house cats and compassion.
https://www.craigswanart.com/

Lynn Crussel, Costumes, Previously worked on Namron costumes Fahrenheit 451.

Campaign Details

For S & S, our main concerns are raising funds to pay for performance space, artistic stipends, and technical elements. Our goal is to pay everyone involved something for their hard work, talent, and time. Musicals are far more involved then straight plays. A play requires actors and a director.  A ballet requires dancers and a choreographer.  A concert requires singers and a musical director.  A musical requires all these, plus: live and recorded music; sets, costume, lighting and sound designers; dance and fight choreography; scenery builders; stage managers; as well as cast and ensemble (20), orchestra (7), technical crew and more. Our aim is to raise 13K to produce Spots and Stripes in Spring 2018.  Here's how our budget estimate rolls out:


And remember Namron is a 501c3 nonprofit organization. We need all YOUR SUPPORT for this ambitious work with fabulous music!

What You Get!

We are grateful to you for being a huge part of making this happen! You benefit as well!   
Perks include Facebook, Program, and Pre-Show Recognition, for you and your business; S & S T Shirts; Magic Silver Oak Leaves; S & S Tickets and VIP front row seat tickets; you will get to pick from 6 total performances.  It's also possible to get 1 year season passes to all Namron shows and Dinner/Karaoke with Gregg & Becky.  For our highest level, you can also have a custom song written for you for a special friend or occasion, and dinner with our Director where you can ask all your burning questions about Musical Theatre!
 

Your Contribution Makes an Impact!

NAMRON's goal is to create work that we, as artists, are passionate about. S & S has been a most unexpected and exhilarating experience for all involved.  There is a generosity of spirit that keeps us flying and allows us the inspiration to create music and art.  There is strength, fortitude, courage, and incredible natural talent that allow the development and distance that we've all come thus far!  We believe in bringing communities together and celebrating!

Challenges

Should we fall short of our target, and let's hope not, we will still use the funds to produce Spots and Stripes, but will re-prioritize aspects of the production. The production will continue to raise funds via grants and donations and achieve our production targets.  If we perchance exceed our goal, we plan to distribute it to the artists.  This is an exciting opportunity for these artists to earn compensation for their work. Compensation which often hard to come by in theatre.
An ongoing challenge is to "keep the wheels spinning" in these coming months of development.  Our BIG hope is to create a professional and popular musical that may be managed and performed by new teams over the coming years.  

Other Ways You Can Help

 We ask all friends to do whatever  you can.  Here are some ideas:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come to our show!
  • Use all that social media for good!

Once you've contributed, you're a part of our theatre family–if you provide your email, we will keep you posted every step of the way on this production and future ones! Every bit helps. Even spreading the word or sharing the campaign would make a huge difference. 

The most important thing is to get this show onstage for you to see!  We're ready to tell you a really great story and perhaps surprise you along the way.  We believe the process of making Spots & Stripes and sharing it will be a success in itself!

story:
Le Laboratoire

Le Laboratoire, théâtre de (ré)création contemporaine, a été créé en 2009, parce que c'était le rêve fou de la comédienne Eugénie Beaudry d'enfin mettre sur scène ce qu'elle avait dans la tête. Collaboratrice de longue date avec le chorégraphe Dave St-Pierre, elle a appris a laisser libre cours à son imagination en créant sur scène des images fortes, ludiques et émouvantes. Elle voulait chercher l'endroit où les mots n'ont plus leur place, explorer les travers du genre humain. Le Laboratoire est né.

Le Projet

Le Trou est la 3ème création du Laboratoire. Écrite et mise en scène par Eugénie Beaudry, elle met en vedette des comédiens chevronnés; Édith Arvisais, Joseph Bellerose, Yannick Chapdelaine, Isabelle Guérard et Mariane Lamarre. Karine Galarneau est de nouveau à la barre des costumes et des décors, Anne-Marie Rodrigue Lecours à l'éclairage, Benoît Finley à la musique originale et Sonia Montagne à la régie et assistance à la mise en scène. Une équipe de rêve! 

C'est un projet qui est inspiré du milieu dans lequel l'auteur a grandi; l'industrie de la foresterie. L'action se déroule dans un sous-sol, à la veille de la destruction d'un village inconnu dans le fin fond de la province suite à la fermeture de l'usine de pâtess et papiers de la ville. Les gens sont partis chercher du travail ailleurs. Aux nouvelle on nn'en parle pas. Tout le monde s'en sacre, finalement. Sara-Lee, complètement incapable de sortir de son sous-sol à cause de multiples phobies sociales, rassemblera tout ce qui lui reste de courage pour empêcher que sa ville ne s'éteigne définitivement. Son père, ancien maire de la ville devenu paralysé à la suite d'un AVC, et Jo, son bras droit, feront tout en leur pouvoir pour lui cacher la vérité jusqu'à la dernière seconde. 

L'auteur joue encore une fois dans son terrain de jeu préféré; les bas-fonds de la société et les perceptions erronées qui entrainent les personnages vers un dénouement redoutable et inattendu.

Où iront vos sous?

Vous pouvez vous associer au Laboratoire pour créer ce spectacle! Nous avons besoin de 2500$ qui seront intelligemment dépensés: 

1500$ serviront à défrayer les coûts de la publicité (relations de presse, affiches, programmes, site web, médias), c'est essentiel pour amener le public au théâtre et obtenir des entrevues dans les médias. 

1000$ qui serviront à payer en partie les locaux de répétition (110 heures X 10$ = 1100$ + taxes)

Évidemment, nous ne couvrirons pas toutes nos dépenses avec ce 2500$, il reste les costumes, les décors, le support technique (dvd, cd, éclairage), la papeterie, le comptable, et j'en passe, alors n'hésitez pas à défoncer l'objectif de 2500$!!! 

Personnalisez votre don! Dites-nous à quel genre de trou vous vous identifiez (!!!)

Votre soutien est essentiel!

L'auteur nous revient avec son style cru, sans détour. C'est un texte engagé, cinglant, les personnages y sont attachants, démunis devant la perte d'une amitié, d'un emploi, d'une vie. Certains y verront une critique de société, d'autres, l'histoire d'une fille asociale qui voulait se battre contre quelque chose de trop grand pour elle. 

Ceux qui ont vu le spectacle Gunshot de Lulla West savent de quoi il est question. Les autres, qu'attendez-vous? Vous pouvez faire une grosse différence dans la production du spectacle! Une perruque coute 25$, des rembourrures pour le costume d'Édith, 10$. Avec aussi peu que 10$, on peut faire beaucoup! 

Avec votre précieux soutien, il nous sera possible de créer un univers riche, et d'enfin amener sur scène le sous-sol de Sara-Lee. Vous passerez une excellente soirée, on vous le garanti!

Pas un rond? Pas de problème! 

Il y a des moments dans la vie où on voudrait aider, mais notre compte en banque, lui, ne peut pas. Qu'à cela ne tienne! Pour nous soutenir, vous nous aiderez autant en partageant ce lien! Parlez-en à vos amis, vos familles! Répandez!
story_txt: Le LaboratoireLe Laboratoire, théâtre de (ré)création contemporaine, a été créé en 2009, parce que c'était le rêve fou de la comédienne Eugénie Beaudry d'enfin mettre sur scène ce qu'elle avait dans la tête. Collaboratrice de longue date avec le chorégraphe Dave St-Pierre, elle a appris a laisser libre cours à son imagination en créant sur scène des images fortes, ludiques et émouvantes. Elle voulait chercher l'endroit où les mots n'ont plus leur place, explorer les travers du genre humain. Le Laboratoire est né.Le ProjetLe Trou est la 3ème création du Laboratoire. Écrite et mise en scène par Eugénie Beaudry, elle met en vedette des comédiens chevronnés; Édith Arvisais, Joseph Bellerose, Yannick Chapdelaine, Isabelle Guérard et Mariane Lamarre. Karine Galarneau est de nouveau à la barre des costumes et des décors, Anne-Marie Rodrigue Lecours à l'éclairage, Benoît Finley à la musique originale et Sonia Montagne à la régie et assistance à la mise en scène. Une équipe de rêve! C'est un projet qui est inspiré du milieu dans lequel l'auteur a grandi; l'industrie de la foresterie. story:
UPDATE: THANK YOU FOR HELPING US REACH OUR GOAL! With 40 donors and a fully funded campaign, we feel confident going to NYC to perform. However, this funding campaign is only about 40% of our project expenses. Our stretch goals help to pay for:

  • Transportation expenses
  • A HOMETOWN PERFORMANCE in Blacksburg, VA at the ROCK THE BLOCKS Festival -- we'd love to perform at home!
  • Additional technical assistance from crew members who are FELLOW HOKIES!


Help to empower an ensemble of emerging artists mount an original performance in New York City. A LIST OF IRRATIONAL FEARS FOR FUTURE LEADERS OF THE WORLD is presented as a part of Critical Point Theatre's inaugural season and is the first full-length play from Andrew Terrance Kaberline.

WHO ARE WE?

Critical Point Theatre was founded by young people with nothing but gumption and our relationships as peers. Essentially, our purpose is to create innovative, original performances by consistently working together as artists while we mature and grow. We believe in social and economic justice, and this viewpoint guides the work that we select. We want to engage peers in the performance field and neighbors in our community to join with us in this action. We think that live arts can truly make an impact in the conversations our communities are having around vital issues.

Our mission: We are inventors at our core. We seek to take in stories unknown, combine them with vision and action, and bring these experiences to life through performance. Our ensemble strives to pair our own development with that of changing communities. We want to stand among and between states of matter to explore beyond boundaries.

We produce all of our shows independently, financing only from collective donations from individuals like you. It's next to impossible for artists without a long business history and legal help to obtain large grants, so we rely on small, grassroots funding campaigns like this one in order to get our work from page to stage.

Learn more at criticalpointtheatre.com!

WHY PERFORM A LIST OF IRRATIONAL FEARS FOR FUTURE LEADERS OF THE WORLD?

We feel very passionately about generational norms about perception, weakness, mental health, and the twentysomething "failure to launch." Developed over two years of drafts, FEARS is Andrew Terrance Kaberline's attempt to wrestle with his feelings on these subjects.

In the play, over 11 years, Kenrick and Jorja learn to live together while selfishly destroying the scary unknown that is post-grad life, in a dark investigation about the power of fear, the state of trust in a youthful world, and the inane mental response to tragedy.

This is the first of (hopefully many) Critical Point Theatre's original productions. We consider it central to our mission to empower artists to create new work, and this production falls squarely in line with that goal.

WHY SHOULD I DONATE?

We've been accepted to the FRIGID NYC Festival in New York. To get there from where we live in Virginia, we'll have a lot of touring costs associated with the production. Critical Point Theatre is reliant on individual donations to make this happen as a small grassroots organization. That's why we need YOU, whether you donate $1 or $100!

Each donation counts towards getting live performance on stage. Your support will go directly to:

  • Paying our artists and actors
  • Creating a compelling scenic environment for the performance
  • Travel costs such as lodging and transportation
  • Generating publicity materials so the show might have a greater impact

HOW CAN I SEE THE SHOW?

We will have a hometown performance in mid-March in Blacksburg, Virginia for all who are local. 

Our performances run from February 22nd through March 1st at various times during the FRIGID New York festival. More information can be found on the FRIGID website. We will be performing in the historic Kraine Theater on 85 E. 4th Street in the East Village.

Show times:
FEB 22 - 6:50 PM
FEB 23 - 12:30 PM
FEB 24 - 7:05 PM
FEB 25 - 10:15 PM
FEB 27 - 5:30 PM
MAR 1 - 3:40 PM

Full price tickets for all performances will be only $10 -- we want to make this show as accessible to people as possible. This is a great deal for a play in downtown Manhattan, so bring your friends!

WE WANT TO INVOLVE YOU!

We understand that not everybody can contribute financially, but you CAN still help contribute to Critical Point Theatre's ensemble. If you're looking to get involved, here are a few suggestions:

  • Can you envision collaboration with your workplace or business? We'd love to help you with our skills as storytellers and artists in exchange for advertising space, goods or services, etc. Let us know how we can help!
  • Are you an artist? We're looking for theatre artists and passionate community members to join us in our adventure. Please get in touch!
  • Want to give us some advice? As emerging artists, we're looking for all of the artistic, financial, and legal advice we can get. If you have access to any of these resources and would be willing to help, we'd appreciate it!

AND MOST OF ALL, SPREAD THE WORD

  • Visit our website
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter
Let your friends and family know about our work!

Are you an artist? We're looking for theatre artists and passionate community members to join us in our adventure. Please get in touch!


Want to give us some advice? As emerging artists, we're looking for all of the artistic, financial, and legal advice we can get. If you have access to any of these resources and would be willing to help, we'd appreciate it!

AND MOST OF ALL, SPREAD THE WORD

story:
INSIDE: From Bucharest to NYC

An international collaboration and performance intervention created for two audience members at a time that uncovers the hidden faces of well know places.

Last May PopUP traveled to Madrid to launch our third concept: INSIDE at the glamorous InterContinental. The scheme was to give audience members the opportunity to enter into familiar territory while granting unprecedented access to unseen spaces within the location. Audience members traveled in pairs through hidden spaces of a familiar location while stumbling upon situations in which they are privy to the internal thoughts and motivations of the characters surrounding them -and all this--through a voice INSIDE their own heads! It was a phenomenal success with audiences and critics alike and now....

This May we have been granted access to one of the leading museums of popular arts and traditions IN ALL OF EUROPE Muzeul National al Taranului Roman. We will produce our site specific collaboration to be inspired by and performed in one of the best museums in all of Bucharest and created by local and international teams of playwrights and directors.

Then, this Winter, we will come back home to intervene a very special iconic location in New York City. 

Joining us will be 4 additional international and local playwrights and directors plus an ensemble of a dozen local actors who will help us to create, write and rehearse the interlinking stories and promenade theatrical in just 14 days before premier!

You can join us too as we embark on our official second season after a whirlwind, world wide 2013 inaugural season that took us from The Gershwin Hotel in New York City to The InterContinental in Madrid, Summerhall in Edinburgh and The Biennal de Arte Joven in Buenos Aires. You helped us get around the world now you can help us get back home!

Who are we?

We are PopUP Theatrics,  a partnership between theatre artists Tamilla Woodard, Ana Margineanu and producing associate Molly Morris.  PopUp Theatrics’ mission is to create site-specific/site impacting theatrical events in dynamic collaborations with theatre artists world wide. In 2013 we made Long Distance Affair, a performance created and performed entirely via skype, collaborating with over 80 artists in 30 countries. LDA performed with rave reviews and sold out houses in New York City, Mexico, Edinburgh and Buenos Aires.  Also, The Window, performed in New York City, received 4 New York Innovative Theatre Awards in 2013, including Best Ensemble.

PopUP’s newest concept for international collaboration, INSIDE, premiered this summer in Madrid and was a collaboration between PopUP Theatrics, Metatarso Teatro Contemporánio and The Cross Border Project. 

El Pais raved:

"If theatre is already three dimensional, this is like a leap to the forth dimension!"

 

What We Need & What You Get!

Our 2014-2015 season is underway, with a strong focus on bringing INSIDE to Bucharest and NYC and we need your help! PopUP Theatrics has a history of producing innovative concepts that are ambitious in scope with almost zero budget. Even the $5000 we hope to raise through this campaign won’t cover all our budget. But it will make possible our plane tickets, accommodation for the 3 international artists and the hire of local support staff. We need to buy costumes, props and the necessary technology (those clever devices that create the INSIDE voices in our audiences ear) for the show.

Your 10 dollars will buy us a prop, $50 will get us two of the 12 mobile devices we need in the performance, $100 will pay for the flyers, $500 helps with renting an apartment in Bucharest.   

In return, we’ve thought of really cool perks you can access even if you don’t live in Bucharest or NYC. Starting in Bucharest in May we are going to blog, post pictures and videos daily and weekly.  You’ll get to know the whole team of amazing international and local artists we’re working with.  You'll feel as if you're virtually right there with us. We are also going to thank you on Facebook and Twitter and our website...a lot!  

The funding from this campaign will go towards the production in Bucharest, as well as the production in NYC.  As a bonus to our supporters we will double the perks by sending each from Bucharest and New York.  Double the return on your donation by helping fund both productions!  

Please share the word!

Not everyone can be active financially, but everyone can be involved! So if you can't contribute now please consider making a bit of noise about our show and this campaign.  Like our campaign on IndieGogo and Facebook, post this link to your Facebook profile or twitter feed!  Tell ALL your friends and most importantly, come see us at a PopUP theatrical in Bucharest or NYC this season!

story:
Our main goals are:

  • Starting an Irish dance kids academy in Sofia
  • Getting more kids to dance
  • Giving everybody an opportunity to learn the Irish dance, to improve and grow in their Irish dance skills
  • Drawing more attention to the Irish dance, art and culture in Bulgaria, and the Balkans
  • Strengthening the cultural connections between Ireland and Bulgaria

The dance workshop will be separated in three days as follows:

  • 3 hours only for kids
  • 3 hours for beginners (all ages) in Irish dance
  • 6 hours of dancing and teaching for advanced dancers in mixed levels - primary, intermediate, open
  • Breandán de Gallai will give a lecture about Irish dance and his work experience on the last day of the workshop.
  • End of event cocktail party

In order to hire a teacher from such a high rank and to start the Irish dance kid’s academy, we need your support. We have to cover these few things: travel costs, accommodation, tutors’ payment, dance hall fee, etc.

We are searching for a financial support to make the move happen. Please help us organize this dance workshop. The kids will be very proud and happy to be part of such an event.

More about us

“Fly into Dance” Irish Dance Academy Sofia aims to develop and spread the Irish dance and culture in Bulgaria. The teachers of the school are dancers with extensive experience and knowledge.

The Academy Sofia is part of the “Jigs & Reels” Irish Dance Academy Berlin. We give the students the opportunity to experience the magic of the dance, studying the rich palette of traditional styles. All of our dancers have the perspective to reach the stage and to take part in numerous Irish dance competitions.



About Brendan de Gallaí


Dancer, choreographer and dance academic Breandán de Gallaí’s involvement with dance is multifaceted.

As a choreographer he has created several works, most notably Noċtú and Rite of Spring. In 2011, Noċtú completely a 5-week residency at the Irish Repertory Theatre in New York. On the back of this run the show was nominated for 2 Drama Desk awards, “Outstanding Choreography” and “Unique Theatrical Event”.

His second work, Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring premiered at the opening of the Fleadh Fringe in August 2012 attracting 14,000 spectators. The work received a nomination for the coveted Allianz Business to Arts Awards (Dublin 2012).

As a dancer, Breandán toured with Riverdance from 1994 - 2003, 7 of which in the position of principal dancer. He performed in Europe, USA, Asia, Australia and New Zealand, and led the company at the opening ceremony of the World Special Olympic Games in 2003. 

Breandán’s main focus is his dance company Ériu. The company explores the poetic potential of the Irish dance form and present work that is explorative and innovative in a contemporary context. His new duet Linger, premiered in Project Arts, Dublin, January 2016.

He regularly presents TV programs for RTÉ and TG4; acts in TG4’s popular soap opera Ros na Rún; and also hold a B.Sc.(Hons) in Physics.

As a dance scholar his interest lies in the contemporisation of Irish dance. He completed a performance-based doctorate in 2013, the first of its kind in the world. His PhD in Arts Practice title is - “Imeall-Siúl: A Choreographic Exploration of Expressive Possibilities in Irish dance”. He earned an MA in Ethnochoreology in 2009, and was external examiner for the MA in Traditional Irish Dance Performance at the University of Limerick from 2004 - 2008. Breandán was acting Course Director of the Arts Practice PhD programme at the University of Limerick for 2012.

Theatrical Event”.
His second work, Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring premiered at the opening
of the Fleadh Fringe in August 2012 attracting 14,000 spectators. The work
received a nomination for the coveted Allianz Business to Arts Awards (Dublin
2012). 
As a dancer, Breandán toured with Riverdance from 1994 - 2003, 7 of which
in the position of principal dancer. He performed in Europe, USA, Asia, Australia
and New Zealand, and led the company at the opening ceremony of the World
Special Olympic Games in 2003. 
Breandán’s main focus is his dance
company Ériu. The company
explores the poetic potential of the Irish dance form and present work
that is explorative and innovative in a contemporary context. His new duet Linger, premiered in Project Arts,
Dublin, January 2016.
He regularly presents TV programs for
RTÉ and TG4; acts in TG4’s popular soap opera Ros na Rún; and also hold a B.Sc.(Hons) in Physics. 
As a dance scholar his interest lies
in the contemporisation of Irish dance. He completed a performance-based
doctorate in 2013, the first of its kind in the world. His PhD in Arts Practice
title is - “Imeall-Siúl: A Choreographic Exploration of Expressive Possibilities
in Irish dance”. He earned an MA in Ethnochoreology in 2009, and was external
examiner for the MA in Traditional Irish Dance Performance at the University of
Limerick from 2004 - 2008. Breandán was acting Course Director of the Arts
Practice PhD programme at the University of Limerick for 2012.

story:
If you've ever experienced a David Johnston play, odds are it still sits vividly in your memory: The hilarity and tenderness in BUSTED JESUS COMIX, the scathing political satire of A BUSH CAROL, the epic storytelling in his re-imagining of Aeschylus' THE ORESTEIA. You remember the sly and sophisticated psychological maneuverings in CONVERSATIONS ON RUSSIAN LITERATURE, the giddy fun of EFFIE JEAN IN TAHITI, and PLAY RUSSIA’s zany parody. You might flash back to the strip-club raunch and lyric sweetness that met and ignited, improbably, in YES YES YES, or find yourself revisiting the dingy dressing room of MOTHRA IS WAITING, David's lovesong to showbiz pluck.

David's plays are the stuff of fandom, and time and again he delivers — theater that sticks, long after the house lights are back up. And in all of the works above, and more, Blue Coyote Theater Group has been a proud producer and collaborator. We are thrilled, then, to announce that David’s newest play, CONEY, will have its world premiere in October of 2012, at the New Ohio Theatre, produced by Blue Coyote!

CONEY is a work of fierce affection, spun by one of Coney Island's most passionate aficionados. Evocative, informed, panoramic, sidesplitting and heartbreaking, CONEY is unforgettable. And unforgettable plays deserve unforgettable productions.

 

We hope that you will help us to achieve the production that CONEY deserves with a contribution to this fundraising campaign. Reaching our goal of $5,000 will insure that we can hire the top-notch team of actors, designers, and production associates we need to bring CONEY to life—in all its tawdry grandeur!—this October.

Thank you for your consideration!

Kyle Ancowitz
Robert Buckwalter
Gary Shrader
Stephen Speights

BLUE COYOTE THEATER GROUP is dedicated to producing new American plays and actively collaborating with emerging American playwrights.  BCTG is a GLAAD Media Award nominee, has been selected as one of NYTHEATRE.COM's People of the Year, and distinguished itself on TIME OUT NEW YORK's year-end "best" list. Blue Coyote is a proud member of the LOWER MANHATTAN ARTS LEAGUE and the ALLIANCE OF RESIDENT THEATERS/ NEW YORK.

story:
Our Story

Hi there! We're InterAct Story Theatre, an educational theatre company based in Maryland dedicated to bringing performing arts programs to schools and communities throughout our region.  Our merry band of artists include theatre folk, dancers and choreographers, musicians, film and video mavens, creative opera makers, and multidisciplinary artists. We specialize in "arts integration" and "applied arts": we're experts at integrating the arts with classroom instruction to meet educational goals, and we love to find ways to explore big issues through the arts. 


The project in this Indiegogo campaign is a great example of what we love to do.  Over the past year, our partners have asked us, "Can you do a program with our students that talks about bullying?" So we started a year-long investigation of how we can explore bullying through drama, and to see what all else is out there.  And one thing we discovered right away is that the issue is huge and complex, with no easy answers - since everyone's situation is different, the answers for each person is different.  So, it became really clear to us that our job isn't to provide an answer to the problem of bullying, but to open up dialogue about the issue and give kids tools and information they can use to combat bullying. With this in mind, we piloted a parent-staff-child workshop on bullying this spring and began developing workshops and residencies exploring bullying through drama.


This led us to writing Voytto Tech: a scifi fable.  This powerful new play for young audiences combines science, engineering and technology with a strong anti-bullying message.  In this play, Klipp Casey travels from a planet far, far away to study at Voytto Tech, the most famous science magnet school in the galaxy.  Right away, Klipp has trouble fitting in at his new school, and becomes a target for bullying.  What can he do? Who can he go to for help? And what can anyone do about the energy and waste problems on the planet? This interactive play is performed by two actors who become a variety of characters. The entire audience participates from their seats, becoming characters in the story and brainstorming possible solutions for Klipp's problems. 


We're really excited about this project. It's our first new play since our new artistic director Ali Oliver took the reins of the company, and it's shaping up to be a great show.  Not only is this our first new work, but it's our first multimedia project, so it's a whole new world for us as a company. We're all energized by our progress so far. We had a really successful public reading this summer, have been polishing it and revising it, and are in production and rehearsal right now.  In the video, you'll hear from several artists in the project, and catch a glimpse of a "table read" rehearsal. We have several schools already who have scheduled this show for the fall--we just need your help to make it happen and get the show on the road! 


The Impact

Your donations will help us bring theatre into schools and help us make an impact on children's lives.  Schools are clamoring for this kind of program: quality theatre for children that addresses the complex issue of bullying.  There is a real need for this in the schools, and schools have asked us to help fill this gap. We want to be able to fill this need, and we need your help to do it and do it well.


We want you to know that we will put every single penny you donate to work--whether we reach the campaign goal or not. We are committed to making Voytto Tech happen--the question is how well can we do it, and how many kids can we reach. We are working tirelessly to raise funds and find creative ways to do more for less. The more funding we can raise, the better the project and the more children we can reach thanks to your generous support. Every little bit helps, and we are so, so grateful for any help you can offer.


Every little bit helps! You'd be surprised at how far a $10 or $25 donation can go in the hands of theatre people (Or, if you're a theatre person, maybe that's not news to you). And again, we will put every dollar to work, whether or not we meet our fundraising goal. We promise!

So where's the money going?

Your dollars will help bring this powerful play to children in two important ways: 

1.  Technical equipment and know-how.  Not only are we growing and stretching into new areas of theatre, we're going multimedia for the first time.  After all, it's a play about technology and science! This is a whole new area for us as a small touring theatre company, so not only are we investing in a raft of audio/visual and electronic equipment, we are hiring folks with expertise in how to make it happen. Our crack team of tech consultants are helping us figure out how to do it as economically as possible--but it still adds up!  So, your donations will help defray these costs, so that we can put the best multimedia experience in front of the kids seeing our play.

At minimum, our multimedia costs include:

  • 37" video screen
  • Rolling hardcase for the screen
  • Power conditioner
  • Computer system/peripherals in order to run the audio and video during the performance
  • Cables, cables cables
  • Video filming/editing/production costs related to recording the audio/visual elements of the show
  • Music/sound composition/editing:  We're tickled to have a score composed by Helen Hayes award-winner Tom Teasley, and we want to do his wonderful work justice


2.  Taking it on the road.  InterActors tour just about everywhere - cities, suburbs, rural communities - and times are tough across the board.  We've seen our rural friends hit especially hard in the past year; two different school districts in our tour have seen roughly 50% cuts in funding! Sadly, the areas hit hardest by budget cuts are exactly those areas that need us the most; in some of the schools we visit, InterAct provides the only live theatre these children will see all year. And if the funds aren't there, the kids miss out.


We think that kids deserve quality theatre that really means something, and we're asking for your help to bring this play to them.  So, once our A/V costs are met, donations will go towards bringing Voytto Tech to schools and communities who otherwise would have little or no access to live theatre. 

These costs include:

  • Personnel costs: we have a great group of pros working on this production.  The tour itself includes two professional actors who handle everything on the road from transportation to set up to strike. This on top of performing their parts!
  • Transportation expenses: gas, vehicle costs, tolls, etc.
  • Hotel and food for the actors while they're on the road; we try to keep costs down, so we can maximize your donation dollars.

What do you get for your donation?

All donations made to this project are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law, thanks to sponsorship by Fractured Atlas.  Plus, there are perks for each level of contribution, ranging from shout-outs and acknowledgements to nifty InterAct gifts and more.  Donors at the top level will receive exclusive, limited-supply items like a CD by Tom Teasley (the composer of Voytto Tech's music) and a video of Voytto Tech with exclusive bonus material. 


We'll be giving shout-outs by Facebook, Twitter and our own website. If you've got a Twitter handle, please be sure to let us know, so we can give you a proper mention. Thanks!

How else can you help?

We would just love it if you could help us get the word out about this campaign.  There are lots of easy ways to get the word out. Indiegogo has these great 'share tools' that let you send a link around or paste this info into Facebook, Twitter, etc.  Please help us get the word out - the more we raise, the better the project and the more children we can reach!

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

We know that there are lots of ways to spend your time and money, and whether you donate to our campaign or not, we'd like to thank you for spending the time to learn about our project.  If you have any questions, please feel free to post it in the comments, or to drop us a line.


Thanks!

InterAct Story Theatre

Facebook:  InterAct Story Theatre

Twitter: @InterActStory

web: www.interactstory.com

story:
OUR PRODUCTION 

 

Mind The Gap Theatre Company and fandango 4 productions will be presenting THE WORLD IS MY CHEESECAKE: 7 Short Plays of Memory, Loss, Memory Loss, Love, Fate, Death & Marriage by Award-Winning Playwright Daniel Damiano, to run at the WorkShop’s Jewel Box Space, 312 West 36th St (4th Fl), from Sept. 6th through 17th, for 10 shows only.

 

Mind The Gap Theatre Company (coming off their recent smash success Under the Blue Sky - Backstage Critics Pick) and fandango 4 productions (2-time MITF Award Nominee for last summer's The Hyenas Got It Down) present THE WORLD IS MY CHEESECAKE - an unforgettable evening of 7 unrelated short plays by Award-Winning Playwright Daniel Damiano (2004 Wolk Award Winner, Silver Stage Award Winner, OOBR Critics Choice Award, 2-Time Playwrights First Award Finalist). The plays blend the surreal, the absurd and the outlandish with biting social commentary, culminating in a funny, moving and thought-provoking evening of theatre . 

 

Starring the wonderfully talented Judy Alvarez, Sue Glausen, Emma Gordon, Richard Kent Green*, Kate Greer*, Michael Janove*, Justin Herfel*, DH Johnson*, Simon Pearl*, George Stavropoulos, Stuart Williams, & Anna Emily Wood. 

 

Directed by Paula D'Alessandris, Daniel Damiano & Stephanie Staes.

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

 

In helping us achieve our goal of making this ambitious production a true reality, we’re asking for some blessed assistance. Mind you, this is not our entire budget we’re looking for, but just a portion of what will ease our fiscal strain. We know that times are tough and money is tight, but we also know that it is the Theatre that has the greatest power to manifest the world’s adversity into something powerful, creative & thought-provoking. So if you a have a few bucks to throw our merry way, this will help us greatly towards the costs for rehearsal spaces, actor stipends, insurance, advertisements and various other theatrical accoutrements which will make our ship sail proudly. And we'll thank you like heck for it!

 

Mind the Gap is a 501(c)3 non-profit, which means your donation is fully tax-deductible!

 

*Actors Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity.

 

For complete show schedule, photos, and other juicy CHEESECAKE-related stuff, visit our website at www.fandango4.blogspot.com.

story:
What

  • I wrote a play about a funny and complicated man: W.C. Fields.  So far audiences love it. 
  • Now determined to tour the play all across America.
  • Created the Make'em Laugh Project as a companion project.  
  • In every town and city, and at no charge, W.C. will go to Children's Cancer Centers, Senior Homes, Hospice, and other such facilities to bring laughter to those less fortunate. No face will be left unsmiling.  
  • My wife and I don't have the money to finance it.

About Dale

The fire doesn't go out just because old-man-hood catches up to you.  The fire burns harder, hotter, it rages, it demands, it's relentless, and it won't go away.

I've been an actor for 38 years; a member of the Screen Actors' Guild (SAG) for 20 years and Actors' Equity Association (AEA) for almost 10 years.  Along the way I made a few movies (held Jack Nicholson's arm for a few seconds in Hoffa), appeared on a few TV programs (yeah, had a trailer with my name on it), and had the great good fortune to perform on stage with wonderful actors in many different states, and in some productions that I wrote.  I've written 20 plays.  Two or three are pretty good.  W.C. Fields By Himself! is the best.

In the early years, along with my acting, I was a professional property manager, running residential housing complexes in California, Illinois, Indiana, and Pennsylvania.  For 10 years, ending in 2010, I owned and managed the 6th@Penn Theatre (later Compass Theatre) in San Diego.  The economy forced us out, but we were able to find another theatre company to take the space.

I'm married to Jamie and we live in Santee, CA.  She's been a student counselor for 30 years at UCSD and I long for the day she can retire, and we tour theatres across the country in my play W.C. Fields By Himself!  We have two adopted mutts from the pound, and a black and white cat that terrorizes them both.

What We’ve Done Where We’re At

  • See the Gallery Page for timeline.
  • We have a completed budget for the first two tour stops that his campaign will fund.

The Goal The Plan The Get’n There

  • Goal 1.  To make a living and to provide jobs for others by introducing the play W.C. Fields By Himself! to playhouse audiences all across America.
  • Goal 2.  To bring happiness and joy to those in Children’s Hospitals, Senior Care Home, Hospice, and other such facilities at no charge with the Make’em Laugh Project.  Leaving no face without a smile on it.
  • Goal 3.  To get the show on the road, raise the minimum funds necessary to mount the show in two locations: a small playhouse in Los Angeles, CA and a larger venue in Arizona or New Mexico. Places that have an abundance of the demograhic we need: Seniors and an older general population.  These theatre spaces need to be reserved months in advance.  One in particular I'm studying and corresponding with is the Mesa Arts Center in Mesa, AZ.  They have shown a willingness to negotiate their rental fees.  
  • Goal 4.  Raise the money to make it all happen on Indiegogo by moving people to share my dream.

Why This Campaign is Important To Me

Writing and performing as W.C. Fields is the best idea I've ever had in my life.  And it came at a time when I needed it most.  With just Social Security, this project will allow me to continue to make a living, while creating jobs for at least three other people as we travel: two additional actors and one stage technician.  And as a success it will bring revenue to the stages we rent, the restaurants we eat at, the facilities where we stay, and bring laughter to those that need it.

The W.C. Fields Project, which includes the theatrical production W.C. Fields By Himself!, and the Make'em Laugh Project!, under the auspices of which we plan to go to Children's Cancer Centers, Senior Facilities, Hospice, and others to introduce W.C. Fields and his cohorts to those that are in need of joy and laughter.  In every city we go to, and at no charge, we will seek out such facilities and offer our services.  And we guarantee that no face will go without smiling!

Once Funded

  • We will firm up the first two tour stops and get ready to go.
  • We will keep you informed all along the way.

What you mean to us

We hope you find some magic in the name W.C. Fields.  Our experience shows us audiences will.  We just have to go to them with a good evenings worth of entertainment and we'll be successful.

As a senior citizen I find the advent of sites like Indiegogo an amazement.  I have operated a non-profit organization for over ten-years.  I know what fundraising to friends and family and patrons of the arts is like.  They hide when they see me coming.  Oh, they will still help me on this campaign, but there is no hope to touring the W.C. Fields show, and bringing laughter to hospitals and care facilities without your help.  Aside from our perks I can only promise this.  In every town we go to, and at every opportunity, we will seek out and destroy sadness in the only way we know how.  Make'em Laugh!

I'm happy to answer any questions.  dmorris466@gmail.com 

What Else Could You Do?

To save hotel and food bills we hope to travel in a Motor Home.  Small, large, new, old, if you have one you'd like to donate we would love to have it.  San Diego Theatre Scene, Inc - the producing organization behind our show, is a 501 (c3) Nonprofit Organization.  Your gift would be tax deductable.

What

I wrote a play about a funny and complicated man: W.C. Fields.  So far audiences love it. 
Now determined to tour the play all across America.
Created the Make'em Laugh Project as a companion project.  
In every town and city, and at no charge, W.C. will go to Children's Cancer Centers, Senior Homes, Hospice, and other such facilities to bring laughter to those less fortunate. No face will be left unsmiling.  
My wife and I don't have the money to finance it.
About Dale
The fire doesn't go out just because old-man-hood catches up to you.  The fire burns harder, hotter, it rages, it demands, it's relentless, and it won't go away.I've been an actor for 38 years; a member of the Screen Actors' Guild (SAG) for 20 years and Actors' Equity Association (AEA) for almost 10 years.  Along the way I made a few movies (held Jack Nicholson's arm for a few seconds in Hoffa), appeared on a few TV programs (yeah, had a trailer with my name on it), and had the great good fortune to perform on stage with wonderful actors in many different states, and in some productions that I wrote.  I've written 20 plays.  Two or three are pretty good.  W.C. Fields By Himself! is the best.In the early years, along with my acting, I was a professional property manager, running residential housing complexes in California, Illinois, Indiana, and Pennsylvania.  For 10 years, ending in 2010, I owned and managed the 6th@Penn Theatre (later Compass Theatre) in San Diego.  The economy forced us out, but we were able to find another theatre company to take the space.I'm married to Jamie and we live in Santee, CA.  She's been a student counselor for 30 years at UCSD and I long for the day she can retire, and we tour theatres across the country in my play W.C. Fields By Himself!  We have two adopted mutts from the pound, and a black and white cat that terrorizes them both.
What We’ve Done Where We’re At


See the Gallery Page for timeline.
We have a completed budget for the first two tour stops that his campaign will fund.

The Goal The Plan The Get’n There



Goal 1.  To make a living and to provide jobs for others by introducing the play W.C. Fields By Himself! to playhouse audiences all across America.


Goal 2.  To bring happiness and joy to those in Children’s Hospitals, Senior Care Home, Hospice, and other such facilities at no charge with the Make’em Laugh Project.  Leaving no face without a smile on it.


Goal 3.  To get the show on the road, raise the minimum funds necessary to mount the show in two locations: a small playhouse in Los Angeles, CA and a larger venue in Arizona or New Mexico. Places that have an abundance of the demograhic we need: Seniors and an older general population.  These theatre spaces need to be reserved months in advance.  One in particular I'm studying and corresponding with is the Mesa Arts Center in Mesa, AZ.  They have shown a willingness to negotiate their rental fees.  

Goal 4.  Raise the money to make it all happen on Indiegogo by moving people to share my dream.
Why This Campaign is Important To Me
Writing and performing as W.C. Fields is the best idea I've ever had in my life.  And it came at a time when I needed it most.  With just Social Security, this project will allow me to continue to make a living, while creating jobs for at least three other people as we travel: two additional actors and one stage technician.  And as a success it will bring revenue to the stages we rent, the restaurants we eat at, the facilities where we stay, and bring laughter to those that need it.The W.C. Fields Project, which includes the theatrical production W.C. Fields By Himself!, and the Make'em Laugh Project!, under the auspices of which we plan to go to Children's Cancer Centers, Senior Facilities, Hospice, and others to introduce W.C. Fields and his cohorts to those that are in need of joy and laughter.  In every city we go to, and at no charge, we will seek out such facilities and offer our services.  And we guarantee that no face will go without smiling!
Once Funded

We will firm up the first two tour stops and get ready to go.
We will keep you informed all along the way.
What you mean to us
We hope you find some magic in the name W.C. Fields.  Our experience shows us audiences will.  We just have to go to them with a good evenings worth of entertainment and we'll be successful.As a senior citizen I find the advent of sites like Indiegogo an amazement.  I have operated a non-profit organization for over ten-years.  I know what fundraising to friends and family and patrons of the arts is like.  They hide when they see me coming.  Oh, they will still help me on this campaign, but there is no hope to touring the W.C. Fields show, and bringing laughter to hospitals and care facilities without your help.  Aside from our perks I can only promise this.  In every town we go to, and at every opportunity, we will seek out and destroy sadness in the only way we know how.  Make'em Laugh!
I'm happy to answer any questions.  dmorris466@gmail.com 
What Else Could You Do?
To save hotel and food bills we hope to travel in a Motor Home.  Small, large, new, old, if you have one you'd like to donate we would love to have it.  San Diego Theatre Scene, Inc - the producing organization behind our show, is a 501 (c3) Nonprofit Organization.  Your gift would be tax deductable.

story:
These funds will be used to pay the dancers and designers for their work this summer.This show is the result of a two-year process of investigation and development which has been funded up until now by Pepsi Cola,Goldman Sachs, the Bossak Heilbron Foundation, DNA commissioning funds, private donors, TSD board and an Artist Residency at the Galapagos Art Space. We need this additional kick to get us to the finish line-THE SHOW!

Known for finding “the human soul in exacting, abstract movement” (Eva Yaa Asantewaa), Stronach and her company present a program that includes the world premiere of duet Me and Not Me, a reimagining of Stronach’s acclaimed solo Mother Tongue, and the first showing of a work-in-progress quartet.  Stronach teams up with the highly seasoned dancers Lindsey Dietz Marchant, Darrin Wright and Denisa Musilova and visionary designers Jane Shaw (sound), Deb O (costume and sets), David Tirosh (video design) and Bessie Award-winning lighting designer Joe Levasseur. Don't miss it!
