story:
I love going to the movies. It helps me escape, imagine, feel, learn, and laugh. I love that what I might find inspiring, someone else might find tasteless. What I might perhaps find funny, someone else might find offensive. What I might find personally transformational, someone else might decide is just fluff.  You get my point. So in the Fall of 2012, after moving back to NYC from LA and leaving behind friendships, my job, and everything that had made me feel comfortable I found myself asking “now what”? I felt alone and directionless, and I sought comfort in my old friend “the movies” to keep me company and help me escape. I couldn't decide where to begin so I figured I'd rely on the so called “experts” and took on tackling the American Film Institute’s Greatest 100 American Films of All Time. To my surprise, I didn't lose myself, nor did I escape. Why? Because somewhere along the journey I became frustrated by some of the choices on the list. How was it possible that some of my favorite movies were nowhere to be found? How could some of these films on the list actually be called “the greatest of all time?” The answer was simple. Movies are art. Art is subjective. Every person is unique and has their own filters and perspective and that is when I realized that I don’t believe in “best of” lists. 

But I also realized that I suddenly felt incredibly inspired and my creative juices began to percolate. After watching film after film in rapid succession, something began to happen. AFI's list began to take on a life of it's own inside my head and all the films began to blend into one. And so I set out on a mission to stitch-together the most absurd parody of "the greatest 100 American movies" chosen from the list. I wanted to create a hilarious evening of theatre, touching on a large well known body of work much like The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged)had so brilliantly done. It's taken nearly two years, countless rewrites, endless amounts of caffeine, laughter, headaches, and conviction. I've heard it come to life a few times with table reads thanks to the incredible support of fellow artists who have in some way, shape or form lent either their talent or insight into helping see my play to come to life. 

What if I asked you to close your eyes and imagine what Star Wars would have been like if Katherine Hepburn had been offered to play Princess Leia?  Or if Jimmy Stewart had played Oskar Schindler? Keep them closed and imagine Bonnie and Clyde in Bedford-Stuyvesant Brooklyn on the hottest day of summer about to rob the local pizza parlor in a very Pulp Fiction kind of way. Did those images get your imagination running wild?  Welcome to a quick glimpse of the crazy place that is my brain and what you might expect to see live on stage with The List.

And although I wish I had the scruples of, say, Butch Cassidy and The Sundance Kid or even Bonnie and Clyde, I am setting out to raise money the good old fashioned way, through asking kind folks such as yourself to help contribute and help me realize this dream. There will be no stick-ups or guns involved, I promise. You see, putting up a show in NYC is not easy. To get a show produced in NYC doesn't take the west village but rather an entire island.  There are so many costs associated with getting a play up and running. I've been able to finance some of it on my own, but this show deserves a world-class world premiere and I can’t do that alone! So if you, like me, love art, believe in individuality, and the power of the movies and the theater…please help me make my dream come true! There is no donation too big or too small. And if you can't financially donate, that's okay, there are still other ways that you can help and still make a difference: by simply sharing this link with your friends and colleagues, you help me get the word out there.  Who knows- perhaps someone YOU know is the one that gets me to my fundraising goal! And The List is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, the leading arts fundraising service non-profit. Charitable contributions for "The List"  are tax‐deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

What I Need & What You Get

So here is the deal. To produce this show and give it the premiere it deserves (hint: it deserves the kind of premiere and run that raises eyebrows and the interest of the Off-Broadway community!) it will take roughly $25,000. You wouldn't believe how even an arguably simple show like this one really requires all the aspects of a bigger production. Below are just a few of the costs categories associated with getting the show up and running (all at a fraction of the market rate given how committed my cast and crew is to making this project a reality!) 

•  Casting Director

•  Cast

•  Designers

•  Crew

•  Rehearsal Space

•  Set

•  Costumes, Wigs, Props

•  Marketing

•  Insurance/Fees

And that's only scratching the surface!

Now what happens if I can't raise all the money? Well, having produced several independent features and short films, I know first hand the chaos that ensues when fundraising goals are at risk and the relentlessness it takes to stay focused and meet the deadline of getting the show produced no matter what. If I fall short, I do have some contingencies and certain elements of the show will not be able to be fully realized and artistic sacrifices will be made. I'll have to rework the budget and call in even MORE favors from cast and crew. I'm hoping to not have to do this, but we will not know the answers to those questions until the 30 days from fundraising are up. I am hoping for the best and I am going to work at this harder than I ever have. This show will be produced at all costs with your contributions. I am a creative guy, and I've done this before...the show will go on!

In the past, I've been fortunate enough to have been involved with successful projects like the independent films Weather Girl and 6 Month Rule.  I also know what it's like to put my mind to something and stop at nothing to win which is how I was able to succeed on the reality show Thintervention with Jackie Warner.I am in this to win this, people!

If you have read all of this I appreciate it :) Think about it, and in the meantime, whether you can contribute a lot, or nothing but your love, go ahead and like our page on Facebook.  http://on.fb.me/1qVVkr7

SO WHO ARE THE CHARACTERS ASSOCIATED WITH THE LIST?

Bryan T. Donovan (WRITER/PRODUCER) is a New York based actor/writer/producer with a career that spans stage, film, and television. On Broadway, Bryan has been seen in Wrong Mountain (Eugene O’Neill Theatre) and several Encores! City Center productions, and Off-Broadway/regionally at the Vineyard, Playwrights Horizons, Carnegie Hall, ACT, Goodspeed Opera House, among others, and has studied with The Groundlings and Upright Citizens Brigade. In addition to performing, Bryan has produced several independent features and short films that have premiered at Slamdance, SXSW, LAFF, Outfest (LA) and other festivals.Bryan is best known in television for spilling and shedding his gut in the reality television series, Thintervention with Jackie Warner on Bravo, as well as roles in Boardwalk Empire, Blue Bloods, Law and Order, and Medium. 

Regan Adair (DIRECTOR) most recently directed the 2013 regional premier of Neil LaBute's In A Forest, Dark And Deep in Dallas, Tx. Other regional credits include; The critically acclaimed Red Light Winter for Second Thought Theatre, Talk Radio for Upstart Theatre Co. In 2005-2006, he served as Artistic Director for Richardson Theatre Center, where he helmed productions of Verdict, Blithe Spirit, Misery , Les Liasons Dangereuses (which the Dallas Observer and Dallas Voice awarded one of the Top Ten Best Productions of 2005), Wait Until Dark, and The Unexpected Guest. Regan has also directed reginaol productions of The Underpants, The Normal Heart (with Uptown Players, which was named one of the Top Ten Productions of 2006 by the Ft. Worth Star Telegram) and Every Trick in the Book (with Classical Acting Company, which also garnered honors as one of the Top Ten Best Productions of 2006 by both the Dallas Observer and the Dallas Voice).

Elizabeth R. English (LINE PRODUCER) produced Human Fruit Bowl at FringeNYC 2013 (WINNER: Best of the Fringe for Solo Performance and Best Short Script) and has presented nationally and internationally, including; REDCAT (LA), Highways Performance Space (Santa Monica), Women’s Project, terraNOVA Collective, Ars Nova, HERE Arts, and at the Edinburgh Fringe. 

Michael Fitzgerald (PRODUCTION DESIGNER) is a production designer who uses his visual heart and his theatrical background to make compelling stories come alive. His credits include Without Men with Eva Longoria and Christian Slater, Blayne Weaver's romantic comedies 6 Month Rule and Weather Girl, and Jordan Robert’s wacky and irreverent 1.2.3. Frankie Go Boom with Ron Pearlman, Charlie Hunnam, Lizzy Caplan, and Chris O’Dowd. More recently he worked on Darren Stein's GBF, The Last Five Years starring Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan, as well as Life of a King starring Cuba Gooding Jr. He was also the puppeteer and set designer for the Creeps reenactments.

Curtis Craig (SOUND DESIGNER AND COMPOSER) His sound & media design for Gizmo was recently selected for exhibition at the 2013 World Stage Design expo in Cardiff, Wales; prior to that, in 2009, his composition and sound design work for Pentecost was was awarded the gold medal in sound design at the World Stage Design exposition in Seoul, South Korea. He currently serves as the Commissioner of Sound Design for the United States Institute for Theater Technology. He is also an active freelance sound designer & composer, as well as the head of the undergraduate sound design program at Penn State University. In addition to sound design, he also works and teaches in the areas of media design and show control. His design and composition work can be seen and heard on his website at www.soniclandscape.net. His work has recently been seen and heard at the Clarence Brown Theater, Dallas Theater Center, Watertower Theatre, Arkansas Rep, and Pennsylvania Centre Stage. 

Natalie Robin (LIGHTING DESIGNER) is a NYC-based lighting designer of theater, opera, dance, music and performance art. She is the associate producer of American Realness, a festival of contemporary performance curated by Ben Pryor. She is a founding company member of Polybe + Seats and an Associate Artist of Target Margin Theater. She is also an adjunct faculty member at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts Department of Undergraduate Drama. Natalie is the winner of the Apollo Lighting 2011 Standing O Award and was chosen as a 2008 Young Designer to Watch by Live Design Magazine. She was nominated for the Rolex Mentors and Protégés Arts Initiative.  In 2009 and 2010, she participated in the Lincoln Center Directors Lab and has been a guest artist at Williams, Bard and Muhlenberg Colleges. Natalie was an adjunct faculty member at CUNY/Brooklyn College in 2013. Natalie is a contributing writer to Live Design Magazine and Stage Directions. Natalie also tours as a lighting supervisor and production manager for Miguel Gutierrez and the Powerful People. BA: Columbia. MFA: NYU/Tisch Notably, Natalie designed The Bad and the Better, directed by Daniel Aukin; made her regional theater design debut at Dallas Theater Center; and designed myendlesslove choreographed by Miguel Gutierrez, and 13 Love Songs: dot dot dot, created and performed by Ishmael Houston-Jones and Emily Wexler. She is currently designing The Craft of the Father by Levi Gonzalez at the Chocolate Factory and Poetry 2014: Birth of a Hip-Hop Nation for the Brooklyn Academy of Music.                                    

Benjamin A. Klemes (COSTUME DESIGNER) Design: One Row Over, Mickey and the Bear (NYU Gallatin), Blonde (Short Film). Assistant Design: Ragtime (NYU Tisch), The Mystery of Edwin Drood (NYU New Studio), Antigone (NYU Gallatin). Internship experience: Metropolitan Opera, Damn Yankees (Goodspeed Musicals), Metropolitan Museum of Art (Costume Institute), American Ballet Theatre. BA: NYU.

Studio), Antigone (NYU Gallatin). Internship experience: Metropolitan Opera,
Damn Yankees (Goodspeed Musicals), Metropolitan Museum of Art (Costume
Institute), American Ballet Theatre. BA: NYU.

story:
Who is Lisa Engelken?!

Hello from Denver! My name is Lisa Engelken and I am a dancer, performer, teacher, community activist, and cultural enthusiast. I am currently an apprentice for the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble in Denver, CO.  I love being a part of this modern dance family that is so dedicated to social change and community action. Most recently, I have had the pleasure of collaborating with dancers from Zimbabwe and Cuba and have had the chance to train in San Francisco and Buenos Aires, Argentina. I will also take the stage this month with the premiere company, Black Listed, in the self-titled multi-media production of an exploration of healing through the arts.  
I feel so blessed and full to have this dance community in Denver and I also feel it is time for me to spread my wings into my next adventure which is why I am going to the American Dance Festival this June! I need your help to make it possible! By attending ADF, I will spend six weeks exploring new dance genres, companies, auditioning, and expanding my network nationally and abroad. This is truly my next step in achieving my dream of seeing and healing the world through the power of movement. 
How you can help!

This past February, I attended the International Association of Blacks in Dance Conference, where I was awarded a partial scholarship to ADF. I still have the expenses of half-tuition, travel, housing/board, and dance supplies. Here's the break down:

•Tuition: $900

•Housing/Board: $250/$850 (found an awesome family who I will dog sit for while they are in China)

•Travel: $400

Total Estimated Cost: $2400

I have set my fundraising goal for $1500, which of course I will be ecstatic to exceed. 4% of my raised money will go back to Indie Gogo for their assistance! 

Thank you for your time, love and support!

In contributing to this summer program, the impact on my dance career and life will surpass just a six week program. I truly believe that this summer is the beginning of a new chapter in my life. I will be using this opportunity as a launch ing pad for the rest of my life. It has always been my dream to move out of my home town of Denver and to impact the greater world. After traveling to Kenya my sophomore year of college, my soul was fed and called to be among other cultures and to exchange our experience of being human. To me, dance truly is the universal language. Through all of my international experiences, it has been the key to connecting with other people and for feeling fulfillment in life. Even if you can give $5, it will make a difference. Thank you!

story:
What we're doing.

The World Premiere of GHOST BIKE, by Laura Jacqmin, presented by Buzz22 Chicago as our fourth year Mainstage.

The story.

Ora and Eddie fell in love with Chicago on their bikes. But when Eddie is hit by a car and killed, Ora refuses to let him go. Instead, she rides beneath our city to bring him back, facing off against underworld gods and ghosts -some interested in helping her, some determined to get in her way. The more difficult her journey becomes, the more Ora must question what it is she's journeying towards. In Ghost Bike, Chicago culture skitches off of Greek, African, and Chinese mythology, sparking a spirited mash-up of underworld and after-life as seen from the seats of fixies, BMX's and ten-speeds.

Why we're doing it.

Buzz22 Chicago stages stories to explore the constant coming of age: the ever-occurring moments that challenge who we are and who we want to be.

In Laura Jacqmin's GHOST BIKE, a young woman challenges her destiny.  Set in and below our city, this play explores one route to follow when fate robs you of your plans.   Told with humor, depth and unique imagery Buzz22 immediately jumped at the opportunity to explore this challenging new play.  

Why you should help.

GHOST BIKE is a show near and dear to Chicago and our company. Your donation will directly help us produce this show - from building custom bikes to creating an entire underworld. Support a huge show, told in an intimate and exciting way featuring an ensemble of fearless performers and the talent of some of Chicago's best designers...and did we mention this show happens mostly on bikes?! We couldn't be more grateful to you for helping us fully realize this story. 


More info at: buzz22chicago.com

The video.

Original artwork: Artistic Associate Alex Tey

Original music: Matt Deitchman

Special thanks to: Josh Kahn, Thea Lux & Aurora Adachi-Winter

The deets.

GHOST BIKE by Laura Jacqmin

Greenhouse Theater Center 2257 N Lincoln, Chicago IL 60614

Previews: March 8 and 9

Run: March 13-April 6

Tickets: http://greenhousetheater.org/portfolio/ghost-bike/

story:
Short Summary

Two Worlds is dedicated to the craft of performing arts expressing the duality of the contemporary American Indian through drama, comedy, storytelling and immersive theater. We Reclaim our Identity through Live Performance for our past, present, and future Native Communities. Guided by shared Native experiences, we strive to develop ways of telling our stories through honest and creative expression.

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous donation to our Indiegogo campaign will help us to continue our Two Worlds’ Mission by developing job opportunities in the arts, empowering and celebrating our identity and voice, and producing work for and by Native and Indigenous artists. 

The Impact

Our ensemble has and will continue to discover and give voice to the visions and stories of Native people around the world through touring, educating diverse communities, and providing mainstream culture with a positive representation of Native Americans in contemporary society.

Risks & Challenges

There is simply not enough we can do to promote more Native and diverse theater, both locally and Nationally. Help us share our stories with our rural and urban communities, and bring Native performing arts up to a professional level with the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow Two Worlds' on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for our upcoming performances, tour dates, and collaboration projects in 2020!

If you are interested in volunteering or applying for our Board of Directors,  please email: twoworlds.nm@gmail.com

story:
What is Click Chamber?

CLICK CHAMBER, written by Aaron Krygier and Justin Karcher, was a smash hit at the Buffalo Infringement Festival this past summer (2013) , packing houses night after night and building up a nice buzz in and around Western New York. The show was even covered nationally and featured in the Dramatist Guild Regional Report (read it here! Dramatist's Guild Tumblr)

But you ask, what is it? Well, Click Chamber is:

  • Noir - A real black, white and grey scale feel
  • A fresh, original new play, with equal parts lyricism and grit
  • A production built from the ground up with an all regional cast (Western NY)
  • Something different that isn't about the problems between mom and dad
  • Like witnessing a car crash in front of you and not being able...to look... away...


What Click Chamber Needs & What You Get

We've designed Click Chamber to be as portable as possible and as functional as possible with a minimal space, budget, and everything in between. But we've still gotta get down to NYC, eat, and in theory sleep in something a pay grade above a storefront stoop in Williamsburg. Here's where your generous financial help is going:

  • 100% to the production first and foremost. We're paying for people to get down to get down on stage, via bus, train, hitch hiking and any way possible.
  • Accommodations! Aside from Justin and Aaron sleeping in doorways, we're trying to take care of our people and put them up in a place with 4 walls, even if we're just renting a dumpster to cram everyone in. We can't stress enough that our people are donating their time, so we need to pay them back as much as possible in every way possible.
  • Other basic needs like metro fare in the city, and costs associated with the show including space fees, props, makeup, etc.
  • Ideally we'd like to cover our people point to point and give them something to pocket away for a rainy day in May (Buffalo is wet and wild through the spring).
  • We've got some really cool perks from Buffalo artists both visual and musical, tickets to our gala event, signed scripts and more! Everything is all original and designed or created specifically for our production, and you can share in that!

The Impact of Click Chamber

We've created something here that isn't the norm, and isn't going to be viable on each and every stage in the universe. We aren't interested in that. Click Chamber has enough bite and presence to press up with the big boys, harkening back to the days when writing was cool, and you were smoking a cigar with a thick plume of smoke and downing a gin and tonic (or bourbon) in the rain and the heat.

But more than giving you our perfect valuation, we want the following from you as our viewer, sponsor, and friend:

  • We want you to feel something, whether you love it or hate. No tepid response.
  • We want you to think, and to formulate some of your own conclusions about what's right, what's wrong, and how to decide about that grey area.
  • We want to illuminate the struggles of the every day people, and how easy it is to get lost in the ghosts of ambition, whether in your mind, or the paranormal right in front of you.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please like us on Facebook! Click Chamber on Facebook:

If you like what you see here, please share it!

Thanks so much for your time and your support in any way you've chosen to give. The Click Chamber family thanks you!

story:
About Inclined Dance Project...

Inclined Dance Project began in January 2009 as informal rehearsals between director Kristen Klein and her friend's and fellow dance colleagues from The Boston Conservatory. Initially started as a way to experiment with movement and various choreographic exploits, these experimental rehearsals eventually took shape leading Kristen Klein to found Inclined Dance Project, with the company premiering in July 2009. 

Our 2015 Company Dancers include: Amy Campbell, Christina Chelette, Leighann Curd, Chie Mukai, Morgana Phlaum, and Jennifer Radcliffe.

Inclined Dance Project is now in it's 6th year of making work, and we have been fortunate enough to present and perform our work throughout NYC and around the tri-state area. But, it's time to expand! For the first time, our group will be traveling outside of NYC to Boston, MA where we have been invited to present our work at The Dance Complex in the Julie Ince Thompson Theatre on March 13 + 14, 2015. We will be presenting company favorite Stuck Together Pieces (which premiered to sold out audiences in 2013) and Inclined's newest work Temporize,  featuring Inclined's Leighann Curd & Chie Mukai. This show will be a split-bill with local Boston based company Intimations Dance, and we can't wait to share the stage with them!

But, in order to make this happen we need your help...

Help Us Get To Boston...

We are so excited to have been invited by The Dance Complex and to travel outside of NY for our Spring Performance Season! The Dance Complex, located in Cambridge MA just outside of Harvard University, has been presenting local, national, and international dancers since 1991, and it is the central hub for the Boston contemporary dance community. We are so thrilled to have our name added to it's roster of presented artists, but we cannot get there without your help! This is a huge opportunity for Inclined Dance Project. Most performing artists rarely get the chance to present work in their own resident city; it is that competitive! Inclined is extremely fortunate that we've been able to perform and dance in New York these past 6 years, and now we are even more fortunate to have this chance to bring our name and work to another city. Traveling to Boston will help to expand our name, our audience, and our own personal viewpoint as a group. Not many artists receive opportunities like this, so we are beyond thrilled that The Dance Complex has accepted us and invited us to their venue. This is a major milestone for Inclined, and it will help to open many more doors for us in the future. 

In order to get to Boston, we need a bit more than Artistic Director Kristen Klein's pocket change in order to safely get to Massachusetts and to put on the best show we can. That's where you come in! 

Your Donation...

Your generous donations will help Inclined in a multitude of ways! We need to get our 7 performers out of NYC and safely to Boston in March 2015. In order to do that, we need to raise at least $3000 to help cover the costs of:

  • Bus Fare + Traveling Fees
  • Housing for our weekend in Boston
  • Venue Fees in relation to The Dance Complex, including rental costs and security deposits
  • Lighting Design, Stage Managing, and Box Office personnel
  • Dancer Stipends

All donations are processed through our Fiscal Sponsor Fractured Atlas, and are fully tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law. 

In return, we have some awesome thank you's and gifts for our campaign supporters!

Other Ways You Can Help

First of all, thank you for even taking a look at our campaign and our company! We understand that things are tight for everyone these days, so if you can't contribute at this time: we understand! You can help us in other ways. :)

- Spread the word about our campaign! Share our link with your friends, family, dancers, fellow art lovers...the more people check us out, the better!

- Come to our shows! No matter what happens with the campaign, we still plan on finding a way to get to Boston for our Spring Season. Join us at The Dance Complex March 13 + 14, 2015. OR! Come to our NYC prequel performance on March 8th at The Secret Theatre.

- Like us on Facebook! or visit our Website. Or follow us on Twitter.

- Join our email list! Send an email to: inclineddp@gmail.com requesting to join our eblast and stay up to date on all of Inclined's amazing happenings.

- Send us happy vibes. Virtual high-fives. Or hugs. We love hugs.

Thank you for reading, watching, and most of all for supporting our goal. You are helping us keep art, dance, and live performance thriving. Thank you for sending us to Boston!

story:
Our Project: We are a new theatre company called Sheer Fiesty, which was founded  by two female performers Sorcha and Aella. We’re performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this summer with our new piece In Real Life (IRL). This devised two-hander explores what identity means in a contemporary age when technology can both enhance or manipulate our connection to the world.

Sheer Fiesty started working together last year to write and devise IRL. We met on The Performer Project which occurred in a converted community centre called The Albert in North London. This was a one-on-one interactive live art event which was inspired by relationships with food. We brought both the spectator and the performer physically close to the food substances, creating intimate one-off experiences in private rooms. We believe that Sheer Fiesty’s work can provoke audience’s thoughts about relevant concepts which need immediate attention. In Real Life (IRL) directly deals with the impact the internet has on modern relationships, offering multiple perspectives on the role of the catfished victim and the internet stalker themselves. 

Our Campaign: We are passionate about our work and consider the Edinburgh Festival an ideal platform to showcase our new performance. This opportunity would enable us to reach out to national and international communities that we think need to see our show. However we need £3000 to fund this project. With a venue confirmed just off the Royal Mile, we would have the ability to perform in a central location to a diverse range of audience members. All we need now is your generous donations to help make that happen. £3000 could help us pay for our venue in full and contrubute to the costs of marketing. The most effective tool in gathering audiences during the festival is flyering, talking to people on the street and postering every day. For that we need to order and print thousands of glossy flyers and posters, which we need your help to pay for!

What we need: If you could spare a donation, big or small, you could us help us reach our target. We won’t be able to showcase our work at the festival without you. Your generosity could be the springboard for performing future shows in London and around the UK. 

What we can offer you: There are four tiers of sponsorship; Bronze, Silver, Gold and Platinum. £15 will get you a subscription to our contributor’s monthly newsletter and your name will be mentioned in the Edinburgh show program. An additional £10 and we’ll also send you a personalised postcard while we are on tour in Edinburgh. Make a donation of £50 and you have bought a share in the production along with the previous perks. Above £100 and you will have all the benefits of the Bronze and Silver sponsors as well as two shares in the production and two free tickets to see us at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help: If you would like to keep up to date with our goings on, or if you are unable to make a donation, your support is still appreciated! Please help by spreading the word about Sheer Fiesty.

Lke us on facebook! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sheer-Fiesty/459127880825261 Follow us on twitter! https://twitter.com/sheerfiesty. Check up on our blog: http://sheerfiesty.wordpress.com/in-real-life-irl/. Email your address to sheerfiesty@gmail.com to recieve information about the company, with the title "mailing list". 

We will be showcasing work-in-progress previews so please stay tuned for further information. Thank you for your support and we hope to see you "In Real Life (IRL)"!

For that we need to order and print thousands of glossy flyers and posters, which we need your help to pay for!
What we need: If you could spare a donation, big or small, you could us help us reach our target. We won’t be able to showcase our work at the festival without you. Your generosity could be the springboard for performing future shows in London and around the UK. 
What we can offer you: There are four tiers of sponsorship; Bronze, Silver, Gold and Platinum. £15 will get you a subscription to our contributor’s monthly newsletter and your name will be mentioned in the Edinburgh show program. An additional £10 and we’ll also send you a personalised postcard while we are on tour in Edinburgh. Make a donation of £50 and you have bought a share in the production along with the previous perks. Above £100 and you will have all the benefits of the Bronze and Silver sponsors as well as two shares in the production and two free tickets to see us at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 
Other Ways You Can Help: If you would like to keep up to date with our goings on, or if you are unable to make a donation, your support is still appreciated! Please help by spreading the word about Sheer Fiesty.
Lke us on facebook! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sheer-Fiesty/459127880825261 Follow us on twitter! https://twitter.com/sheerfiesty. Check up on our blog: http://sheerfiesty.wordpress.com/in-real-life-irl/. Email your address to sheerfiesty@gmail.com to recieve information about the company, with the title "mailing list". 
We will be showcasing work-in-progress previews so please stay tuned for further information. Thank you for your support and we hope to see you "In Real Life (IRL)"!

story:
Lamplit are a company from Warwick University of three friends (Lissy Stowell, Molly Eedle and Lilith Wozniak). We spend a lot of time clowning around. Sometimes we play. Sometimes we dance. Sometimes we sing, loudly. Sometimes we just chat. We try not to take ourselves too seriously. Somehow we're making theatre.

We want you to see this theatre for free which is why we've chosen to go to PBH's Free Fringe. However, that doesn't mean that making the show is going to be free. Our major expenses include:

- Fringe Registration and Programme Fee

- Props and Costumes 

- Marketing Materials

- Travel to Edinburgh

These are the main things that your money will contribute to (any extra funds will go towards a place to sleep).

We know there  are a lot of people asking for your money so we've tried to make the rewards feel worthwhile. That's why we haven't done cumulative rewards, so you can get what you actually want. Of course if you want more than one of something, go for it! 

We hope to see you at the show. Donate now and you can walk haughtily past our bucket shaking!

Thank you! We'll see you in Edinburgh!! xxx

story:
What is Persephone?

We are devising an interdisciplinary, wordless movement theater piece called Persephone. Using modern dance and shadow work, we will tell the story of Hades stealing Persephone from her mother and dragging her to his home in the underworld. Demeter, Persephone's mother, frantically searches the world for her daughter while Hades seduces Persephone. Demeter's panic and despair brings about an eternal winter which consumes the land. Demeter finally does find her daughter, but not how she expected, as Persephone has found power with Hades, taking on the mantle of the Queen of the Underworld. As the tensions flair between the rulers of the realms, Persephone must make a difficult choice in order to save the fabric of reality: her newfound love and power and place in the world; or the comforting embrace of her mother and family?

The Cast and Crew!

Persephone- Katy Tye

Demeter- Hope Endrenyi

Hades- Josh Porter

Shadow Ensemble- Jacky Beatrice, Grace Cuny, Dakota Ratliff, and Eric Berg!

Written and Directed by Katy Tye

Music by Dean Wray

Magic by Trigg Watson

Set and Light Design by Jonah Gutierrez

Marketing and Promotion by Adam A Anderson and the Striped Heart Crew

What We Need:

Telling such an epic tale will require some innovative means to convey the story in a way that is effective and powerful. To further create the separation between the two worlds, we will be placing soil and "light flowers" made out of el wire to serve as Demeter's realm. We will also be using this space to explore how the changing of the seasons reflects the emotional and mental state of Demeter after the loss her daughter. Shadows on the other hand, are a malleable and versatile medium that can easily express the terrifying and magical beings that would exist in the Underworld. Thus, Hades' realm will be performed completely in shadow that will require the hanging of a huge muslin sheet that is capable of being raised and lowered. Finally, we will be using Trigg Watson as our magic consultant to make seemingly impossible events come to life like characters phasing in and out of solid sheets of fabric, and shadows affecting tangible objects.

Additionally, on Persephone’s opening night (October 31st) PrismCo will be collaborating with House Party Theatre to throw a Halloween after party featuring live bands, a costume contest, and a special performance by House Party Theatre themselves!

Use of Funding

Your funds will be used for the following purposes:

Paying our highly specialized performers and designers for their work on this project.

Fabric to make our panoramic, audience encompassing shadow screen

A quality projector to give an even throw of light on the screens, allowing for sharper shadow imagery.

El wire to create our garden for Demeter

Our marketing and outreach campaign, which includes paying for our design team and all of the posters, postcards, and t-shirts they will create.

What You'll Get 

Instead of thinking of this as just a fundraising campaign, we'd like our funders to think of this as a VIP preordering system. At the actual event tickets will be $15 each, but for a limited time only we will be giving all of our funders the opportunity to pre-order their tickets to this beautiful show for just $10 each. 

And for those of us who have been to a PrismCo show before, good seats run out pretty fast, so why not guarantee that you’ll have the seat of your choice? At $15, we will reserve a seat wherever you want it, and at $30 we’ll reserve those seats for you and a guest.

Additionally, we’ll be offering a ton of awesome perks that will only be offered for this campaign only, like a video of our behind the scenes process and some great deals on our PrismCo classes. Keep checking in as we will be offering more and more perks as we get closer to the final date!

The Impact

We have nothing but the highest expectations for PrismCo’s effect on the Dallas arts scene. Not only are we offering a type of theatre that is very rarely seen in the Dallas arts community, but we also hope our productions will offer opportunities to a wide variety of artists from different disciplines to showcase their work. For a lot of our visual, musical and performing artists, these shows can serve as their chance to premiere in the Dallas arts world, or hone their skills and try something completely new. We want to make sure these artists’ amazing talents are seen by Dallas artistic professionals and that they are fairly compensated for their incredible talents.

Also, because of the nature of PrismCo’s wordless, movement based theatre, our productions are an excellent medium for educational theatre, as we are able to present a variety of myths and other artistic experiences to a younger audience in a way that is engaging, and easily digestible for students of all ages.

Finally, we hope that PrismCo will ultimately help kick start West Dallas’ artistic growth as the area transitions into a new noncommercial arts district. With funding, we will not only be able to make our company stronger, but we will be helping to diversify the Dallas community of artists as a whole.

story:
Hi Friends,

Van Cougar is proud to present its third production, TUBE, premiering at the Incubator Arts Center (NY, NY) from November 30 - December 16, 2012.

Tube is an exploration of human connection through the theatrical convergence of YouTube, one of the grittiest, most pervasive forms of entertainment, and stories shared face-to-face, which are increasingly a rarity in this era where we type and text more than we talk. 

Your support will enable us to pay our actors and designers and build our set. 

All donors will receive a thank you letter and their name listed in our program (optional - let us know if you'd like to be anonymous). 

Thanks for listening,

Van Cougar

Mark Sitko, Erica Rippy, Paul Alexander

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

See what has been said about our past shows, Rocky Philly (2009) and Gonna See a Movie Called Gunga Din (2012)! 

About Rocky Philly:

 “Van Cougar's unprepossessing upstart of a show proceeds to pummel our expectations, drawing from a seemingly inexhaustible well of craft, cleverness, and Sweet Science.” – Village Voice

 About Gunga Din:

 “Whether you prefer your war stories low key or over the top, hesitant or harrowing, “Gonna See a Movie Called Gunga Din” has you covered.” – New York Times

“This dense and wonderful evening of theater has a stellar cast and remarkable moments, a richness of theatricality that attests strongly to that extensive talent that put it together.” – NYTheater.com

“Some of the most solid theater available.” – NYTheater.com

 “Conceived and directed by Mark Sitko, Gunga Dinis a darkly witty collage of American war sagas, mixing cherished fictions with gruesome truths.” – Village Voice

“Like the Rudyard Kipling poem of its title, Gunga Din finds understanding and communion where conventionally—and in pop culture—there is only conflict.” – L Magazine

story:
What is LET THE ANGELS IN?

     “Let The Angels In” is an evening length benefit performance including the works of Nicole Bilbao, Letticia Camacho, myself Juliet Dolan, Shawn Garnier and Nessa Rodriguez. “Let The Angels In” will premiere June 28th, 29th 2013 at 8 pm and June 30th, 2013 at 3 pm in The Aldous Theater of Triskelion Arts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. 

      “Let The Angels In” purpose is to raise funds for Down syndrome research through the gift of dance. All profits raised will be donated directly to Alexander’s Angels a non-profit organization whose mission is to further raise the awareness and contributions and needs of individuals with Down syndrome. Alexander’s Angel’s is dedicated to raising funds for advocacy, service, and various other research organizations. 100 percent of the profit raised will be donated towards this organization. 

      Our Pledge: In order to cover the remaining costs towards the production of this performance, we need your help. Your donations will ensure that all production costs such as costumes, sound and lighting equipment, light design, rehearsal space, and theatre rental will be covered in full.

      My personal experience in having a loved one diagnosed with Down syndrome is the inspiration behind the production of this work. My youngest sister Jilian was born with Down syndrome July 24, 2002. By combining my passion for dance and my desire to help those with special needs I aspire to bring Down syndrome awareness to the dance community.

      Through my involvement in Queens College’s Student Choreography Showcases, I have raised funds for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (2011) and the Carcinoid Cancer Awareness Network (2012). This production will be my first opportunity piloting and producing my first of many evening length works in an effort to raise funds for various organizations in need. 

     Other artists collaborating throughout the choreographic process of “Let The Angels In” include Queens College Dance Team Coach and Adjunct Professor Shawn Garnier, recent Queens College graduates, emerging choreographers and co-production managers Nicole Bilbao, and Letticia Camacho. “Let The Angels In” promises you to display a wide range of styles of dance including, modern, contemporary, and jazz to name a few. Each piece encompasses it’s own story and personality depicted by the uniqueness and voice of its choreographer. With your support we can help dance embrace and empower Down syndrome. 

Producer and Director 

Juliet Dolan, recently graduated with a bachelor's degree in dance from Queens College. Prior to receiving her bachelor's, she received her associates in American Sign Language at Nassau Community College. While attending Queens College she played a dedicated role in their Student Choreography Showcases, Faculty Showcases, and joined their nationally ranked Dance Team. At the age of 7, Juliet began tapping at the South Shore School of Dance. By 12, she was studying ballet, jazz, contemporary,tap and modern at KJ Dance Theatre.  Juliet Dolan aspires to direct and choreograph benefit dance performances to raise funds and awareness for human rights causes. These past two years, Juliet combined her love of dance, and interest in philanthropic work by producing successful fundraisers for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, and The Carcinoid Cancer Awareness Network.  Having a sister with Down syndrome makes this a cause very close to Juliet's heart. Juliet and her family have been involved with Alexander's Angels, Inc. for several years. By raising funds at the 2012 Queens College Summer Performing Arts Festival in their production of "Sweat It", and at "Last Call" in Farmingdale, New York, Juliet provided the basis for the production. 

Obstacles! 

    In effort to produce this show we have encountered several challenges along the way, such as obtaining the production space, and coordinating dance rehearsals. Although most individuals maybe interested in a live theatrical performance, we risk the possibility of people not attending. Our production location is far from our central social network. We are working hard to broaden our advertisements of this production in hopes to capture a wide audience. We risk people not receiving the information or taking an interest in this important cause. 

   This production has been made possible through the assistance provided by our family and friends. Through the art of dance, it is our mission to inspire, empower, and increase awareness to our audience on the need to support other individuals.

Other Ways You Can Help!

Any help recieivng exposure for this benefit will be greatly appreciated! Whether it be posting on facebook, instagram, twitter, tumblr, word of mouth etc..

Thank you so much for your support,

 

Juliet Dolan

**And a special thank you to Kevin McAuley. This indiegogo would not have been possible without him!**

story:
Help the incredibly famous and well revered cast of "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown" hire a drummer!

Hi. We're from Piper Theatre Productions, a small Brooklyn-based non-profit theater company with a very big heart.

This July, we're putting on a musical (comedy) production of "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown" outside (in a park) and under the stars (from the sky) and it's free. And adorable. And so stupidly fun that your face will hurt from smiling and laughing and your heart will swell up and explode because it's so heartfelt and also we're adorable.

We love this show and want everyone to love it even more but we would REALLY love to raise enough money to have a drummer besides just our piano player. (She wishes her piano also could turn into a drum set.) But we - because our hearts are so big and filled with love and not money - don't have the funds to pay for music-players on our own. So will you help us? Did we mention how adorable we are?

So if you've ever read a Charlie Brown comic, held your head low because you couldn't fly a kite OR if you once named your dog Snoopy because at the time it seemed original, throw us some Peanuts (get it?) and maybe your heart will feel just as big as ours.

story:
Dancemoves Studio of Dance, Celebrating 30 years of dance education!  We are ready to expand and create a new space where we can focus on our future stars - the little dancers, creating a new beautiful studio and a new dancewear store.  The studio continues to grow and flourish and the addition of our 4th space in a new building will help Dancemoves approach the future with adequate space and will encourage even more new families to try Dancemoves as their dance studio choice.  In addition, with the expansion of our programming to include a new non profit entity to support the development of our classical track, we have found it is the time to expand to a 4th space.  This new space will house a  30 x 21 studio along with a completely new dancewear store, so our students can find the attire for their classes right in our own store. 

Dancemoves has a great track record, our graduates have gone on to elite dance colleges throughout the country, Oklahoma City University, Marymount College in New York, Joffrey School of Ballet in New York, North Carolina School of the Arts, etc.  We are proud of our professionals, finding careers with such great companies as Disney Cruise Lines, Disneyland in California, Joffrey Ballet Company in New York and Complexions Contemporary Ballet Company of New York.  Dancemoves is certainly making its mark on the dance world.  

With your help, we continue in this quest to continue to grow and offer the best to our students and community.  Whether it is ballet, jazz, tap, hip hop or modern dance, Dancemoves offers it all.  Please help us meet our goal.  If you are ever in the White Marsh, Maryland area, please stop in and try a class on us:D!  Thank you from the bottom of our dance shoes!!!  Please share everyone, so we can spread the word and hopefully everyone will want to help, if just a little:D!  Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Brent Eickhoff, and I'm a senior Directing and Theatre Education Major at Ball State University in Muncie, IN. For my senior directing capstone, I am producing a production of Caryl Churchill's play The Skriker. 
I first read this play two years ago and was immediately grabbed by its combination of magical realism and horror, as well as Churchill's unique use of language and movement to construct a truly unique theatrical experience. As a senior capstone, The Skriker is artistically, intellectually, and technically challenging to all members of my production team; a perfect piece for a senior thesis.
As is the case with many of Churchill's works, The Skriker has many social ties, as well. Themes of feminism, environmentalism, and post-partum disorders such as depression and psychosis run throughout the piece. In an effort to make the focus of this project less on my success as an undergrad, and more about the world at large, I have partnered with Postpartum Support International, to ensure that all profits from this performance support a worthy cause. It is my hope that in addition to supporting one of the world's leading resources for postpartum disorders, my capstone can also educate audiences at the collegiate level about various postpartum disorders and complications,

What We Need & What You Get

We have already obtained rights to three performances from Samuel French, Inc, and, although it would be nice for me to get that money reimbursed, rights are not the main goal of this fundraiser. This fundraiser specifically helps:
  • Pay for the construction and design of costumes for 10 actors playing a total of over 20 roles.
  • Pay for the creation of a minimal set, designed and displaying artwork from a Ball State art major.
  • Pay for the securing of multiple props, from an antique baby pram to more practical pieces such as chairs and a knife. 
  • Pay for clamp lights so our lighting design can exist!
  • Pay for the printing of advertising materials, as well as fulfillment of donation perks.
  • Pay for the rental of chairs for our performance venue, as the chairs that are available to us are incredibly uncomfortable.
Depending on the amount donated to this campaign, you can receive your name in the special thanks section of the program, a poster from the show, or a poster from the show signed by the cast and crew!
If we don't reach our entire funding goal, the money we do gain will try to achieve these goals on a slighter budget. However, we believe that $500 is already quite a small budget, even for a minimal production of this piece. 
If we raise more money than we end up spending, the remainder of the proceeds from this campaign will be donated to Postpartum Support International, along with all ticket sales and donations from performances.

**UPDATE 10/17/14***
Wow! Already only $50 away from our goal, thanks to some very generous contributions! Here's a stretch goal: If we make it to $600, that means that we may be able to add a fourth performance of the show, which also means more ticket sales to benefit Postpartum Support International, and more people to see this show! With over ten days left, I'm more than confident we can get that far! 

The Impact

Your contribution helps support theatre at the collegiate level, as well as the development of students of Acting, Musical Theatre, Directing, Stage Management, Sound Design, Lighting Design, and Theatrical Studies. Our creative team has a successful record of creating and performing in theatre productions ranging from Shakespeare to contemporary drama and Golden Age musicals. Our design team has similar experience working in a variety of performance venues, from intimate 40-seat black box theatres, to larger black box theatres, and prosceniums. Additionally, your contribution, in turn, helps support Postpartum Support International, while reinforcing a need for socially-conscious theatre in the world.

Risks & Challenges

As with any project, there are certainly some challenges to producing a play as demanding as The Skriker, even on a minimal budget with minimal design. However, it is my belief that by collaborating with other students of theatre in a variety of concentrations, the sum total of our efforts will be great enough to solve any problem, be they problems within Churchill's text, the technical limitations of our performance venue, or budgetary limitations based on our fundraiser.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, please feel free to help out in any other way possible! Spread the word and share this project with others, send a card of encouragement to the cast and crew, or consider becoming an advocate for Postpartum Support International!

story:
Yay! We did it! On September 27, 2014 we seriously rocked the house with our one-night-only preview of RADITATICAL: A Journey in Rhythm. With so many new things being tried for the first time, we really didn't know how it would go...

It went off! It went crazy! It went fantastic! Here's what happened:

  • A thrilled crowd leaped to a jubilant standing/bouncing/screaming ovation for our phenomenally-talented cast. Valiant parents had to restrain their excited tykes as they tried to rush the stage at curtain-call.

  • Bronkar Lee, the world's only rhythmic juggling beatboxer (Tonight Show, America’s Got Talent), guided us through a hero's journey to becoming a raditatically rhythmic being. The packed house participated via interactive mass body percussion & beatboxing experiences.

  • From the very young to the very young at heart, hundreds of theatre-goers learned, "It's The Feeling That Comes From the Rhythm, And The Rhythm Is The Feeling That Comes From The Joy" and left the venue happily singing our closing number.

  • The Montalban asked us back. By any measure, this night was a success, and we all want more.

So we know it worked! And here's what we're doing next:

We're returning to the Montalban Theatre for a six-show run! This time we're aiming for a bigger, bolder, super-charged version of the original One Night Only experience. 


The RADITATICAL team is excited to meet our audience-demand with a technically and creatively revitalized show, for a new set of toe-tappers, head-nodders, chair-dancers and music-lovers. 

What we need...

We're looking to raise $22,000 to make this expanded run a reality. In theater terms, this is not a lot of money. And that's what we keep telling ourselves... 

Here's where the money goes:

  • Hear, Read and Tweet All About It! -- Word of mouth about our preview event has been positively humbling. To reach a brand new set of audiences for our two-week run, we want to bring in a professional marketing guru with an MBA in Theatrical Production and tons of great experience and connections.  This is probably the most important step in filling seats and making sure this awesome show is financially successful!

  • Purchase TouchDesigner Software -- RADITATICAL is more than an exploration of rhythm. It's an interactive, multimedia experience, utilizing video projection and a multitude of special effects. TouchDesigner software fine tunes that process and aids in the seamless creation and execution of high-tech storytelling elements.

  • Hanging Our Hats -- Part of your contributions will go towards the rental of rehearsal spaces so we can tighten up the show and add back a couple new scenes that weren't ready for our preview. 

What you get...

This show is all about positivity! Empowering and enlivening the world is the reason we put this show together and it's the core of why we do what we do. In addition to the personal satisfaction of helping us help make the world a brighter place, we've got a bunch of rewards that allow you to enjoy the show and offerings from our cast.

Check out the sidebar for info on the rewards available to those who contribute...

For those interested in contributing at the $5K level and above, please contact us directly for investor opportunities.


FAQs...


Who's running this campaign?

The fine folks of Raditatical Productions (Bronkar Lee, Sam Rogers & Cyndi Harvell) have teamed up with the ladies of Bad Barbie Media (Ameenah Kaplan, Tina Sanchez & Kelsey Scott) for this expanded run. Any questions about us, just ask! 


Didn't you guys already raise money? 

Yes! Thanks to 130+ loving supporters, we successfully overfunded our Kickstarter campaign for $12,000 for our show development launch and preview night. This campaign is to level-up our show for our December run. 


    Why Indiegogo this time?

    Our show development/launch campaign ran on Kickstarter because that was an all-or-nothing kind of thing: either we got the budget to launch the show or the show didn't go on. Now the show is ON!!! Indiegogo allows us the flexibility to run a longer campaign that is more flexible. Because we're up and running at this point, we can adjust our budget to match your contributions. The more you give, the better we get, and the more people get to know about us!


    How else can I help?

    Money is the obvious thing, but we welcome all kinds of your love and support! We're looking for people to help us get the word out about the show in the 6-weeks leading up to it. If you're local to the LA area and can be part of our Raditatical Street Team that will distributed printed promotions, we will love you forever. If you're all over facebook/twitter/blogs/whatevers, hit us up and tell us what you can do. Just tweeting or sharing the link to this campaign would be huge for us! And (hint! hint!) you can do that with the conveniently placed links below... ;)

story:
Who we are and What we're about!

Epsilon Theater Company provides a new form of theater entertainment that brings the show to you. Combining the intimacy of film with the power of live performance, ETC has created a catalog of plays designed to be performed in any private living space. Providing an array of both established plays as well as original works, Epsilon has the perfect show for your next social gathering. We have built a team of award winning directors, writers, and actors, but we are still missing one vital piece. You!

We were founded by Grafton Doyle and Daniel Korth, two experienced actors, directors, and writers who come from the San Francisco Bay Area. They met while studying together at the Meisner Technique Studio and formed a friendship grounded in their shared  passion and aspirations for theater.  After performing a play in Grafton's apartment, the two realized the potential that this intimate theater experience brings and created a team and business model to make it possible.

Daniel Korth, founder and Aristic Director. Daniel graduated with a B.A. in play-crafting and dramaturgy from San Francisco State University and brings with him the experience of producing several independent productions and has helped form other theater companies such as 4th Mirror Productions. He has written and directed shows in San Francisco and San Jose and has a history of producing theater in non-traditional spaces. 

Grafton Doyle, founder and C.E.O. graduated from the Meisner Technique Studio in San Francisco in 2011.  Since then, he has produced and directed several shows in San Francisco and Los Angeles. Most recent works were selected for The Hollywood Fringe Festival and what is currently the Avery Schreiber Playhouse.  

We are also supported by an incredible team:

Shoshanna Chagall, Managing Director. Armed with an MBA and a JD, she brings a strong business acumen and a flair for creativity to launch this novel production company. Her fresh yet informed perspectives were part of launching several successful technical incubators and artistic ventures . Years ago, an accidental dabble in the arts through a college performance playing Nora in Henrik Ibsen's A Doll's House, confirmed a life-long love for all things Theater. Also, produced and acted in feature films.

Tessa Evelyn, board member

Bryan Becker, director

Melanie Weisner, director

Philipp Maximilian, company member

Brandon Miradi, company member

How We Work:

After selecting one of our plays, we set up a private consultation with you in your home. Here we will go over the specifics of the production, discuss where and how the performance will be shown, and plan out our logistical design. All plays are ready to go and be molded to fit into any space.

On the day of the performance, we will arrive at your home and work around you and your guests as we set up. You will all then be invited into the space and sit around comfortably as the story unfolds around you. Only requiring a half hour on either end to set up and take down, it will be a seamless experience as your home transforms. 

The focus of our plays is on the writing and performances. Because you are sitting so close to the action, there is no need for elaborate sets and lighting. All the plays take place in residences, so the setting is already established just by being in the home.  We will bring in costumes and props along with minimal technology, but it is the story and performances that will transport you into another world.

It is already a great feat to produce one play, much less a catalog. In addition, we have created a formula that can transport the play to any location. Your help will allow this all to come to life.


Want to donate?

Your contribution helps us make our vision a reality.  We have the team already in place and need to extra boost to effectively move us forward.  

We are asking for $12,000 to initiate our startup costs which include: LLC costs, lighting and equipment, costumes, publicity, tech and crew, talent, and directors.  

For those who donate to our cause we are so grateful and want to spread the love! 

Check out or special gifts for your donation amount!

$5,000  - Executive Producer credit on single performance plus everything below

$2,000 -  Donated Show of your choice to your home

$1,000 -  Invitation to a private performance

$500    -  Invitation to a rehearsal plus meet with the actors

$250    -  Honorary company member 

$100    -  Credit in our programs and website

$50      -   A Shout Out! on Social Media 

$10      -   Special Thank you 

What we strive for.

Our purpose is to share the gift of intimate storytelling in small personal living spaces while maintaining proper business practices to insure success.  The reflection of life we share through performance brings the actor and audience in communion with the human spirit. 

Risks & Challenges

Theater has been around from time immemorial, and for several centuries private performances of the arts were meant just for royals. Thankfully, shifts in societal strata brought the magic of theater to people everywhere and now it's come a full circle where anyone can have a private performance put up for their friends and family. Epsilon is a budding company with a seasoned idea. We understand that the love for theater is an acquired taste and not all segments of the populace are engaged in supporting local arts. Our challenge is to convert the non-believers and make them feel part of an artistic experience even if they are not into typical plays. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who are not able to contribute financially, that's OK!

If you like what you see please feel free to share our idea with the people you love and trust.  And if there is someone you know who you think might be interested in our work please recommend us!  We welcome any and all support to make our business a success!

story:
Dear Friends, Family and Dance Enthusiasts...

I'm excited to announce that my multi-media dance work, Self Portrait has been accepted into Triskelion Arts' 6th Annual Comedy in Dance Festival! The work will be performed at their new Muriel Shulman Theater in Greenpoint, Brooklyn on March 21st at 8pm. With this page, I'm aiming to raise the funds it will take to pay for logistical factors (rehearsal space, costumes, etc) and to pay the dancers I'm working with. Scroll down to learn more about me, the work, and how you can help.

A little bit about me...
I recently made the move to Brooklyn after spending most of my life in Florida (yes, I'm cold). I'm fresh out of Graduate School and hold an MFA in Choreography and Performance from Florida State University and a BFA in Modern Dance Performance from University of South Florida. In Tampa, FL, I danced for Moving Current Dance Collective and All Out Repertory Theatre. In 2009, I co-founded Shoes at the Door Dance Company (SatD) alongside Danielle Boe and Brooke Bissell (check out their website here: www.shoesatthedoor.org). I served as an artistic director, choreographer, teacher, and performer with SatD until 2014. Following my desire for more training in multimedia production, I chose to attend FSU and take every dance technology course offered. 

A little bit about the work...
Self Portrait  premiered in April of 2014 as a part of my MFA Thesis Concert.  This multimedia dance work follows a modern day social media subscriber and her multiple online personas. The social media phenomenon is reflected in video and still projections featuring colorful, Andy Warhol influenced design and accompanies a mix of gestural and space eating movements on the stage. The music, "Magic Marker," was composed by Brian Petuch (check out his website here: www.brianpetuch.com). This work explores themes of narcissism, identity, and centers around the idea that online, you can be anyone, anything and as many different versions of yourself as you wish. The choreographic process took a year and a half and was done in collaboration with the cast (FSU dancers Mary Rebekah Bartos, Taylor Ennen, Ashley Goos, Emily Lievsay, Alyssa Morris, and rehearsal assistant/understudy, Veoletta Range). We discussed our own experiences with social media - how we think we project ourselves, how we think we are perceived, how we want to be perceived, how we perceive each other in person and online, and built movements out of our findings. Simultaneously, I drew up projection designs, took footage, edited, and repeated the process several times until what was on the screen complimented the movement and vice versa. 

How you can help...
I have a magnificent new cast here that is working hard, commuting all over the city, and taking time off of their jobs for the show. I DESPERATELY want to compensate them for their enormous efforts. Currently, I am paying for rehearsal space out of pocket and must purchase costumes for the work as the original outfits belong to FSU.
Your funding will go towards....
  • Compensating the dancers ($200-$600)
  • Studio rentals (approx $250-$300)
  • Costumes (approx $150)


Your impact...

I am seeking $1000 to cover the logistical costs and I've built into that number enough to give the dancers between $50-$150 each. My compensation for showing this work will be exposure. I'm extremely grateful for this as I plan to continue choreographing, however, my day job does not provide me with enough money to fund this on my own. Contributions will first go towards studio rentals and costumes and any other money raised will go towards paying the dancers. If my goal is not reached, it is possible that the dancers will not be paid. Professional dancers, especially when they are starting out, often work hard for little to no compensation. Your contribution can impact this unfortunate reality by providing pay for their long hours and fierce dedication to their art.

If you can't afford to contribute...
Share, share, share! The piece is about social media, so  let's put it to work! Mention it in a status, in the spirit of the work, post a selfie and copy the link to it! 


Many thanks to you all!

-Erica and the cast
story_txt:
Dear Friends, Family and Dance Enthusiasts...
I'm excited to announce that my multi-media dance work, Self Portrait has been accepted into Triskelion Arts' 6th Annual Comedy in Dance Festival! The work will be performed at their new Muriel Shulman Theater in Greenpoint, Brooklyn on March 21st at 8pm. With this page, I'm aiming to raise the funds it will take to pay for logistical factors (rehearsal space, costumes, etc) and to pay the dancers I'm working with. Scroll down to learn more about me, the work, and how you can help.

A little bit about me...
I recently made the move to Brooklyn after spending most of my life in Florida (yes, I'm cold). I'm fresh out of Graduate School and hold an MFA in Choreography and Performance from Florida State University and a BFA in Modern Dance Performance from University of South Florida. In Tampa, FL, I danced for Moving Current Dance Collective and All Out Repertory Theatre. In 2009, I co-founded Shoes at the Door Dance Company (SatD) alongside Danielle Boe and Brooke Bissell (check out their website here: www.shoesatthedoor.org). I served as an artistic director, choreographer, teacher, and performer with SatD until 2014. Following my desire for more training in multimedia production, I chose to attend FSU and take every dance technology course offered. 

A little bit about the work...

Self Portrait  premiered in April of 2014 as a part of my MFA Thesis Concert.  This multimedia dance work follows a modern day social media subscriber and her multiple online personas. The social media phenomenon is reflected in video and still projections featuring colorful, Andy Warhol influenced design and accompanies a mix of gestural and space eating movements on the stage. The music, "Magic Marker," was composed by Brian Petuch (check out his website here: www.brianpetuch.com). This work explores themes of narcissism, identity, and centers around the idea that online, you can be anyone, anything and as many different versions of yourself as you wish. The choreographic process took a year and a half and was done in collaboration with the cast (FSU dancers Mary Rebekah Bartos, Taylor Ennen, Ashley Goos, Emily Lievsay, Alyssa Morris, and rehearsal assistant/understudy, Veoletta Range). We discussed our own experiences with social media - how we think we project ourselves, how we think we are perceived, how we want to be perceived, how we perceive each other in person and online, and built movements out of our findings. Simultaneously, I drew up projection designs, took footage, edited, and repeated the process several times until what was on the screen complimented the movement and vice versa. 

How you can help...
I have a magnificent new cast here that is working hard, commuting all over the city, and taking time off of their jobs for the show. I DESPERATELY want to compensate them for their enormous efforts. Currently, I am paying for rehearsal space out of pocket and must purchase costumes for the work as the original outfits belong to FSU.
Your funding will go towards....  Compensating the dancers ($200-$600) Studio rentals (approx $250-$300) Costumes (approx $150)
   

Your impact...

I am seeking $1000 to cover the logistical costs and I've built into that number enough to give the dancers between $50-$150 each. My compensation for showing this work will be exposure. I'm extremely grateful for this as I plan to continue choreographing, however, my day job does not provide me with enough money to fund this on my own. Contributions will first go towards studio rentals and costumes and any other money raised will go towards paying the dancers. If my goal is not reached, it is possible that the dancers will not be paid. Professional dancers, especially when they are starting out, often work hard for little to no compensation. Your contribution can impact this unfortunate reality by providing pay for their long hours and fierce dedication to their art.


If you can't afford to contribute...

Share, share, share! The piece is about social media, so  let's put it to work! Mention it in a status, in the spirit of the work, post a selfie and copy the link to it! 
 Many thanks to you all!-Erica and the cast

story:
The Eight-Reindeer Monologues 

by Jeff Goode

KNOW BETTER PRODUCTIONS

  • Know Better Productions (KBP) consists of a few Madison locals (primarily Simone LaPierre and Brian Belz and the KBP secret weapon of entertainment Francisco C Torres) who like to do theatre and other things such as filmmaking / dancing / photography / making web pages / and more :) 
  • Know Better Productions has produced theatre before though this campaign begins a regular effort to bring you one or two productions each year of fun and challenging theatre from both royally published writers and local/beginning ones too!  We like to work with groups all over Madison and we like to do our own favorites too and you can join us -
  • We will use funds raised from this campaign to stage The Eight-Reindeer Monologues by Jeff Goode for December 2013 at the Broom Street Theatre space - any funds raised beyond our goal will be directed toward our next production so no donation shall be left without purpose -

Having support for our projects brings us all together and makes us smile :)

  • For The Eight there is a not necessarily inexpensive list of cost involved ---Royalties ($300) / Print costs ($160) / Scripts ($65) / Unexpected Costs ($?!?)
  • We have put together some fun perks and recognitions for those who would like to be a part of this project by making a donation - such as --- getting thanked in the program for $1 / getting reserved tickets and a poster signed by the cast for $15 / getting reserved tickets and CDs with music from the production for $30 / or getting it all and more for $50 by making The End of the Rainbow donation!
  • any funds raised before or beyond our goal will be directed firstly toward the current project of The Eight and anything left will go toward our next production(s) so no donation shall be left without purpose

why The Eight and KBP?

  • The Eight-Reindeer Monologues is fun to stage AND maintains an important and timeless consideration about what people should expect from each other and the value of respect-
  • Know Better Productions has produced theatre before - including both original work at Broom Street Theatre and outdoor Shakespeare
  • Writers and directors who want to see their work produced will have opportunities with KBP for future projects and these collaborations are a big part of the excitement for continuing

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Want to help even more with KBP?  in addition to OR in place of making a donation on indiegogo you can go to facebook.com/knowbetterprod and contact us:)
  • If you're excited about The Eight or think KBP sounds cool in any way then check out the Indiegogo share tools and get the word out!  KBP has never tried the Indiegogo share tools but let us know if they are cool and useful - Indiegogo recommends them anyway :)

Enjoy the show!

story:
About the young company and Fund-A-Need:

the young company at Stoneham Theatre offers children so much more than performance opportunities: children have a place to belong; a place to build confidence and creativity; a place where they share friendships and joy. Through voice lessons, dance, workshops and performance festivals, they learn to express themselves, and connect to others.

We have a promise to keep:

We promise to never turn away a child due to financial need. 

We need your help to keep this promise so that every child can have these opportunities.

Your gift (of any size) will help us level the playing field for children whose families are experiencing financial hardships. Last year, more than $15,000 was distributed to cover tuition through Fund-A-Need scholarships, but that money is gone and another year is ahead of us, with more children who need financial assistance.

Why Give?

Your donation is what allows us to say yes to students with financial hardships. We have subsidized tuition for children with parents who are unexpectedly laid off, and others who have enormous medical bills piled on top of an illness. Some parents struggle while working several low-paying jobs. All of these children in these situations should still have the opportunities Stoneham Theatre can provide.

Take a look at the perks we are offering, from private intermission parties to inspiring updates to free tickets!

The ultimate perk? You can know you had a hand in improving a child's life by opening the door to the benefits of theatre.

Other ways to help:
Some people just can’t contribute even $10, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • You can privately email or Facebook message this link to friends who love theatre and care about children.
  • You can share this link on Facebook. Often!
  • You can join us in the audience to enjoy these wonderful children on stage.

Thank you!
