story:
History of the Production

Our artistic team began this journey in 2012 at The Wedge, Hangar Theatre’s innovative second stage in Ithaca, New York.  We experimented with unlocking Beckett’s classic text for a contemporary theatre-goer and need to share our production Happy Days with the savvy audiences of Washington DC!

Our production delves into what is particularly unique about this experience today. Our culture is obsessed with things.  Particularly fast things.  3G is quickly discarded for 4G is quickly discarded for 5G with fingerprint security.  We stand in line for hours for the newer faster thing. We are in a constant state of discarding things that are
slow in order to #stayconnected!  Our production of Happy Days explores what happens to the things we discard -- and the people that remain connected to them.  

As our audiences enter CulturalDC’s Mead Theatre Lab in February 2014, they won’t be stepping into the proscenium stages of yesterday’s theatre, but literally into Winnie’s world as we convert the traditional theatre space into an art installation with your generous help.  

Who We Are

We are not a theatre company.  We are a group of artists passionate about collaboration and making art.  Therefore, we are extremely fortunate to have been invited to present Happy Days as part of CulturalDC’s Mead Theatre Lab 2013-2014 season.  The Mead Theatre Lab is the first step to producing Happy Days. YOU are the second.

  • Producer & Director: Jess Jung
  • Producer & Assistant Director: Maureen Monterubio
  • Set Design: Joe Klug
  • Art Director & Photography: Ryan Maxwell
  • Sound Design: Edward Young
  • Lighting Design: Sean Forsythe (original lighting by Felicia Hall)
  • Costume Design: Joni Martin Yost (original costumes by Barbara Begley)
  • Winnie: Karen Lange
  • Willie: Christian Sullivan

 

The Play

Happy Days was written by Samuel Beckett in 1961.  It is the story of Winnie, a woman in her 50’s, buried to her waist in the earth.  Winnie dwells in a barren landscape under the hot sun with only her inattentive husband, Willie, to talk to. Although she is trapped, Winnie remains delightfully optimistic and passes “another happy day” futzing with beloved objects that keep her company…including a gun.  

Beckett’s plays are considered triumphs of the Theatre of the Absurd.  Martin Esslin, the scholar who coined the term “Theatre of the Absurd”, wrote that these plays:

“…explore the human subconscious in depth rather than trying to describe the outward appearance of human existence… [Theatre of the Absurd] aims to shock its audience out of complacency, to bring it face to face with the harsh facts of the human situation as these writers see it. But the challenge behind this message is anything but one of despair. It is the challenge to accept the human condition as it is, in all its mystery and absurdity…”

Happy Days is no exception.

 

What do we need?

Well, money.  Here is the breakdown…

  • Producing Rights = $675
  • Actor, Designer, & Artist Fees = $2000
  • Production & Gallery Materials = $625
  • Marketing Materials = $200
  • Total = $3500


The Impact of Your Donation

The core of theatre is about connection, an essential piece to humanity dwindling in our digital world.  Your generous support of live theatre gives audiences the opportunity to connect creatively face to face with an artist.  It’s even faster than 5G. 

 

What do you get?

To make Winnie very Happy!  Plus a selection of insider perks.  We hope that these perks display our sincere gratitude for your support.  Again, we can’t make art without you!

Plus, we have been generously sponsored by Fractured Atlas.  What does that mean for you?  It means that your donations are tax deductible! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign and like us on Facebook!
  • Come see the show.
  • Tweet it on Twitter @DCHappyDays.
  • Come see the show.
  • Tell people about us without the assistance of social media.
  • And then, maybe, come see the show.

 

CulturalDC and The Mead Theatre Lab

CulturalDC makes space for art. Each year CulturalDC serves over 1,000 artists and arts groups and 30,000 audience members through the activation of art space and presentation of contemporary visual and performing arts at our two spaces, Flashpoint and Source, and in nontraditional venues across the city. Through our programs and services we work with artists and arts organizations to build the creative infrastructure that fuels the arts and builds community in Washington, DC.

The Mead Theatre Lab Program at Flashpoint, a CulturalDC project, is generously sponsored by the late Jaylee Mead. Additional support is provided by The Dallas Morse Coors Foundation for the Performing Arts, the Max & Victoria Dreyfus Foundation, the Mary & Daniel Loughran Foundation, The Washington Post Company and The Weissberg Foundation.

Funding for CulturalDC is generously provided by The Morris & Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation, DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities, The Community Foundation for the National Capital Region, The Kresge Foundation, the MARPAT Foundation, the Eugene & Agnes E. Meyer Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts, Prince Charitable Trusts, The Share Fund of the Community Foundation for the National Capital Region and many other generous partners. Marvin is CulturalDC’s 2012-13 Wine Partner.

story:
SUPPORT ARCHITECTURE IN MOTION

New works are the heart of dance. Over our twenty-year history under the leadership of Artistic Director Jacques Heim, Diavolo Dance Theater has presented dozens of dance works, creating one of the dance field’s most compelling repertoires. Diavolo is poised to continue re-defining movement this season with the completion of L’Espace du Temps—a trilogy of new works commissioned by the L.A. Philharmonic Association. 

The third piece in the trilogy—Fluid Infinities—will receive its “Avant Premier” at our in-studio fundraiser on Saturday, August 31st. The world premiere will take place live with the L.A. Philharmonic at the Hollywood Bowl on Thursday, September 5th. All three works in L’Espace du Temps will be re-mounted in a single concert program for worldwide touring beginning in 2014!

In order to complete all this, we need your help. Let’s join together to make it all happen. 

The Diavolo Touring Company. Photo by Leandro Damasco. 

CORE GOAL & STRETCH GOAL

Our core goal is to raise $5,000 here online, in time for the Fluid Infinities world premiere. Your contributions will go towards completion funds for Fluid Infinities and the L’Espace du Temps re-mounting, including:

  • dancer pay for adding one week of rehearsal on the trilogy
  • set transportation (storage shelves, transport carts)
  • lighting and costume materials

Our stretch goal is to raise an additional $5,000 here online (bringing us to $10,000 total). In addition to giving us more wiggle-room, this funding will allow us to hire our collaborators for futher work on the trilogy (dramaturg, lighting director, etc) as well as pay for needed set repairs (paint, welding). 

COMMUNITY BENEFITS

There are so many ways that the L'Espace du Temps trilogy will positively impact the community, including supporting world-class dance made right here in Los Angeles.

As one of the leading local dance companies to tour locally, nationally, and internationally, Diavolo is a cultural pillar of our community. As the culmination of a seven-year collaboration with the L.A. Phil, L’Espace du Temps is a major accomplishment. Diavolo's presentation of bold new works on the world stage enhances both city life and L.A.'s reputation as the creative capital of America.

“[Diavolo] define[s] the art of this city…To say Diavolo is exciting is redundant...Maybe art—concert dance—can help us brace against whatever war, pestilence, storm, and injustice have in store.”

– Los Angeles Times, on the 2007 and 2010 world premieres of the two previous works of the trilogy -- Foreign Bodies and Fearful Symmetries -- at the Hollywood Bowl

The set model for Fluid Infinities. Photo by Tina Trefethen. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word. Make some noise about this campaign on your social media platform of choice (Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, etc). Click on the share buttons on this page. Encourage people you know to attend our "Avant Premiere" L.A. Fundraiser, our Hollywood Bowl world premiere, and especially to help support the completion of this trilogy. 

Ask questions. Contact Executive Director Matt Wells at matt@diavolo.org or (323) 225-4290. Get involved. Become a part of L.A. dance history.

story:
Introductions

Robert Monegan is a New York City based Illustration artist, writer, director, combining his Glam Divas comic book style artwork and stories into theatrical presentations for stage and film. Successes include stage/film versions of The Glam Divas Show, where his fierce illustrated characters come to life in the form of actors, models, and drag queens. www.glamdivas.net

Upstate born Mark Thaddeus Williams is the technical member of the team, responsible for graphic realization and music direction. A graduate of Colgate and Yale Universities, he is a Manhattan based freelance graphic designer. www.markthaddeus.com

Inspired By...

Written as both play and screenplay by Robert Monegan, Defiantly Fabulous is a comedic and gay twist on the classic 1958 film, "The Defiant Ones". It starred Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier, about two escaped convicts, one white, one black, shackled together, hate each other, but must help each other, in order to survive and outrun the law. Great film, serious drama. Robert always wanted to do a gay version of the story. Not really a spoof, but semi same plot as original film, only comedic, catty, over the top, plenty of pop culture winks, set in the funky 1970s, and gay eye candy galore....so he wrote one. Originally Robert wrote it as a play, but after a chance meeting with SIDNEY POITIER, who suggested switching  it to a screenplay, Robert did as such.

The Plot Thickens

Defiantly Fabulous - you are teased with a barrage of pop culture reminders of how life used to be. A throw-back to a simpler time, before cell phones, internet, and political correctness made everyone uptight, scared, and boring. The story centers around two men, their connection, and how they deal with it, all done up in a dare-to-go-there plot.

Set in the deep south of the 1970’s, two attractive convicts manage to escape from prison, and now are on the run from the Law.  Adding to the mix, one convict is black, the other is white, they are shackled together, and not too fond of one another (or so we think).  Oh, it should also be mentioned that both convicts are gay, and although one of them is closeted, and the other is “way out there”, neither of them have any trouble expressing their dislike for each other, with all the wit and fierceness you expect (and enjoy) in a gay farce.  However, the shackles the two share are a constant reminder of the connection they have, and the team work they must do in order to survive. Tempering their clashes (of sorts), the hunky duo keep a skip and jump distance from a redneck Sheriff and his side-kick Deputy, who are hot on their trail. As our runaway boys continue their flight through unknown wilderness and rural areas, they eventually stumble upon a lonely single mother and her quiet (but very cute) teenage son. It’s not long before we realize the mother hungers for a new life…and a new man to share it with.  She frees the two from their chains, only to find out that neither man wants to service her desires. Thus, our captivating convicts continue on the run, rid of their shackles, but now must face a much stronger connection they have….their true feelings for each other. In the end, one wonders what was the biggest crime these two men committed? Skipping prison or skipping their hearts?

The Goal 

Producing two trial performances of the play, for further shopping of both play and screenplay versions to producers and industry. Performance dates: Fall 2012.

Needs and Perks

Seeking additional funds for production budget. Amount: $2500. Money will go towards theatre/rehearsal space rental and tech crew. The cast are non Equity actor friends, who are volunteering their time and talent in exchange for copy and credit of production. Wardrobe, make-up, and hair are also contributed. Regardless of whether entire amount is raised or not, all funds will go towards this production.

Who doesn't need their own website...and a good one at that? In exchange to those who help with funding, web designer Mark Thaddeus Williams will offer affordable rates on his professional and prompt designing services. But that's not all! For all those divas out there (and we know who you are), artist Robert Monegan offers free gift packs of his sassy Glam Divas greeting cards, which feature fierce chicks, hot men, and tongue in cheek humor...no, not porn, just good clean bitchyness! T-shirts with Defiantly Fabulous logo (as shown in campaign image) also available. See "perks" section for details.  

The Bigger Picture

For the last five years, Robert Monegan and Mark Thaddeus Williams have created shows and events, with the help of a dedicated and talented team of technicians, actors, and stylists. Defiantly Fabulous is no different. However, as the productions grow, so does the need for additional funding. Robert and Mark's purpose for their shows is not just to do a show, but to also use their creativity as a way towards the bigger goal of producing entertainment where a percentage of profits goes to their personal cause: finding a cure for Parkinson's Disease. Your contributions to this campaign will push Robert and Mark closer to that bigger goal.

And Another Thing...

Other ways you can help? Duh - tell your friends (LOL)!
story_txt:
Introductions
Robert Monegan is a New York City based Illustration artist, writer, director, combining his Glam Divas comic book style artwork and stories into theatrical presentations for stage and film. Successes include stage/film versions of The Glam Divas Show, where his fierce illustrated characters come to life in the form of actors, models, and drag queens. www.glamdivas.net
Upstate born Mark Thaddeus Williams is the technical member of the team, responsible for graphic realization and music direction. A graduate of Colgate and Yale Universities, he is a Manhattan based freelance graphic designer. www.markthaddeus.com
Inspired By...
Written as both play and screenplay by Robert Monegan, Defiantly Fabulous is a comedic and gay twist on the classic 1958 film, "The Defiant Ones". It starred Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier, about two escaped convicts, one white, one black, shackled together, hate each other, but must help each other, in order to survive and outrun the law. Great film, serious drama. Robert always wanted to do a gay version of the story. Not really a spoof, but semi same plot as original film, only comedic, catty, over the top, plenty of pop culture winks, set in the funky 1970s, and gay eye candy galore....so he wrote one. Originally Robert wrote it as a play, but after a chance meeting with SIDNEY POITIER, who suggested switching  it to a screenplay, Robert did as such.

story:
Love Sick is the debut play by Kristina Poe. Airport Bar Productions is presenting this hilarious, exciting, passionate story at Theater for the New City from February 3 - 25.

Emily is Love Sick. Her husband has left her for a younger woman. She's killed one man who's crossed her. And worse, she's started smoking again. Family and friends offer no help. And group therapy ends up disappointing her. Can a mysterious Man be the answer to rekindling her lost passion? Or will her husband finally realize the love he's thrown away? And how many men have to die before she finds the answer?

Developed with LAByrinth Theater and featuring LAB company members Elizabeth Canavan, Maggie Burke, Michael Puzzo, Charles Goforth, Justin Reinsilber, and playwright Kristina Poe. Also featuring Cara Akselrad and J. Eric Cook.

The Distracted Globe Foundation has awarded Love Sick a $5,000 grant (YEAH!) that we would like to match. Funds raised from this indiegogo campaign will go directly toward production expenses (lighting, scenery, costumes and sound) for Love Sick.

Thank you for helping make this dream come true!

Love Sick is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Virginia and my son loves to dance.  And we don't mean loves to move around - he loves dance.  From the age of 3 we knew Weston saw the world different, he felt it different and he heard it different.  We explored avenues to help him control his body movements and his "energy" as it was often called. (His nickname is Wind).  We decided to encourage it instead by enrolling him in his first ballet class.  At age 3 he took to the stage and fell in love!

At 7 years of age, he now has been asked to be part of 2 competition groups and does tap, jazz, ballet, hip hop, and musical theater.  And dance has changed his life.  However, competition and dance are a financial toll for our family.  The studio has been generous and given us a break, and we are doing trade deals for individual classes, but this will not get him to competitions.

We are asking for funding because we don't want his love of dance ever discouraged, and as a boy, BOY HAS IT EVER.  We've endured many a comment regarding the fact that he is a young boy in dance and he has too, but he truly doesn't care, he loves dance.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for 5,000 dollars for two reasons, so we can pay the studio what they are worth!  The teachers at Ryan's American Dance have embraced Weston and have done so much for our family.  He spends every afternoon for numersous hours at the studio.  They are incredible teachers, dancers, and mentors.  Finally, the funds are so we can get him to at least 2 competitions this year and to a 6-week dance intensive program over the summer.  We started looking at options at Stanford but we shut it down when we saw the cost.  I want Weston to feel the support and love that a boy, at any age, can take on this sport and have the opportunity to share his passion.

The Impact

The impact would be huge for Weston.  He would see the world pouring out support for a young boy dancer.   We have had many meetings with teachers, professionals, peditricians who have "advised" us about Weston's inability to focus, and I just smile because at age 6 my son did a 3 hour performance with 8 dances and 7 costume change all on his own (you see there isn't usually a lot of help backstage when you are the only boy and there are 50 girls to contend with).  The first performance, I wrung my hands worried sick what was going to happen, and he came on like a star and at the end of the night he said "that was the best night of my life, this is what I want to do".

story:
Requiem

My name is John-Mark Owen. I am an independent ballet choreographer living and working in New York City. I have danced with several different ballet companies here and across America all with the goal in mind of making my own work when the time was right. I completed my graduate studies at NYU/Tisch School of the Arts a couple of years ago and have shown my choreography successfully since at venues including Jacob's Pillow Inside/Out Dance Festival, NYC's Ballet Builders, 92 St. Y/Harkness Dance Center, Symphony Space NYC, the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theatre and Joe's Pub to name a few. Please visit johnmarkowen.com for further information.

The Time Is Right

 Requiem is the result of 5 years of work and is quite personal. As a gay man, and a product of a community that does not accept homosexuality, mine has always been the search for truth in all aspects of living.

 Requiem is an exploration of how masculinity is defined in societal terms. My aim is to encourage a dialogue around the societal archetype of men. This is because I see a continued regard of homosexual men as both “less than man” and “other.” Though homosexuals have gained societal recognition for many achievements over these past few years, there lingers a thought that homosexuality, among men, is less than masculine. Until that thought is dispelled, inequality will persist. By redefining societal archetypes, perhaps we can come to know that masculinity has more to do with courage of conviction than uber examples of stalwart strength. 

It is my interest to combine the intensity and raw emotion of Dance Theatre with the melodic grace of balletic line. By imbuing balletic line with the immediacy, and unabashed exploration, of Dance Theatre I believe the intrinsic beauty of balletic line can be enhanced. To achieve this the body must become narrative. Sculptural shapes must be manipulated through transitions to build atmosphere and purpose. This leads to an experiential, essential, cinematic approach, which I believe has sustaining value. With this approach in mind I will create a work that centers on a narrative compelled by the musical score; where raw human experience is conveyed through the body as language. I will develop a working vocabulary that utilizes the classical principles of form and structure yet gives way to evocative imagery. With this vocabulary I will create a painterly world that captures the essence of narrative as opposed to literal narrative itself.


The Funding I Need


Requiem will premier at the Manhattan Movement and Arts Center Sept 13-15, 2012. The production requires a cast of 12 dancers. In addition to my dancer's salaries (compensation for 7 weeks of rehearsal and performances), I need to raise money to rent studio space, lighting design, costume design, stage management and various miscellaneous administrative expences. 

Theatre- $7,200, Dancers- $30,000 (12 @ $2,500 per), Lighting design- $2,500, Costume Design- $3,000, Stage management- $2,500, Studio Rental- $2,500, Marketing/Miscellaneous Admin- $5,000. I am quite fortunate that a majority of my development studio space has been granted to me as Artist-In-Residence in Newport, RI for two weeks this summer (http://www.islandmovingco.org/?page_id=230) as well as at the Silo (http://silokirklandfarm.dancenownyc.org/) where we can get a huge amount of work done towards Requiem. 

Your generous contribution will not only go towards making Requiem a reality. It will also contribute to the continued passion around the voice for all whom have experienced the frustration of rejection from "normal" society. Requiem is certainly meant to be metaphorical in it's purpose. I invite you to join with the others who have funded my belief in this before- those who continue to encourage my exuberence for this ballet and propell it forward. If you are unable to contribute monetarily at this time, please share this invitation with everyone you know... fires have to start somewhere, eh? Thank you for your consideration.

Together we can change the world one ballet at a time!

story:
English version (versiÃ³n en espaÃ±ol en la parte inferior de la pÃ¡gina)

Our Story

â€œDios de Adrenalinaâ€ is a cross cultural collaboration street theater project featuring acrobatic stiltwalking and live music from two US American and two Colombian companies. The Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company from San Francisco, CA and Nemcatacoa Teatro from Bogota, Colombia, each specialize in creating live site-flexible street performances featuring the unique art of acrobatic stiltwalking. Verbo Bala is a VJ/DJ/Spoken word collective from Tucson, AZ and Hojarasca from Carmen de Viboral, Colombia is trio that composes contemporary music with traditional Andean instruments.

In 2010 Carpetbag Brigade Director Jay Ruby and Nemcatacoa Director Nico Cifuentes began to plan a collaboration between their two companies. In 2011 the two companies spent three weeks together exchanging techniques and styles and discussing the issues that connected and divided their cultures. In 2012 the companies are invited to present a collaborative performance at the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogota, Colombia. To assist in creating the musical texture of the live performance the companies have invited Verbo Bala to work as DJ's and bilingual spoken word artists as well as Hojarasca to compose musical textures for the performance.

"Dios de Adrenalina" - A Poetic Thesis Of Trauma

Adrenaline is the source of the fight or flight response in humans. It is regulated by the adrenal glands and impacts the interpretation of our perceptions and thus influences our relationship to reality.  When the adrenal system creates a sense of trauma, we respond to reality in a traumatic manner.  In this way, the metabolic level of the body influences social relations between individuals and cultures.

Violence and drugs are some of the most common and potent causes of imbalances in the adrenal system, and they exist together in a perpetual shadow economy. The economy of weapons and narco-trafficking is a constant link between the USA and Colombia, and this commerce defines the relationship between the two countries. The adrenaline created by this business continually affects communities in both nations with devastating results.

Who is the god of adrenaline that fuels a path of mutual destruction?
What are the pathways to readjust this systemic overdose of adrenaline?
How do we address the continuing cycles of anger, trauma and ignorance?
These are the questions that underlie the Dios de la Adrenalina project.

The Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company, directed by Jay Ruby (San Francisco, California) and Nemcatacoa Teatro, directed by Nicolas Cifuentes (Bogota, Colombia) are engaged in theatrical research around these themes. Together the companies use acrobatic stilt-walking, butoh dance, contact improvisation, and physical theater as a means of creating aesthetic, thought provoking street theater performances.

Verbo-bala (Tucson, Arizona) and Hojorasca (Carmen de Viborral, Colombia) are conducting the musical research for the project. Verbo-bala is a multi-media collective that will provide live music, video projections and bilingual spoken word narrative. Hojorasca is an experimental acoustic musical group evolving the art of traditional Andean music. The musical groups will each create their own scores and collaborate on mixed tracks for the project, as well as perform live with the performance.

Project Origins & History

The Carpetbag Brigade and Nemcatacoa saw each anotherâ€™s work at the 2005 Al Aire Puro Festival in Bogota, Colombia.  In 2010, Jay Ruby and Nicolas Cifuentes worked together in The Carpetbag Brigadeâ€™s Stiltasana seminar in San Francisco, California.  During this time they recognized the common seeds in each otherâ€™s workâ€”influences of David Clarksonâ€™s Stalker Theatre, and the Odin Teatret.  Curiosity about the different aesthetics and trainings of their companies lead to a laboratory project proposal in which the companies would spend three weeks doing research together, sharing techniques of training, and composing creative material.  The companies were able to realize this laboratory in July and August of 2011 through self-raised funds on Kickstarter, the support of the US Embassy, the support of the El Gesto Noble Festival, Teatro Tespys, and La Casa de la Cultura del Carmen de Viboral.

Documentation of this process from Adam Cooper TerÃ¡n, video specialist, is available at the following links and a DVD can be sent if you wish for hard copy.

Laboratory Week 1: http://vimeo.com/28726114
Laboratory Week 2: http://vimeo.com/28728181
Laboratory Week 3: http://vimeo.com/28744070

The Impact

We are examining the shadow economies of guns and drugs through the mediums of acrobatic stiltwalking, spoken word and music. We are confronting our selves as points of contact between the borders of different cultures and different histories to create a powerful experience that seeks to unveil the distance and distinctions between our countries and cultures. We want to create a tapestry of action that is a testimony to the impact of gun and drug induced adrenaline on the autonomic nervous system. We want to retrace the echoes of those collective and personal traumas in order to redress the ignorance and fear that exists as a wall between stereotyped images of one another and transform it into an atmosphere of respect and love through the sharing of public performance.

Our immediate goal for the winter of 2012 is to storyboard an early version of the performance so that we can present it at the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogota and use the success of that endeavor to create support and further opportunities for development and presentation.

What We Need & What You Get

Our Indie Go Go goal is $7777 by February 14th....
We will be 18 people working together in a small village in Colombia.
We are planning a cost effective research time from the beginning of February through the middle of March.
To work as effectively as possible we need to raise $7777 by February 14th!
This money will go towards assisting in travel costs to get all of us to Carmen de Viborral, to  pay for our shelter while we are there together and to assist in our production costs for costumes and props.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help let people know about this project by putting it on your facebook wall, but signing up for our mass emails and by checking out our informational videos.

___________________________________________________________________
En Espanol

Nuestra historia

â€œ Dios de la Adrenalina â€œ es un intercambio cultural y creaciÃ³n colectiva de teatro de calle enfocados en teatro fÃ­sico y acrobÃ¡tico en zancos y mÃºsica en vivo de 2 agrupaciones Norteamericanas y 2 agrupaciones Colombianas. Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company (San Francisco â€“ USA) y FundaciÃ³n grupo artÃ­stico y cultural Nemcatacoa (BogotÃ¡- Col), ambas especializadas en crear espectÃ¡culos de teatro de calle con tÃ©cnicas de acrobacia en zancos. VerboÂ·bala es VJ/DJ/palabra hablada (Tucson â€“ USA) y Hojarasca (Carmen de Viboral â€“ Col) es un triÃ³ que compone mÃºsica contemporÃ¡nea con instrumentos andinos tradicionales.

En el 2010 el director de Carpetbag â€“ Jay Ruby â€“ y el director de Nemcatacoa â€“ Nicolas Cifuentes â€“ comenzaron a planear una colaboraciÃ³n entre sus grupos. En 2011 ambos grupos pasaron juntos 3 semanas intercambiando tÃ©cnicas y estilos y discutiendo sobre los temas que unen y separan sus culturas. En 2012 los grupos estÃ¡n invitados a presentar su coproducciÃ³n en el Festival Iberoamericano de Teatro de BogotÃ¡, Colombia. Para asistir y crear las texturas musicales de la obra fueron invitados VerboÂ·bala y Hojarasca.

â€œDios de la Adrenalina â€œ -- Tesis poÃ©tica del trauma â€“

La adrenalina es el causante de la respuesta en el pelear o huir en los seres humanos. EstÃ¡ regulada por el sistema adrenal, lo cual afecta la interpretaciÃ³n de nuestras percepciones y asÃ­ influencia nuestra relaciÃ³n con la realidad. Cuando el sistema adrenal crea un sentido de trauma, es entonces cuando se responde a la realidad de una manera traumatizada. De esta forma el nivel metabÃ³lico del cuerpo influencia las relaciones sociales entre individuos y culturas. La violencia y las drogas son de las causas mÃ¡s potentes y comunes de los desequilibrios del sistema adrenal, y juntos permanecen en una economÃ­a clandestina. La economÃ­a de trÃ¡fico de armas y el narcotrÃ¡fico existe como un vÃ­nculo constante entre los Estados Unidos y Colombia, y Ã©sta define la relaciÃ³n entre los dos paÃ­ses. La adrenalina creada por este comercio afecta continuamente comunidades en ambas naciones con resultados devastadores. Â¿CÃ³mo podemos tratar los ciclos continuos de enojo, trauma, e ignorancia? Ã‰stas son las preguntas que sirven como punto de partida para el montaje Dios de la Adrenalina.

Carpetbag Brigade (USA) y Nemcatacoa Teatro (Col) estÃ¡n comprometidas en una bÃºsqueda teatral acerca de estos temas. Usando acrobacia en zancos, danza butoh, danza de contacto o contact improvisation y teatro fÃ­sico como lenguaje para crear obras de teatro de calle. VerboÂ·bala (USA) y Hojarasca (Col) estÃ¡n encargados de dirigir la bÃºsqueda musical del proyecto.VerboÂ·bala es un colectivo que mezcla mÃºsica en vivo, video proyecciones y narrativa verbal. Hojarasca es un grupo acÃºstico experimental evolucionando sobre la mÃºsica andina tradicional.
Los grupos compondrÃ¡n piezas para la obra y crearan conjuntamente otras para el proyecto ademÃ¡s de tocar en vivo para las funciones.

Proyecto: OrÃ­genes e Historia

En el Festival al Aire Puro (BogotÃ¡) del aÃ±o 2005 ambos grupos de teatro presenciaron el trabajo escÃ©nico en zancos de cada uno. En 2010 los directores Jay Ruby y NicolÃ¡s Cifuentes trabajaron en el seminario Stiltasana de Carpetbag Brigade en San Francisco, California. AllÃ­ reconocieron las raÃ­ces comunes de su trabajo y las influencias de David Clarkson y el OdÃ­n Theater. El interÃ©s suscitado en los diferentes entrenamientos y la afinidad en la bÃºsqueda estÃ©tica de ambas compaÃ±Ã­as resultÃ³ en una propuesta de creaciÃ³n colectiva que comenzarÃ­a con un laboratorio teatral donde los grupos durante 3 semanas harÃ­an una investigaciÃ³n en zancos, compartirÃ­an tÃ©cnicas de entrenamiento y compondrÃ­an material escÃ©nico. Los grupos realizaron este laboratorio en Julio y Agosto de 2011 con fondos autos gestionados en Kickstarter.com, ademÃ¡s de apoyos de la Embajada de USA en Colombia, el Festival Gesto Noble, Teatro Tespys y la Casa de la Cultura del Carmen de Viboral (Antioquia- Col.).

El impacto

Nosotros estamos examinando la economÃ­a clandestina de trÃ¡fico de armas y drogas a travÃ©s de medios como acrobacia en zancos y mÃºsica. Estamos confrontÃ¡ndonos como puntos de referencia entre las fronteras de diferentes culturas y diferentes historias para crear una experiencia poderosa que busca revelar la distancia y distinciones entre nuestros paÃ­ses y culturas. Nosotros queremos crear un tapiz de acciones que sirva de testimonio del impacto inducido por la adrenalina implÃ­cita en armas y drogas en el sistema nervioso. Queremos re-trazar los ecos de los traumas colectivos y personales para poder corregir la ignorancia y el miedo que existe como una pared de imÃ¡genes estereotipos de una y otra y transformar esto en un atmosfera de respeto y amor a travÃ©s de un espectÃ¡culo pÃºblico de espacios abiertos. Nuestro objetivo inmediato para el invierno 2012 es crear una primera versiÃ³n de la obra para presentar en el Festival Iberoamericano de Teatro de BogotÃ¡ y usar lo positivo de esta primera versiÃ³n para crear a futuro apoyos y oportunidades de desarrollar la obra.

Que necesitamos y que tendrÃ¡s

Nuestro objetivo Indiegogo es â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦..U$ 7777 hasta el 14 de Feb.

story_txt:
English version (versiÃ³n en espaÃ±ol en la parte inferior de la pÃ¡gina)Our Storyâ€œDios de Adrenalinaâ€ is a cross cultural collaboration street theater project featuring acrobatic stiltwalking and live music from two US American and two Colombian companies. The Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company from San Francisco, CA and Nemcatacoa Teatro from Bogota, Colombia, each specialize in creating live site-flexible street performances featuring the unique art of acrobatic stiltwalking. Verbo Bala is a VJ/DJ/Spoken word collective from Tucson, AZ and Hojarasca from Carmen de Viboral, Colombia is trio that composes contemporary music with traditional Andean instruments.In 2010 Carpetbag Brigade Director Jay Ruby and Nemcatacoa Director Nico Cifuentes began to plan a collaboration between their two companies. In 2011 the two companies spent three weeks together exchanging techniques and styles and discussing the issues that connected and divided their cultures. In 2012 the companies are invited to present a collaborative performance at the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogota, Colombia. To assist in creating the musical texture of the live performance the companies have invited Verbo Bala to work as DJ's and bilingual spoken word artists as well as Hojarasca to compose musical textures for the performance. 
"Dios de Adrenalina" - A Poetic Thesis Of TraumaAdrenaline is the source of the fight or flight response in humans. It is regulated by the adrenal glands and impacts the interpretation of our perceptions and thus influences our relationship to reality.  When the adrenal system creates a sense of trauma, we respond to reality in a traumatic manner.  In this way, the metabolic level of the body influences social relations between individuals and cultures.Violence and drugs are some of the most common and potent causes of imbalances in the adrenal system, and they exist together in a perpetual shadow economy. The economy of weapons and narco-trafficking is a constant link between the USA and Colombia, and this commerce defines the relationship between the two countries. The adrenaline created by this business continually affects communities in both nations with devastating results.Who is the god of adrenaline that fuels a path of mutual destruction?What are the pathways to readjust this systemic overdose of adrenaline?How do we address the continuing cycles of anger, trauma and ignorance?These are the questions that underlie the Dios de la Adrenalina project.The Carpetbag Brigade Physical Theater Company, directed by Jay Ruby (San Francisco, California) and Nemcatacoa Teatro, directed by Nicolas Cifuentes (Bogota, Colombia) are engaged in theatrical research around these themes. Together the companies use acrobatic stilt-walking, butoh dance, contact improvisation, and physical theater as a means of creating aesthetic, thought provoking street theater performances.Verbo-bala (Tucson, Arizona) and Hojorasca (Carmen de Viborral, Colombia) are conducting the musical research for the project. Verbo-bala is a multi-media collective that will provide live music, video projections and bilingual spoken word narrative. Hojorasca is an experimental acoustic musical group evolving the art of traditional Andean music. The musical groups will each create their own scores and collaborate on mixed tracks for the project, as well as perform live with the performance.
Project Origins & HistoryThe Carpetbag Brigade and Nemcatacoa saw each anotherâ€™s work at the 2005 Al Aire Puro Festival in Bogota, Colombia.  In 2010, Jay Ruby and Nicolas Cifuentes worked together in The Carpetbag Brigadeâ€™s Stiltasana seminar in San Francisco, California.  During this time they recognized the common seeds in each otherâ€™s workâ€”influences of David Clarksonâ€™s Stalker Theatre, and the Odin Teatret.  Curiosity about the different aesthetics and trainings of their companies lead to a laboratory project proposal in which the companies would spend three weeks doing research together, sharing techniques of training, and composing creative material.  The companies were able to realize this laboratory in July and August of 2011 through self-raised funds on Kickstarter, the support of the US Embassy, the support of the El Gesto Noble Festival, Teatro Tespys, and La Casa de la Cultura del Carmen de Viboral.
Documentation of this process from Adam Cooper TerÃ¡n, video specialist, is available at the following links and a DVD can be sent if you wish for hard copy.Laboratory Week 1: http://vimeo.com/28726114Laboratory Week 2: http://vimeo.com/28728181Laboratory Week 3: http://vimeo.com/28744070The ImpactWe are examining the shadow economies of guns and drugs through the mediums of acrobatic stiltwalking, spoken word and music. We are confronting our selves as points of contact between the borders of different cultures and different histories to create a powerful experience that seeks to unveil the distance and distinctions between our countries and cultures. We want to create a tapestry of action that is a testimony to the impact of gun and drug induced adrenaline on the autonomic nervous system. We want to retrace the echoes of those collective and personal traumas in order to redress the ignorance and fear that exists as a wall between stereotyped images of one another and transform it into an atmosphere of respect and love through the sharing of public performance.Our immediate goal for the winter of 2012 is to storyboard an early version of the performance so that we can present it at the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogota and use the success of that endeavor to create support and further opportunities for development and presentation.
What We Need & What You GetOur Indie Go Go goal is $7777 by February 14th....We will be 18 people working together in a small village in Colombia.We are planning a cost effective research time from the beginning of February through the middle of March. To work as effectively as possible we need to raise $7777 by February 14th!This money will go towards assisting in travel costs to get all of us to Carmen de Viborral, to  pay for our shelter while we are there together and to assist in our production costs for costumes and props.Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help let people know about this project by putting it on your facebook wall, but signing up for our mass emails and by checking out our informational videos.___________________________________________________________________En Espanol

story:
6th Annual Bet Lahem Live Festival

The sixth annual Bet Lahem Live Festival takes off again this year from August 1st – 3rd  2019, next to Israel’s Apartheid Wall!  This is an annual opportunity for Bethlehem to celebrate its city with the rest of the world—linking local communities to global action, with an extensive list of local and international talented performers and four full days of activities — including workshops, conferences with speakers from around the world, and international and community panels. 

Together, we celebrate culture and produce programming, which challenges local and international notions of justice, faith, and community in a globalized world.

Who We Are

Bet Lahem live is brought to you by the Holy Land Trust, in cooperation with the Bethlehem Municipality and Governorate, Ministry of Tourism -  attracting more than 25,000 visitors each year. 
Bet Lahem Live Festival is, first and foremost, a community event supporting social responsibility in Palestinian society, specifically of Bethlehemites to their city and their community.  Social responsibility is an essential value for the future of any community and involves every level of society, particularly the corporate world.   
This grassroots, non-profit initiative is possible due to the generous support of actors in our community.  Help us ensure the sustainability of the festival as an open-access, inclusive festival. 

 

2019 Bet Lahem Live Theme 

#IamPalestinian


This year BLF is celebrating Palestinian identity, authenticity, culture & roots to preserve our historical identity and unity. 

While recognizing the unique circumstances of each Palestinian - those living in Gaza, East Jerusalem, in the West Bank, inside the historical borders of Palestine - we reject attempts for the global community to separate us. 

Bethlehem Live combats the erasure of our identity through remerging Palestinian cultural heritage, history & art. Nothing, especially the occupation, can erase or divide this identity.

BLF moved its location from the Old City of Bethlehem to the Rachel Tomb’s area, right next to the Israeli Apartheid Wall. We moved to make the Palestinian voice heard: Nothing breaks or divides a cultural identity aging thousands of years of authenticity.

#IamPalestinian is a holistic movement that will take place in August 2019. It’s another act of nonviolent resistance and steadfastness towards all kinds of injustices that Palestinians have been suffering from for the last seven decades. It is time now to change the status quo through a big collective cultural and artistic act.


Goals and Objectives
Our goal is creating an annual festival that can challenge the local and international community in envisioning an ideal for the future of the Holy Land. To further these goals the objectives of the festival are to create a program that engages, promotes and celebrates the religious diversity and acceptance in Bethlehem; build a cultural platform for the arts and heritage of Bethlehem’s communities to engage, expose exchange and enrich their creativity. Woven together, these create, inspiration and raise awareness to engage the community role in social justice.  

Program & Activities: Cultural, artistic and musical performances, workshops addressing a range of topics, faith panels; community activities, tours and awareness, social justice and handicraft marketplace. 

Partners, Audience & Beneficiaries

Local Audience: Bethlehem, Cities in Palestine and 1948 territories, youth between the age 16 – 28, families and children, intellectuals, artists, artisans, faith leaders, local businesses, Muslim and Christian communities, local organizations and NGO’s. 

International Audience: Tourists, peace-activists, network of our partner organizations and our network of 25,000+, youth and adults 21-35, intellectuals, artists, faith leader, diplomatic entities, international media, twin cities around the world, a network of sister festivals, Palestinian Diaspora – Committees.

story:
THE HISTORY

In August of last year we received a generous space donation and began developing a devised work in response to the loss of indie theater spaces in the New York downtown scene. Our team began working with the historically infamous Bowery Poetry Club to create a fun and vital performance to reinvigorate bare bones theater in a way that incorporates and builds the audience into the show itself.

The creative team that has been assembled are some of the most passionate downtown up and coming artists. We have developed dance numbers, written new music, created thrilling acts all in the style of a late 1920's Weimar underground Cabaret.

Now, after a nearly sold out 2 nights in November we've been invited back to present the next stage of development: more acts, more booze, an even sexier, bloodier, Eschaton.

Part of the stipulation of this project has always been to produce this show on an affordable budget. Miraculously, we did this for $100 the first time around. We've had incredible luck with generous gifts in kind from the Bowery Poetry Club and MTWorks.

(I've personally hand sewn/made 3 tu-tu's from found material. Daniel Irizarry donated his strength to help me haul donated fabric materials all the way from Queens.)

We've cobbled together resources and raised funds with the last two performances but still have a tiny ways to go to support this developing project.


Here's what your support (in any amount) can help us do:


$7 pays for one script to be copied ( we are printing 18)

$15 pays for 1 hour of rehearsal space (a typical production of this size with music, dance and numerous acts rehearses for 40 hours)

$20 pays one artists stipend ( there are 11 total performers, 5 writers, a stage manager and 2 directors)


$30 pays for 1 roll of instant Polaroid film for our period photographer


$100 pays for 1 day of technical rehearsal ( the day that we incorporate lights and sound and special effects)


Other Ways You Can Help:


SPREAD THE WORD!- Help us by sharing this project on Facebook.


DONATE REHEARSAL SPACE- If you have a space with a piano or a dance rehearsal room the space would really help us to cut costs!

DONATE MATERIALS: we are still hunting down a pair of size 10 men's ballet pointe shoes, laundry detergent and food coloring (for stage blood), 

BUY A TICKET: We'd love to see you there!


THE SHOW

The time is now. Join us.

Berlin, 1929 and ESCHATON CABARET devised an act that's getting them evicted. Forbidden to perform, they close their doors. But the audience has their curious demands. . . and what's a girl to do. . . but invite everyone to the cast party. Weimar is ending. Brecht is beginning. Come. Be a part of it. Sometimes a little death isn't so bad.

ESCHATON CABARET
an interactive devised anarchy
with dance, original music and death (defying) acts

written and conceived by: Libby Emmons (2009 Clubbed Thumb Fellow), Michael Niederman (Crosstown Playwrights, Actors Studio Member), Matthew Paul Olmos (Sundance Fellow, terranova Ground Breaker 2012) Jody Christopherson (New York Theater Review web editor), John C. Hume (JOHN HUME LIVE!) and Laura Butler Rivera (CHO H CHO, Mabou Mines).

directed by: Ali Ayala (Blue Box Productions), Christopher Burris, Daniel Irizarry ( CHO H CHO, Mabou Mines)

stage manged by: Rebecca Lowry

Choreographed by: Deborah Wolfson

performed by:

Cate Bottiglione
Jody Christopherson
Stephanie Dodd
Ellie Foumbi
Rachael Hip Flores
John C. Hume
Daniel Irizarry
Richard Kass
Natalya Krimgold
Audra Pace
Michael De Roos


$15 TICKETS can be purchased in advance or at the door 30 min prior to show. Stay tuned for VIP and FB friend deals. https://

http://

New York Theatre Review post: read more about the origin and exciting development of the show here: http://

back to present the next stage of development: more acts, more booze, an even sexier, bloodier, Eschaton.
Part of the stipulation of this project has always been to produce this show on an affordable budget. Miraculously, we did this for $100 the first time around. We've had incredible luck with generous gifts in kind from the Bowery Poetry Club and MTWorks. 
(I've personally hand sewn/made 3 tu-tu's from found material. Daniel Irizarry donated his strength to help me haul donated fabric materials all the way from Queens.)

We've cobbled together resources and raised funds with the last two performances but still have a tiny ways to go to support this developing project.

Here's what your support (in any amount) can help us do:

$7 pays for one script to be copied ( we are printing 18)

$15 pays for 1 hour of rehearsal space (a typical production of this size with music, dance and numerous acts rehearses for 40 hours)
$20 pays one artists stipend ( there are 11 total performers, 5 writers, a stage manager and 2 directors)

$30 pays for 1 roll of instant Polaroid film for our period photographer

$100 pays for 1 day of technical rehearsal ( the day that we incorporate lights and sound and special effects)

Other Ways You Can Help:

SPREAD THE WORD!- Help us by sharing this project on Facebook. 

DONATE REHEARSAL SPACE- If you have a space with a piano or a dance rehearsal room the space would really help us to cut costs!
DONATE MATERIALS: we are still hunting down a pair of size 10 men's ballet pointe shoes, laundry detergent and food coloring (for stage blood),  

BUY A TICKET: We'd love to see you there!


THE SHOW
The time is now. Join us.  Berlin, 1929 and ESCHATON CABARET devised an act that's getting them evicted. Forbidden to perform,
 they close their doors. But the audience has their curious demands. . .
 and what's a girl to do. . . but invite everyone to the
cast party. Weimar is ending. Brecht is beginning. Come. Be a part of 
it. Sometimes a little death isn't so bad. ESCHATON CABARET an interactive devised anarchy with dance, original music and death (defying) acts
 written and conceived by: Libby Emmons (2009 Clubbed Thumb Fellow), 
Michael Niederman (Crosstown Playwrights, Actors Studio Member), Matthew
 Paul Olmos (Sundance Fellow, terranova Ground Breaker 2012) Jody 
Christopherson (New York Theater Review web editor), John C. Hume (JOHN 
HUME LIVE!) and Laura Butler Rivera (CHO H CHO, Mabou Mines). directed by: Ali Ayala (Blue Box Productions), Christopher Burris, Daniel Irizarry ( CHO H CHO, Mabou Mines) stage manged by: Rebecca Lowry Choreographed by:  Deborah Wolfson performed by: Cate Bottiglione Jody Christopherson Stephanie Dodd Ellie Foumbi Rachael Hip Flores John C. Hume  Daniel Irizarry Richard Kass Natalya Krimgold Audra Pace Michael De Roos  $15 TICKETS can be purchased in advance or at the door 30 min prior to show. Stay tuned for VIP and FB friend deals. https://http:// New York Theatre Review post: read more about the origin and exciting development of the show here: http://

story:
Our Story

In 1887 Lloyd Osbourne approached his step-father Robert Louis Stevenson with a draft of a comic novel, asking for advice.  Stevenson enjoyed the novel and agreed to collaborate on it, and in 1889 they came out with a delightful black comedy, The Wrong Box.  When Rudyard Kipling read the book, he wrote: 

I have got R.L. Stevenson's [The Wrong Box] and laughed over it dementedly when I read it.

 

After reading “The Wrong Box” and laughing as much as Rudyard Kipling, I thought it had to be brought to the stage.  One of RLS’s lesser-known works, the story is rich and exciting and the characters the sort of delightful, scheming antiheroes one can root for and against at the same time.  And their passions are so big, it simply cried out for musicalization.

 

Luckily, musicals are what I write.  I worked like crazy for months writing an adaptation of The Wrong Box, which went on to be produced at Union College in Schenectady, NY in 2002.  Audiences laughed and laughed.  Later, in 2006, selections were performed at the Golden Fleece Composers Chamber Theatre in NYC, and now – much later and after years of revising, perfecting, and generally still loving to work on this project - I have decided to make a studio recording.

 

For more information on “The Wrong Box,” my background in musical theater and other shows I’ve written, visit:  http://www.kitgoldstein.com

 

 

SYNOPSIS

A mysterious corpse is knocking about Victorian England, and two unscrupulous cousins are desperately trying to find it – except when they’re desperately trying to lose it!  If the corpse in the train wreck turns out to be Uncle Joseph then Cousin Michael wins the family inheritance, unless Cousin Morris can dispose of the body first.  From pillar to post, from packing-case to piano, the hapless heirs scramble to keep up with the vanishing cadaver in this musical adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic farce.

 

Read the novel of “The Wrong Box” here:  http://www.gutenberg.org/files/1585/1585-h/1585-h.htm

 

See information on "The Wrong Box" and the 1966 movie featuring Michael Caine and Peter Sellers on IMDB:  http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061204/

 

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised on Indie Go-Go will go toward studio expenses, CD duplication, packaging and distribution costs, and stipends for singers and musicians.  If the entire amount is not raised, the project will still continue on a reduced scale.

The CD will be released digitally, and also be used for marketing “The Wrong Box” to theater companies around the country. 

To thank you for your contribution, you will receive one or more completed CDs, signed by the author.  See the “Perks” section for details!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends!  Please share on Facebook, Twitter, in person, by e-mail, on the phone… however you like!

Do you know a producer at a theatre company interested in developing new musicals?  Put us in touch with them or send them a copy of the CD!

If you are a performer in the Albany NY area and would like to be involved in recording the CD, send us a note at newclassicmusicals@gmail.com and we will be in touch with you about auditions.

story:
THE STORY

KILLING JOHN GRISHAM follows aspiring author Josh’s quest to escape his minimum wage life, derailed by self-doubt, girl problems, and loyal friends with violent tendencies. Did we mention the world famous author who steals Josh's book? That too.

THE TEAM

Written by Jack Moore

Produced by Mandy Menaker 

(Recipient of 2011 NYU Tisch Faculty Commendation in Producing)

Directed by Nicole A. Watson 

Member, Women's Project Directors Lab

(Eli and Cheryl Jump, 2009 Fringe, Two Gentlemen of Verona, The 52nd Street Project)


Starring:

Christopher Cartmill as John Grisham

(recipient of the Roger L. Stevens Award from

the Kennedy Center Fund for New American plays) 

Matthew Tully Brown as Josh

Nathan Dame as Kevin

Molly Anne Coogan as Rebecca

Michael Sutherland as Michael


THE FESTIVAL

The New York International Fringe Festival – FringeNYC

A production of The Present Company

August 12-28th

Tickets: $15 -18. For tickets visit www.FringeNYC.org

Specific performance dates and times coming soon.


HOW YOU CAN HELP

KILLING JOHN GRISHAM has been a work in development for four years. KILLING JOHN GRISHAM started as a writing class exercise in NYU’s Tisch Department of Dramatic Writing in 2007. The show was selected for NYU’s Gallatin Playwrights Workshop in 2010 and received its first public reading. From the reading the show was nominated for the 2010 Cherry Lane Mentor Program. The 2011 New York International Fringe Festival will be the first fully staged production of the show.


We need your help to make this production possible. As a thank you for your generous support, we have several levels of gifts and recognitions. There is no donation too big or small. Everything helps. Please be a part of this outstanding play!

story:
Our Story

We are "Teman Hutan"...a travelling troupe of actors performing for communities in the heart of Borneo.  "Teman Hutan" is Indonesian, but in English translates to "Friends of the Forest", and that is exactly what we are...friends of the forest.  Our performance illustrates the negative effects of deforestation while promoting alternative sustainable livelihoods for the indigenous Dayak people.  Our performance also highlights the needs of endangered animals, such as the orangutan, demonstrating why it is better for them to live in the wild as opposed to being kept in captivity or sold into the illegal animal trade.


The Impact

Our goal is to provide sustainable income options for the Dayak people, empowering them to live independently.  If successful, the they will no longer be forced to sell their land to unscrupulous companies to put food on their tables.  They will no longer feel the only option to make a living is to work on gold mines under horrible conditions that poison their bodies as well as the river so many depend on.


The sustainable alternative we illustrate in our performance is the Sugar Palm.  This tree only grows in a  healthy, bio-diverse jungle...not in the deforested, mono-culture plantations the Oil Palm needs to thrive.  The Sugar Palm tree can provide electricity for an entire village, as well as fuel for cooking.  Families are able to collect sugar from the juice of the Sugar Palm, and sell this sugar to a world-wide market through an already existing cooperative.


We also aim to positively impact endangered animals such as orangutans, sun bears, and gibbons.  During our travels we will come across many of these animals in unhealthy situations.  Our performance shows the benefits these animals have on the health of the forest, when they are able to live freely, and will hopefully lead to their release.


We are also part of a global project titled DeforestACTION.  There are other teams working working with us within DeforestACTION to bring captive animals to animals rescue centers where the animals will be rehabilitated and released back into the wild.  There is also a team that will pass out Sugar Palm seedlings to villages that have shown interest in growing their own Sugar Palms.


What We Are Fundraising For

In order to make truly moving, and educational presentations, there are some things we need.  Most importantly is the travel expense to get to Borneo, as well as travel expenses once we are there.  We will have to pay for many river trips to get to the remote villages in the jungle, and we'll need to pay for the fuel to get there as well.  Food and lodging is also of high importance.  If we are able to get enough funding, having a satellite phone and a gps system would be a great comfort in terms of safety and the possibility of getting lost in the jungle!


There are also items needed for the actual performance.  These include mobile speakers, basic costume pieces, various props, high quality durable drama masks, a projector, projector screen, and a mobile power source for performing in villages without electricity.  We will also be leaving educational materials and pamphlets with the communities we perform in, so printing costs will be a part of what we are fundraising for as well.


If we are unable to reach our goal of $6,000 dollars, we will do our best with the amount that has been raised.


Unique Perks

We have fun gifts for all different levels of donations! These include becoming a member of our exclusive email list, having a song written just for you, or even a private musical concert in your home!

story:
Daisy's Madhouse is a non-profit fringe theater in Boise. Its mission is to produce bold, innovative and quality theater, which aims:

  • To diversify and expand the audience for theater in the Treasure Valley by actively reaching out to younger audiences, cultivating the next generation of theatre goers.
  • To develop theater artists by providing new opportunities for performance and artistic exploration.
  • To champion a broad and diverse base of local art and artists. We intend for our theatre to be a physical and creative intersection for community and art in Boise. Our productions often challenge traditional theatrical forms and conventions, incorporating music, dance, performance art and/or digital media.
  • To enrich the Treasure Valley community by producing the Will Act 4 Food Festival to raise funds for the Idaho Food Bank.


By donating to Daisy's Madhouse fall campaign you are ensuring the ongoing success of daring theatre that has meaning in the Treasure Valley.  This Fall we are, ambitiously, producing two wonderful works for the Stage. 


The Laramie Project: 10 years later. On October 6th of 1998 Matthew Shepard was beaten and left to die tied to a fence in the outskirts of Laramie, Wyoming. He died six days later. His murder became a watershed historical moment in America that highlighted the violence and prejudice lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people face. A month after the murder, the members of Tectonic Theater Project traveled to Laramie and conducted interviews with the people of the town. From these interviews they wrote the play The Laramie Project, which they later made into a film for HBO. One of the most performed plays of the last decade, the piece has been seen by more than 50 million people around the country.

The Laramie Project - 10 Years Later is the sequel to this play. The epilogue focuses on the long-term effect of the murder of Matthew Shepard on the town of Laramie. It explores how the town has changed and how the murder continues to reverberate in the community. The play also includes new interviews with Matthew's mother Judy Shepard and Mathew's murderer Aaron McKinney, who's serving dual life sentences, as well as follow-up interviews with many of the individuals from the original piece.


Evil Dead: the Musical!  The "disarmingly" funny musical adaptation of the cult classic films that starred Bruce Campbell, and launched Sam Raimi's directing career. Evil Dead: the Musical tells the tale of 5 college kids who travel to a cabin in the woods and accidentally unleash an evil force. And although it may sound like a horror, it's not! The songs are hilariously campy and the show is bursting with more farce than a Monty Python skit. Evil Dead: The Musical unearths the old familiar story: boy and friends take a weekend getaway at abandoned cabin, boy expects to get lucky, boy unleashes ancient evil spirit, friends turn into Candarian Demons, boy fights until dawn to survive. As musical mayhem descends upon this sleepover in the woods, "camp" takes on a whole new meaning with uproarious numbers like "All the Men in my Life Keep Getting Killed by Candarian Demons," "Look Who's Evil Now" and "Do the Necronomicon."


Daisy's Madhouse needs you to donate whatever amount you can afford to help us produce these wonderful works.  We are committed to keeping ticket prices low to ensure across the board accessibility to attend the theatre. We are only asking for enough money to give the community quality productions of each of these shows. Your support of Daisy's Madhouse in turn supports the community of theatres, at large.


Please help us get the word out!  Donate, and tell others to donate.  Please share this on your Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, via email.  Just tell people about it!  If you are unable to donate to the campaign, please make sure to come see the shows.  They are going to be amazing!  Thank you for your support, and let's all band together to get this done!

story:
Short Summary

I have been offered a role in an African American Theatre show that is going to premiere in Singapore, over Spring Break 2014. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity that I am anxious to be able to do. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to  go to Singapore however I need to raise $1500 to go before Feb. 1st 2014. Any help or assistance that you would be willing to give would be greatly appreciated!!!

This trip is important to me because it will hopefully take my theatre skills and knowledge to another level by adding other cultural influences and experiences to my acting. 

I have little to give in exchange, but would like to offer some sort of incentive. For the following donations, you will receive a small token of my appreciation! 

$10 donation you will receive a personalized postcard from Singapore

$25 donation you will receive a mini photo album with photos collected from my travels

$100 donation you will receive a souvenir from SIngapore!!! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute please just pass the word along! 

Thanks!

story:
Summary

Back by popular demand! On Friday, August 16th, A Mile In My Shoes, Inc. (AMIMS) will partner with NYC Black Pride to feature another reading of The Anointed, a play in which four African-American ministers are forced to wrestle with their own truth—truths that could set them free or destroy their ministries.

The Anointed engages a discourse about sexuality, spirituality and theology in the Black church. It was inspired by interviews with very prominent, same-gender-loving, African-American church leaders, namely: Bishop Yvette Flunder, Bishop Wyatt Greenlee, Reverend Kevin Taylor, Pastor Joseph Tolton and Marques Moore, an African-American survivor of multiple ex-gay ministries.

This play will attempt to bring a heightened awareness of the historical trauma inflicted on Black LGBT individuals by the homophobic hegemony intrinsic in the Black church experience and to encourage enlightened conversation that will advance healing for Black LGBT people and within the Black community.

In order to produce this reading of The Anointed, AMIMS is looking to raise $2,000. These funds will go towards the costs of paying the actors, director, and musicians involved.

Any and all monetary donations are appreciated. Even if you donate $5, that means we are $5 closer to our goal! Progress!

There are a myriad of perks listed below for your contribution. 

A Mile In My Shoes, Inc. is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of A Mile In My Shoes, Inc. must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Join the event on Facebook.

Invite a friend to The Anointed! 

RSVP for the event!

Use Indiegogo's Share Tools to share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and everywhere on the Internet. Help us spread the word!

Tell a friend about our campaign!


Contact us with questions or for more information: info@amims.org

Use Indiegogo's Share Tools to share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and everywhere on the Internet. Help us spread the word!
Tell a friend about our campaign!
Contact us with questions or for more information: info@amims.org

story:
Spreading Light

Theatre is a powerful commodity. It can entertain, provide escape, lift our spirits, and at times enlighten. It can, we believe, make a difference. This is our goal with FACING EAST. 

I saw the play, FACING EAST, in San Francisco a few years ago with it's original cast, and was moved to tears. I was in San Francisco working on another musical, and had been looking for a new project. I wanted to create something that could entertain, move, and create dialogue. I wanted to change the world! Ambitious, perhaps. But in FACING EAST I saw the potential to make that dream a reality. 

The story was simple. A Mormon couple at the funeral of their son (who had committed suicide because of internal conflicts he faced between his sexual orientation and his deep religious beliefs) meet his lover. Conflict turns to a desperate need for understanding. 

I reached out to the playwright, Carol Lynn Pearson, who happened to live nearby in the Bay Area. After meeting her, and explaining that I wanted to adapt FACING EAST into a musical (a MUSICAL!), she balked. She expected something along the lines of THE BOOK OF MORMON, I think. But as I explained my vision: an intimate, almost chamber-style folk musical that would not chastise religion, but encourage dialogue. A piece that simply asks for open minds, and acceptance, in a time when suicide among the young LGBT community is far too common. 

Happilly, she gave her blessing. We've been lucky to have Mark-Eugene Garcia, and David Rigano aboard as our writers, who have crafted a piece that brings every emotion possible to the surface. Our director, Andrew Hobgood, is a rising star in the Chicago theatre industry. Our producing team features ambitious talents from across North America, and even Australia! 

Following an initial workshop reading in Chicago, we now move forward with plans to present a concert/workshop of the show in the Dallas area this July, prior to a full production next season!

We are thrilled to also announce that the concert will feature the talents of JULIE JOHNSON as Ruth, (National Tour of MEMPHIS, Broadway production of CANDIDE, Baby Bop from TV's BARNIE), and MAX SWARNER as Marcus (rising star in the Texas theatrical industry).

Profits from the box office of this concert will go to a local LGBT charity in Dallas. It is very important to us that this be the musical that truly gives back. Our hope is that through this concert, we'll build the momentum we need to mount the show's first fully staged production next season.

I hope that you will join us on this journey. Developing a musical is not easy, but together we can create something truly special. One step at a time.

Thank you!

-Nathan Gardner, producer

 

What We Need & What You Get

Every penny helps! Your contribution will help us to

  • Provide stipends for actors/musicians/crew involved
  • Cover the travel costs to assemble our creative team, and writers 
  • Provide housing for out-of-town talent and creatives
  • Create an advertising and marketing campaign that will help us to sell out and provide the most help the the beneficiaries and further develop the piece!

In return, you're eligable for the perks we've listed on the right. You're also part of creating a new musical. You're becoming part of our family. And we'll never forget your generosity and support. Theatre can touch lives. Theatre can make a difference. You can make a difference. 

The Impact

By contributing, you're doing more than just supporting a new musical. You're supporting a movement working towards acceptance and offering help to young people in the LGBT community who struggle with who they are. Together we can all make things a lot easier for them. 

I know this is possible, because when I was a teen I struggled deeply with who I was and learning to accept myself. A little musical called BARE helped me achieve that inner acceptance. Theatre can make a difference. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, there's lots of ways to help! Share the campaign on social media, tweet us, e-mail, watch and share the videos! Everything helps!

And again... THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!

story:
What is The TRUF?

We are a theater company with a mission: to share stories among people, with a focus on bridging the gap between generations.

We produce children's shows and "grown-up" shows in repertory, with pieces based on similar themes and ideas.

We believe that 5 year-olds and 55 year-olds feel the same things day in and day out...we just don't always know how to talk to each other about it. The TRUF is planting that seed of conversation. And according to TimeOut NY, we "may very well be going places!" (Thanks!)

Sarazad & The Monster-King

"Sarazad" was the first children's show The TRUF commissioned in the summer of 2011. Written by the brilliant EJC Calvert, "Sarazad" is a re-imagining of "Scherezade and the 1,001 Arabian Nights."

It explores the life of 9 year old storyteller Sarazad who is bullied at school by those who don't think having an active imagination is all that cool. As she retreats into a fantastical world of her own making, Sarazad meets a Monster-King whose only distraction from making Sarazad his lunch are her incredible stories. As she weaves tales of pirate captains, talking fish, monkey detectives and bossy robots, Sarazad not only makes a hero of a monster, but also learns to face her playground foes.

Why Your Support is So Important

Along with the entire city of New York, The TRUF faced a very unexpected bully of our own in November of 2012 : Hurricane Sandy. Completely flooding our partner theater and forcing us to end the run of our fall play "The Baltimore Waltz," Sandy destroyed almost all of the props, costumes and set pieces that our new company had begun to build and acquire. Losing performances also fatally impacted our ability to carry on with a Spring 2013 season. 

Sarazad at FringeNYC has given us an opportunity to restore the momentum The TRUF had been growing when we were stopped in our tracks. It also gives us a chance to breathe new life into a show that we believe children and their families all across the city, state, country (and world!) deserve to see.

Every dollar you give goes DIRECTLY to making "Sarazad" a reality. Your generosity helps to pay for:

  • fees involved with being one of the lucky FringeNYC shows (~ $800)
  • the incredible actors, designers, and creative team (~$900)
  • the magic and fantasy that come with brilliant lighting design (~$450)
  • STUNNING costumes (~$350 ... and this is NOTHING because our designer is a genius!)
  • creative, mobile set pieces : trunks & curtain (~$300)
  • props for the monkey, the monsters and the storyteller (~$150)
  • insurance, so that everyone is always safe (~$150)
  • transportation to get our cast and crew to YOU! (~$500)
  • marketing and publicity so that we can tour "Sarazad" into schools and theaters in your neighborhood (~$500)

As you can see, just this revival production costs about $4,100, but we know times are tough. Any and all help you're willing to give is so very appreciated!

THANK YOU

From the tips of our toes to the hair on our heads, we thank you so very much. And if a donation at this time isn't possible, but a visit might be, come on down to the 14th Street Y in Manhattan to see "Sarazad & The Monster-King" come alive in person. Tickets available here : http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=S#S...

story:
The Corpse Bride was a huge success in its workshop production at Toronto’s Young Centre in 2010.  The challenge?  It’s big.  We proudly employ fourteen actors, three designers, four live musicians, and one composer in a pear tree.  Just kidding. 

Now we need only $6,500 to get it to the Ashkenaz Festival, North America’s largest festival of Yiddish and Jewish culture. 

GREAT NEWS:  Our association with the Ashekenaz Festival enables us to offer tax receipts!! (Please enter your full name and address on the payment page so we can send you the tax receipt.)

The Corpse Bride is about a young groom who accidentally weds himself to a dead bride in this darkly comedic spin on Jewish folklore.  A daring piece of movement theatre, done in the style of silent film, full of eerie theatrical images and colourful Yiddish characters.

We have gathered a team of artists that includes genuine Canadian icon and former prima ballerina Evelyn Hart, as well as wonderful theatre practitioners such as Sarah Orenstein, Richard Greenblatt, William Vickers, Kevin Lamotte, Teresa Przylbylski, and John Gzowski.

Presented by Theatre PANIK, producers of award-winning independent theatre in Toronto, in association with the Ashkenaz  Festival and The Harold Green Jewish Theatre.

 

Dates: August 30th to September 2nd

Where: Harbourfront Centre Box Office • 235 Queens Quay W.
416-973-4000 • http://tickets.harbourfrontcentre.com/production.aspx?id=18797

Featuring:      Jennifer Balen, Nathan Carroll, Colin Doyle, Fraser Elsdon, Patrick Foran, Justin Goodhand, Richard Greenblatt, Evelyn Hart, Carys Lewis, Alexandra Manea, Sarah Orenstein, Andy Trithardt, William Vickers, Candice Woloshyn

Story: Niki Landau

Director: Paul Lampert

Original Music:  John  Gzowski

Set & Costumes:  Teresa Przybylski

Lighting:  Kevin Lamotte

Videography:  Cameron Davis

Stage Management: Sarah Miller

Assistant Direction: Robert Levine

Assistant Stage Manager: Nellwyn Lampert

 

http://www.ashkenazfestival.com/theatre-panik

story:
CAST (College of Arts and Science Theater) is a New York University student-run organization dedicated to providing opportunities to get involved in all aspects of theater including performing, directing, designing, writing, choreography and everything else on-stage and back-stage.  We put on a variety of performances throughout the school year from one-act play festivals to full-length shows to our popular musical revue parody performed over NYU Parents & Alumni weekend.

This spring we are excited to be putting on a production of Stephen Schwartz's Godspell.

Auditions were open to all of NYUs undergraduate schools and an extremely talented and hardworking cast was assembled with actors majoring in everything from Math and Psychology to Dance and Vocal Studies. For many of our performers, C.A.S.T. provides a way to continue to be involved in something they love as an extracurricular activity,while others use CAST's shows to build their performance resumes as they pursue careers on stage and screen.  In fact, two Godspell cast members just recently won roles in professional shows that will be touring this summer. We are thrilled to be working with such a talented and diverse group!

But CAST is facing a challenge this year.

Our home theater space at NYU recently went under construction, leaving us without an assigned performance venue for the first time in club history.

We're flexible and don't mind practicing in empty classrooms and dorm study lounges - but the actual show needs to be in a theater!

The good news is that New York City has many performance spaces. The bad news is that these spaces are expensive for a student-run club with a modest budget.  

Your donation can help CAST get Godspell into a theater. We’d be grateful for your contribution.

Godspell is slated to go up April 19, 20, and 21. 

Thank you so much for your help and support of the arts.
